story:
Every day, worldwide, 2,300 people die from lack of inadequate drinking water, sanitation, and hand hygiene, and women lose 152 million hours collecting water for their families. But it doesn't have to be that way.

My name is Chuck Doofe and I am a senior history major and NROTC midshipman at Tulane University in New Orleans. I've been selected to go to Kenya in December for the Homa Bay Water Project with international non-profit Mama Maji through Rotaract at Tulane. Where I will be going in western Kenya, many rural villages lack access to clean water.

Rotaract means Rotary in Action and we're all about meaningful service, especially making a the biggest impact with every hour and every dollar. You can be a part of that impact.

The Goal

I am raising money to support my trip to Kamrongo and Homa Bay, Kenya in December where I will be visiting a project in Kamrongo of which I have been an integral part through Rotaract over the past year, and facilitating the beginning of a similar project in a neighboring area.

Last year through our Catalyst Walk, Rotaract raised $10,000 to bring water to the Kamrongo community. That money went to training 28 Community Health Volunteers to be advocates in their community for clean water, and then building a kiosk that will be opening soon to serve 2,500 people.

Rotaract is hosting the Catalyst Walk again this year, and it will benefit the Homa Bay community for the same process – training the community, building the kiosk, and fresh water for the area.

The Cost

Total Cost - $1,500

This covers:

• Immunizations needed for international travel

• Flights to and from Kenya

• Transportation to the training site

• Supplies for the women needed during training

• Two meals each day as well as clean water

Help me continue to make a difference in the lives of these women! 50, 40 or even 20 dollars can have a huge impact, and sharing this with just 10 friends is a tremendous help!

story:
Pilgrims for the planet

Yeb Sano and his diverse team of climate pilgrims are walking over 1500 km from Rome - where they were blessed by Pope Francis - through Italy, Switzerland & France to the Paris climate talks at the end of November.  They are bringing the experience of people from the world's vulnerable communities to the climate negotiations, lifting up the voices of those who are most affected by climate change and calling on world leaders to move us towards a future powered by 100% renewables & clean energy.


It's a courageous journey and it will be one of the most moving & personal stories in the lead-up to the climate talks.  Along the way, the pilgrims are speaking at faith communities and in town squares, sleeping in the homes of everyday people, sharing meals  with strangers - connecting with thousands of people.  It's a genuine effort to lift up the call for climate action,  in the humblest of ways.

Yeb and friends need your support.

The pilgrims are walking across Europe just as winter is beginning.  They need your support.  We need to hire an organizer who can:

  • identify the safest routes for their journey
  • find speaking opportunities and coordinate media coverage
  • manage all the details of the pilgrimage
  • engage with local communities and make sure every step of the pilgrimage is a chance to build excitement for Paris.
  • find accommodation - as much as possible the pilgrims are staying for free, but some times they will have to pay for a nights lodging.

The People's Pilgrimage is giving power to citizens around the world to express their desire for a better, more just future, safe and free from climate change.  Please help support Yeb and his team.

Get Involved

You can support the pilgrimage in other ways too:

  • Offering a prayer for Yeb and his team - or send positive thoughts and intentions their way
  • Doing your own climate pilgrimage.  Anyone, anywhere can take a walk - short or long - to somewhere near you that will be affected by climate change or more simply go on a hike for a few hours with friends and family to reflect on climate change.
  • Sharing your pilgrimage to inspire others on the global People's Pilgrimage map at www.peoplespilgrimage.org - where you can see other pilgrims stories.
  • Follow The People's Pilgrimage on Twitter at @ourvoices2015 on Instagram at instagram.com/peoplespilgrimage or on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/ourvoices2015

story:
A small miracle

On October 25th 2011 the beautiful town of Monterosso al Mare (Cinque Terre, Italy) was hit by a flash flood. At least nine people have been killed, many others are missing, homes were destroyed and the town is currently isolated from the rest of the world. They have no electricity, no food and no gas. The damages caused by this natural disaster are endless. It will take years to rebuild everything.


Monterosso occupies a very special place in my heart. Most of my family is from there. I grew up playing soccer on the beautiful beach in Fegina or having a fresh granita while talking a stroll through the town with my friends. It's a little paradise populated with a lot of good hearted people. Being there for a few hours can recharge your soul for a whole year. Now things are different, though. 

The beach I used to play soccer on doesn't exist any longer. The streets, shops and bars I went to are buried in feet and feet of mud. Monterosso and it's people are on their knees, praying for a miracle.

We can provide that, at least in a small version of it. PLEASE HELP ME DO IT!!


The Impact

I will personally make sure that the money will be handed to the town's mayor or to the town hall. It will be used to help the population of the town. It might be sufficient to buy some food, restore a few phone lines or finance (in part) the construction of a new sewer system. The old one has been destroyed by the flood.

The town will need more than millions of dollars and a few years to get back to it's everyday life. We can help out, but we need to act now!


Please post this on your facebook page, on your twitter, send a few emails or text people you know. Do not hesitate to send me a message if you should have any questions. I will be happy to answer all of them


Here is one more reason to help:

(from http://www.fattidicronaca.it/ )

Time also to take stock. Vernazza and Monterosso in the Cinque Terre , are on their knees. The mayor of Monterosso Angelo Maria Betta has revealed that in his village the damage amounted to 30 million. All is to rebuild roads, squares, beaches, sewage. "Monterosso is drowning in the mud but the channels were cleaned - said the mayor - have sold the dry stone walls and a huge mass of mud came down to the sea on Tuesday strength was five and he could not receive. "

The Government has allocated 56 million for all affected areas, a figure considered to be insufficient since Monterosso alone had thirty million worth of damages!


The Flood is now in Genova!! Please check out the new pics in the gallery! Help us!


EVEN THE SMALLEST CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP. ALL TOGETHER, WE CAN PROVIDE THEM SOME RELIEF!

(Just FYI: 1 US dollar = 0.7515 euros)

I will personally make sure that the money will be handed to the town's mayor or to the town hall. It will be used to help the population of the town. It might be sufficient to buy some food, restore a few phone lines or finance (in part) the construction of a new sewer system. The old one has been destroyed by the flood.
The town will need more than millions of dollars and a few years to get back to it's everyday life. We can help out, but we need to act now!

Please post this on your facebook page, on your twitter, send a few emails or text people you know. Do not hesitate to send me a message if you should have any questions. I will be happy to answer all of them

Here is one more reason to help:
(from http://www.fattidicronaca.it/ )

Time also to take stock. Vernazza and Monterosso in the Cinque Terre , are on their knees. The mayor of Monterosso Angelo Maria Betta has revealed that in his village the damage amounted to 30 million. All is to rebuild roads, squares, beaches, sewage. "Monterosso is drowning in the mud but the channels were cleaned - said the mayor - have sold the dry stone walls and a huge mass of mud came down to the sea on Tuesday strength was five and he could not receive. "
The Government has allocated 56 million for all affected areas, a figure considered to be insufficient since Monterosso alone had thirty million worth of damages!

The Flood is now in Genova!! Please check out the new pics in the gallery! Help us!


EVEN THE SMALLEST CONTRIBUTION WILL HELP. ALL TOGETHER, WE CAN PROVIDE THEM SOME RELIEF!
(Just FYI: 1 US dollar = 0.7515 euros)

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

Introduce yourself and your background.

My name is Ta Shunke Hinckeka (His Horse is Bay).  I am the son of Chief Dave Bald Eagle of the Cheyenne River Lakota Nation.  I am 65 years old and I have a Ph.D. in History.  I have been a university professor for over 35 years.  Also, I am the International Coordinator of the Indigenous Gathering of the Americas.

Briefly describe your campaign and why it’s important to you.

The campaign I am involved in, has to do with the prophecies that were given to us by our ancestors.  This prophecys are related to the actual problems that humankind is provoking due to its misbehavior regarding the environment.  Polution of the air, waters, lands everywhere is causing major desasters all over the Planet.  The extinction of thousands of species due to human neglet and other environmental problems has taken us to a dead end.  Now we must make a big change in our behavior or we will have to face greater problems in the near future.  

Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Contributors will help us to launch a major educational campaign through which we may be able to reach millions of peoples all over the planet, to help them undestand the danger in which we are right now. Through this campaign we will help may Indigenous Elders come together to send a powerful message to all humankind. Our campaign is directed towards promoting a deep change in the world view of millions of peoples and not only in their behavior.  

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it’s going. Be transparent and specific—people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • We need $50,000.00 to pay for the travel and lodging expenses of the Elders and Wisdom Keepers that will be attending the gathering in Peru.  
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Donors will get valuable perks in return for their contribution: photos, T shirts and art craft from the Indigenous Peoples.
  • Describe where the funds go if you don’t reach your entire goal.
  • The funds will be used to finance the event eventhough if we do not reach the entire goal. 

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Our project is valuable to the contributors because we need to get our voice out to humankind in order to educate them about the dangers that we faced if we do not change the course of collision that humanity if heading to with the destruction of Mother Earth.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • So far we have had thirdteen gatherings since 1998, when we had the first one.  Since then we have accomplished many goals that includes the establisment of a Council of Elders, that are the ones that give guidance to our project.
  • Make it real for people and build trust.
  • Since we started our project we have published several books and videos through which we spread our voice regarding the message that we want people know about.  The gathering has taken place in different countries of the Americas, including Mexico, United States of America, Panama, Puerto Rico and Ecuador.  Next August the event will take place in Peru. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • We want to ask everyone to spred the word out about our event and our campaign to help humankind listened to what the Indigenous Elders are saying about the urgent need to change the outdated vision of the world.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • We will like to remind our contributors to use the Indiegogo share tools.

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
About me

  My name's James. I'm a 20 years old, and I've always considered myself a naturalist. Unfortunately, I've grown up with the smell of factories and diesel fumes nearby--I'm from Wilmington, NC, one of the largest ports on the East Coast.

  You know what? I haven't seen enough. I've been here WAY too long and theres still so much beauty in nature that I've yet to see. My biggest fear is that this beauty is fleeting...

   And THEN I begin to read articles about members of the House of Representatives and Senate thinking about SELLING our national parks. Really guys? REALLY?! Some of the last great beauty in our country, and somebody's always going to want to slap a Wal-Mart on top of it.

If you're not upset, here's an article to get you heated: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/bill-meadows/national-parks-sell_b_1343208.html

So my plan now is to walk through many of these parks, via the Appalachian and American Discovery Trail. I have two goals:

1. I will witness the natural beauty of my country before it is covered with McDonalds' and Jiffy Lubes.

2. All extra money donated will go straight to the Conservation Fund and the National Wildlife Federation in an attempt to keep some natural beauty on this planet.

 

What I Need

Really, not much. Since I'm walking, food and water is just about the only necessity I need. I'll be camping along the trail most times and maybe renting rooms during inclement weather. I'm pretty cheap.  Above all else, I need the beauty and serenity of our National Parks and trails intact, so that's why all extra donations will be sent to the Conservation Fund and the National Wildlife Foundation to further their efforts of keeping our wilderness as pristine as possible.

 

The Impact

Number one priority is to raise awareness of the slow decline of the national parks in the US. Their condition is worsening and less people are coming simply because barely anyone is getting paid to take care of them.

Please, help me donate to these parks so my children may see how our country can be so beautiful!

For anyone that donates more than $20 or more, I'll mail you a postcard from somewhere along the Appalachian or Discovery Trail. Over $100 and you'll get a postcard from every state I walk through. $1000 and I'll also walk to your house and thank you personally for your donation!!!

 

Can't Donate? No Problem!

Just tell your friends and family or hardcore naturalists about this page. Anything you can do is helping the natural beauty of the good ole' USA.

Lets just keep them from looking like that picture right there...

 

Routes

For more information about my route westward, click there!

http://www.appalachiantrail.org/

http://www.discoverytrail.org/

story:
Our Mission

Cape Fear Environmental Film Forum, an event that is free and open to the public,  brings environmentally themed films together with filmmakers, panels of Cape Fear area advocates and audience members to offer grass-roots solutions to environmental challenges. 

This Year's  CFEFF

The forum, which takes place in February 2013, showcases four film blocks: two feature film blocks for the documentaries Ingredients and The City Dark, a third block comprised of short films about innovative environmental solutions and a fourth block hosting a sneak preview of a locally-made feature documentary about the proposed Titan Cement plant in New Hanover county.

The Impact

The forum hopes to present this most serious issue of the 21st century as an opportunity for radical creative potential. There will also be allotted time for panels and audience members to discuss the issues raised in their film screenings and to use these discussions as a springboard to action.

What We Need & What You Get

The money raised through Indiegogo will help buy the rights to the selected films as well as honoraria for participating filmmakers as well as other aspects of hosting the event. Our hope is that Indiegogo will not only help with funds, but will also aid in our efforts to promote the Forum throughout South Eastern North Carolina. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you would like to help, you can "like" us on Facebook as well as copy the link to your wall and urge your friends to do the same.
http://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/Cape-Fear-Environmental-Film-Forum/308636825820445

story:
Who We Are

We are ocean lovers, activists, and scientists, whose mission is to research oceanic plastic pollution and provide a public narrative.

 

Our Campaign

This summer we are sailing from Oahu to San Francisco to research plastic pollution in the North Pacific gyre. Gyres are formed by the circular motion of wave and wind currents. Plastic accumulates in high concentration in the center of the gyre, which spans thousands of miles. There's trash out there, but nobody knows how much.

Our team is already involved in the early stages of research and development for this growing concern. Team members have been collecting water samples and researching marine debris since 2004 in the Pacific and previously collected samples in the North and South Atlantic gyres. To raise awareness our founder sailed from California to Hawaii on the Junkraft, which floated on 15,000 plastic bottles (www.junkraft.com).

We need to build our understanding of what's going on with plastic in our oceans now, so that we can track changes moving forward. As legislation on production and disposal is adopted and consumption patterns shift to address the growing global concern, we need a means of tracking whether we are making headway. Our research is step one.

We can't do it without your support.

 

Why It Matters 

We are concerned about the effect of oceanic plastic pollution on the food chain. As plastic degrades at sea, it breaks into particles small enough to be ingested by birds, fish, and other organisms. Plastic pieces soak up pesticides and other toxic compounds, and potentially leach other toxins as degradation products.

Pollution in the gyre is not restricted to the open sea. Depending on ocean and wind currents, trash gets washed ashore on previously unblemished islands, or even mainland coasts, dirtying beaches and harming wildlife.

Since plastics take immense time scales to degrade, this problem will only get worse. If we do not take steps to understand the scope of the issue now, we will be paying for it later. 

 

What We Will Do With $15,000

$15,000 covers the costs of water sampling and outfitting our vessel. Water sampling requires trawls, a freezer on board, analysis tools on board, and laboratory access. Our vessel needs a bottom job, davits, watermaker, generator, inverter, fuel tank, auto helm, battery bank, battery monitor, satellite phone, spinnaker, SSB radio, aft platform, and a liferaft.

 

Gifts For You

We are offering many gifts from our expedition, so you can enjoy the perks of our trip without the sea-sickness:

 

  • Digital and printed photography
     
  • Ambient mid-ocean sound recordings
     
  • Locally sourced and crafted sea-glass earrings from Ocean Beach, San Francisco
     
  • Package of postcards photographed during expedition
     
  • Marine debris trawl samples
     
  • Personalized songs performed and recorded live at sea, and
     
  • Your name painted onto the side of our vessel

 

The Impact

This expedition continues Sea of Change's long-term goal to delineate and measure the North Pacific Garbage Patch's density.

Establishing an accurate baseline on plastic pollution density in oceanic convergence zones is the first and critical step to monitoring whether or not efforts to reduce plastic marine pollution are successful.

The earthquake and ensuing tsunami in Japan last year swept what appeared to be thousands of tons of debris out to sea.

In this tragedy exists a scientific opportunity. We can learn how marine debris and plastic pollution behave in the North Pacific Ocean. We know where and when the debris field originated. Our findings of debris location and concentration this summer will allow ocean current modelers to create more accurate models of how debris is transported in ocean currents.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating to our campaign here on indiegogo, here's what you can do:

Educate yourself about marine debris and disposable consumption. 

Participate in beach cleanups. 

Reduce your consumption, particularly single-use plastics.

Support plastic legislation. 

Make some noise! Share our campaign, subscribe to our blog, like us on facebook, visit our website regularly.

 

Thank YOU!

story:
Translations:

Indiegogo Turkish translation (Türkçe Çeviri)

Indiegogo Spanish Translation (Traducción Español)


About The Amazon Mycorenewal Project

The Amazon Mycorenewal Project (AMP) is a volunteer-run and 501(c)3 sponsored organization under CoRenewal, founded by Mia Maltz (M.Sc. and Ph.D student),  Nicola Peel (Speaker, Environmentalist and Filmmaker), Joanna Zlotnik (M.Sc.), Bob Rawson (M.Sc. president of International Wastewater Solutions) and Freeda Burnstad (B.A.).

Since 2006, AMP has worked in the Sucumbíos region of northern Ecuador to develop low-cost, effective, and natural systems for addressing severe pollution and health issues related to industrial petroleum extraction. AMP's work revolves around the emerging science of applied bioremediation. Bioremediation is a pollution mitigation strategy that mimics the decomposition and nutrient cycling processes found in the natural world by utilizing fungi, bacteria, and plants to break down toxic chemicals in polluted aquatic and terrestrial environments.

AMP works with local community organizers to help individuals and families afflicted by the health and environmental impacts of poorly managed oil extraction processes. Over the years, AMP has taught mushroom cultivation and medicinal mushroom workshops in the Sucumbíos region. We are currently working towards building long-standing alliances between the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.


About the Oil Pollution in Ecuador

Since the 1960s, various local and international oil companies have established over 1,000 unlined pits filled with petroleum-contaminated wastewater in the Sucumbíos province of the Ecuadorian Amazon. Currently, these pits are fitted with overflow pipes that discharge oil effluent directly into waterways. As a result, it is estimated that over 18.5 billion gallons of petroleum now contaminate this biodiverse and ecologically unique rainforest. On polluted lands, grazing livestock and agricultural crops have also been heavily impacted. People drink, bathe and wash their clothes in these toxic water sources, which afflicts local communities with high cancer rates, birth defects, and severe skin and respiratory ailments. 

The industrial remediation strategies that the oil companies currently employ are far from efficient in cleaning up pollution. Additionally, helping the affected communities recover from the devastation has yet to be properly addressed. Hence, ecological restoration research that employs low-cost and replicable bioremediation technologies is increasingly important.

For more information on this issue, please view the documentaries below:

A Solution To Pollution (17 minute documentary about AMP)

Blood Of The Amazon (80 minute DVD by donation- filmed in the Amazon researching the effects of the oil industry on the environment and indigenous people)

Crude (The inside story of the infamous “Amazon Chernobyl” case, one of the largest and most controversial environmental lawsuits on the planet)


About the 2014 AMP Study:

Since February of 2014, AMP team members have been working in the Sucumbíos province of Ecuador, initiating an 18-month project to develop a modular, replicable, and low-cost water filtration system. This system will effectively utilize native fungi, bacteria, and plants to treat petroleum-contaminated water that overflows from the unlined basins into waterways. Our design will amplify and reintroduce the organisms that have naturally adapted to these sites in a manner that recognizes and integrates the inherent intelligence of nature (biomimicry).

While most bioremediation systems focus on using these organisms in isolation, our project is unique in that we will be combining these species in a multi-trophic approach. The application of such a methodology will provide a significant insight into the power of combining fungi, plants, and bacteria in a simple yet effective bioremediation strategy.

During the 2014 expedition, AMP members will:

  1. Establish a long-term site for continued microbial cultivation. We will identify and profile native microbial flora that are capable of surviving in and potentially degrading the petroleum hydrocarbons that exist in polluted pits. We will then cultivate these species for reintroduction to the contaminated sites.
  2. Design and implement biofiltration systems in contaminated sites of the Sucumbíos region with the help of local and international technicians, students and volunteers. These will be modular and easy-to-maintain systems that will be monitored throughout the 18-month study. 
  3. Report on the laboratory results of our system's efficacy and present our research globally at conferences and community events. As an inexpensive and easy to understand means of testing the biofiltration systems, we will conduct plant performance tests on the treated water vs. contaminated water. 
  4. Submit research results to open access journals and license these findings in the creative commons to provide available resources within the public domain.The technologies used in our research will be provided to grassroots NGOs and communities afflicted with oil pollution worldwide at no profit. AMP maintains a commitment to uphold ethics-based business alliances to provide scientific resources and recommendations as deliverable services to communities motivated to clean up contamination in their local watersheds.


Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor) growing in a petroleum contaminated pit

What Your Contributions Will Fund

This Indiegogo campaign will cover the costs for the 2014-2015 AMP study. While the need for research on industrial remediation is critical, it is often a challenge to obtain funding to support pilot studies for cleaning up industrial contamination utilizing bioremediation strategies. The majority of funding from this campaign will cover costs for laboratory testing of post-treatment water from our preliminary and modified installations. The design will be built using locally-sourced substrates, species, and materials for ease of cost, replication, and adaptation worldwide.

An approximate budget for this project is:

  • Laboratory analysis of soil & water samples - $20,000
  • Soil & water sample shipping and fees- $2,500
  • Biofilter materials (flow cell materials, pond liner, perforated pipes)  - $1,700
  • Mushroom cultivation and genetic preservation materials - $1,500 
  • Microbial population and PCR analysis - $12,000
  • Biochar production facility - $500
  • Digital documentation - $300
  • Ground transportation - $1,000
  • Airfare and living costs for 6 longterm team members - $12,000 
  • Cost of producing and shipping Indiegogo perks - $2,000
  • Indiegogo's fees: $3,500

STRETCH GOALS

  • $70,000 - we will test for more variables (i.e. biochar, microbial species, substrates)
  • $90,000 - we will run parallel trials in West Virginia, United States for remediation of coal ash polluted waters 
  • $110,000 - we will replicate our system in Alberta, Canada for remediation of Tar sands tailings pond effluent

What You Get:

Our perks start with a personal thank you. Thank you! We then diversify with AMP logo stickers, Ecuadorian fungi postcards, AMP supporter T-shirts, an AMP mushroom calendar, and a mushroom spawn bag cultivated by one of our members. Perks from our collaborators include volumes of Mycelium Music and Immune Support mycomedicinal capsules from PowerShroom. Also offered is a copy of Earth Repair by Leila Darwish - a grassroots guide to healing toxic and damaged landscapes. 

Many of the perks for this campaign offer footage of lectures and workshops from the Art and Science of Mycorenewal course that was sponsored by AMP and was held in Santa Cruz, CA in June 2013. This 10-day course taught the skills needed for developing successful grassroots bioremediation projects. The videos taken of these course's lectures are broken up into the following three categories:

General Fungi (5 lectures)

  • Microbial Ecology (Instructor: Mia)
  • What are Fungi? (Instructor: Maya)
  • Fungal Taxonomy (Instructors: Willoughby and Maya)
  • Endophytes (Instructor: Monica)
  • Myco-Medicinals (Instructor: Monica)


Mushroom Cultivation (13 lectures)

  • Cost Efficiency (Instructor: Peter)
  • Commonly Cultivated Species (Instructor: Peter)
  • Culture Transfers (Instructor: Peter)
  • Sawdust Spawn Production (Instructor: Peter)
  • Grain Inoculation (Instructor: Peter)
  • Liquid Culture (Instructor: Peter)
  • Inducing Fruiting (Instructor: Peter)
  • Home Scale Cultivation (Instructor: Peter)
  • Hot Water Pasteurization (Instructor: Peter)
  • Low-tech Cultivation (Instructor: Peter)
  • Activating Fungal Metabolism (Instructor: Peter)
  • Myco-Gardening (Instructors: Mia, Maya, Peter, Willoughby)


Bioremediation (13 lectures)

  • Intro to Myco-Remediation (Instructor: Peter)
  • Applied Myco-remediation (Instructor: Mia)
  • How Myco-Remediation Works (Instructor: Mia)
  • Phyto-Remediation (Instructor: Leila)
  • Micro-Remediation (Instructor: Bob)
  • Bacterial Ecology (Instructor: Bob)
  • Compost Tea (Instructor: Leila)
  • Remediation of Body Toxicity (Instructor: Leila)
  • Remediation of Oil Spills (Instructor: Leila)
  • Myco-Remediation With Fungaia Farm (Instructor: Willoughby)
  • Grassroots Bioremediation (Instructor: Leila)
  • Amazon Mycorenewal Project (Instructor: Mia)
  • Breaking It Down With AMP (Instructor: Bob & Mia)

Lecture Instructors

  • Maya Elson — Environmental Educator, co-founder of Radical Mycology
  • Mia Maltz — Lead Scientist for Amazon Mycorenewal Project, Ph.D student at UC Irvine, Permaculture Instructor
  • Robert Rawson — General Manager of the Graton Community Services District, Microbiology Professor
  • Peter McCoy — Co-founder of Radical Mycology, Mushroom Cultivation Instructor
  • Leila Darwish — Author of Earth Repair: A Grassroots Guide to Healing Toxic and Damaged Landscapes, Community Organizer, Permaculture Designer
  • Monica Neff — Endophytic fungi researcher at UC Berkeley, member of Bay Area Radical Mycology, Amazon Mycorenewal Project, Co-owner of Powershroom Medicinal Mushrooms
  • Willoughby Arevalo - Mycologist, Artist, Performer, and Gardener

'The AMP Experience'
This penultimate perk will include a personalized tour of the area in which we work. Stay with us at our beautiful rainforest lodge that is home base. Join us on a toxic tour, to get a firsthand look at the devastating pollution this region faces. Go on a hike with us to get a sense of the plant, animal and fungi species that are currently at risk.

This perk will cover all expenses except for airfare. Your food (including vegetarian options), lodging, and transportation, once in Ecuador, is on us. You will have a private room with a bathroom and shower. Wake up to the sounds of tropical birds and monkeys chirping in the trees before enjoying a home-cooked breakfast, with local coffee and fresh-squeezed juices.

Why This Project is Important

The Amazon Mycorenewal Project is unique in both its ethic and approach. Through research, education, and implementation of remediation strategies, AMP seeks to improve the quality of life for affected individuals in Ecuador by working directly with communities to address their concerns. We are working to bring effective bioremediation strategies to the Amazon rainforest, "the Lungs of the Earth."

Previous AMP trips have focused on developing relationships with local scientists and organizations, sourcing materials, cataloging and cultivating petroleum tolerant fungi, and prototyping several remediation experiments. This 2014 AMP expedition will focus on synthesizing the previous years of research into a specific remediation protocol. This year's study will be the most important phase of the Amazon Mycorenewal Project to date. 

Once implemented, our design will be an example and aide for other communities facing pollution problems from natural resource extraction methods worldwide.


Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond contributing to this campaign financially, there are several great ways you can help promote this project to your social (mycelial) networks:

Here is a short link to this campaign for easy sharing:

Like us on Facebook 

Share this campaign on Facebook

Tweet about this campaign

Stay updated with our blog

Blogs, Podcasts, & Newsletters:
Write about Amazon Mycorenewal or this Indiegogo campaign on your blog or in your newsletter. AMP members would be happy to do an interview or contribute content to help make this happen. Please contact us through our email to set up an interview.

Email us at: Amazonmyco@gmail.com
story_txt:
Translations:Indiegogo Turkish translation (Türkçe Çeviri)Indiegogo Spanish Translation (Traducción Español)
About The Amazon Mycorenewal Project
The Amazon Mycorenewal Project (AMP) is a volunteer-run and 501(c)3 sponsored organization under CoRenewal, founded by Mia Maltz (M.Sc. and Ph.D student),  Nicola Peel (Speaker, Environmentalist and Filmmaker), Joanna Zlotnik (M.Sc.), Bob Rawson (M.Sc. president of International Wastewater Solutions) and Freeda Burnstad (B.A.). Since 2006, AMP has worked in the Sucumbíos region of northern Ecuador to develop low-cost, effective, and natural systems for addressing severe pollution and health issues related to industrial petroleum extraction. AMP's work revolves around the emerging science of applied bioremediation. Bioremediation is a pollution mitigation strategy that mimics the decomposition and nutrient cycling processes found in the natural world by utilizing fungi, bacteria, and plants to break down toxic chemicals in polluted aquatic and terrestrial environments.AMP works with local community organizers to help individuals and families afflicted by the health and environmental impacts of poorly managed oil extraction processes. Over the years, AMP has taught mushroom cultivation and medicinal mushroom workshops in the Sucumbíos region. We are currently working towards building long-standing alliances between the Northern and Southern Hemispheres.About the Oil Pollution in EcuadorSince the 1960s, various local and international oil companies have established over 1,000 unlined pits filled with petroleum-contaminated wastewater in the Sucumbíos province of the Ecuadorian Amazon. Currently, these pits are fitted with overflow pipes that discharge oil effluent directly into waterways. As a result, it is estimated that over 18.5 billion gallons of petroleum now contaminate this biodiverse and ecologically unique rainforest. On polluted lands, grazing livestock and agricultural crops have also been heavily impacted. People drink, bathe and wash their clothes in these toxic water sources, which afflicts local communities with high cancer rates, birth defects, and severe skin and respiratory ailments. The industrial remediation strategies that the oil companies currently employ are far from efficient in cleaning up pollution. Additionally, helping the affected communities recover from the devastation has yet to be properly addressed. Hence, ecological restoration research that employs low-cost and replicable bioremediation technologies is increasingly important.For more information on this issue, please view the documentaries below:A Solution To Pollution (17 minute documentary about AMP)Blood Of The Amazon (80 minute DVD by donation- filmed in the Amazon researching the effects of the oil industry on the environment and indigenous people)Crude (The inside story of the infamous “Amazon Chernobyl” case, one of the largest and most controversial environmental lawsuits on the planet)About the 2014 AMP Study:Since February of 2014, AMP team members have been working in the Sucumbíos province of Ecuador, initiating an 18-month project to develop a modular, replicable, and low-cost water filtration system. This system will effectively utilize native fungi, bacteria, and plants to treat petroleum-contaminated water that overflows from the unlined basins into waterways. Our design will amplify and reintroduce the organisms that have naturally adapted to these sites in a manner that recognizes and integrates the inherent intelligence of nature (biomimicry).While most bioremediation systems focus on using these organisms in isolation, our project is unique in that we will be combining these species in a multi-trophic approach. The application of such a methodology will provide a significant insight into the power of combining fungi, plants, and bacteria in a simple yet effective bioremediation strategy.During the 2014 expedition, AMP members will: 
Establish a long-term site for continued microbial cultivation. We will identify and profile native microbial flora that are capable of surviving in and potentially degrading the petroleum hydrocarbons that exist in polluted pits. We will then cultivate these species for reintroduction to the contaminated sites.
Design and implement biofiltration systems in contaminated sites of the Sucumbíos region with the help of local and international technicians, students and volunteers. These will be modular and easy-to-maintain systems that will be monitored throughout the 18-month study. 

Report on the laboratory results of our system's efficacy and present our research globally at conferences and community events. As an inexpensive and easy to understand means of testing the biofiltration systems, we will conduct plant performance tests on the treated water vs. contaminated water. 


Submit research results to open access journals and license these findings in the creative commons to
provide available resources within the public domain.The technologies used in our research will be provided to grassroots NGOs and communities afflicted with oil pollution worldwide at no profit. AMP maintains a commitment to uphold ethics-based business alliances to provide scientific resources and recommendations as deliverable services to communities motivated to clean up contamination in their local watersheds.

Turkey Tail (Trametes versicolor) growing in a petroleum contaminated pitWhat Your Contributions Will Fund
This Indiegogo campaign will cover the costs
for the 2014-2015 AMP study. While the need for research on industrial
remediation is critical, it is often a challenge to obtain funding to support
pilot studies for cleaning up industrial contamination utilizing bioremediation
strategies. The majority of funding from this campaign will cover costs
for laboratory testing of post-treatment water from our preliminary and
modified installations. The design will be built using
locally-sourced substrates, species, and materials for ease of cost,
replication, and adaptation worldwide.
An approximate budget for this project is:
Laboratory analysis of soil & water samples - $20,000

Soil & water sample shipping and fees- $2,500
Biofilter materials (flow cell materials, pond liner, perforated pipes)  - $1,700
Mushroom cultivation and genetic preservation materials - $1,500 
Microbial population and PCR analysis - $12,000
Biochar production facility - $500
Digital documentation - $300
Ground transportation - $1,000
Airfare and living costs for 6 longterm team members - $12,000 
Cost of producing and shipping Indiegogo perks - $2,000

Indiegogo's fees: $3,500

STRETCH GOALS

$70,000 - we will test for more variables (i.e. biochar, microbial species, substrates)
$90,000 - we will run parallel trials in West Virginia, United States for remediation of coal ash polluted waters 
$110,000 - we will replicate our system in Alberta, Canada for remediation of Tar sands tailings pond effluent
What You Get:Our perks start with a personal thank you. Thank you! We then diversify with AMP logo stickers, Ecuadorian fungi postcards, AMP supporter T-shirts, an AMP mushroom calendar, and a mushroom spawn bag cultivated by one of our members. Perks from our collaborators include volumes of Mycelium Music and Immune Support mycomedicinal capsules from PowerShroom. Also offered is a copy of Earth Repair by Leila Darwish - a grassroots guide to healing toxic and damaged landscapes. Many of the perks for this campaign offer footage of lectures and workshops from the Art and Science of Mycorenewal course that was sponsored by AMP and was held in Santa Cruz, CA in June 2013. This 10-day course taught the skills needed for developing successful grassroots bioremediation projects. The videos taken of these course's lectures are broken up into the following three categories:General Fungi (5 lectures)

story:
FR / Nous sommes deux photographes français, fondateurs de Green Pix Adventure, une association à but non lucratif dont la mission est de promouvoir la préservation de l’environnement au travers de l’aventure et la photographie.

C'est dans ce cadre que nous allons partir pour un périple à vélo le long de la côte Est américaine, entre Miami et Montréal, soit environ 4.000km à travers une quinzaine d’États américains et une province du Canada.

Tout au long du parcours, nous alimenterons un blog photo en français et en anglais. Celui-ci permettra à tout un chacun de suivre le projet, en relayant au jour le jour, parfois même « en direct », les détails de cette aventure. Les réseaux sociaux (Twitter, Facebook, etc.) joueront un rôle important dans cette démarche.


  EN / We are two French photographers, creators of Green Pix Adventure, a non-profit organization whose main mission is to promote protection of the environment through adventure and photography.

It's for this reason that we plan to travel the American East coast on bike from Miami, FL to Montréal, QC, a distance of about 2,500 miles throughout fifteen US States and one Canadian Province.

All along the way, we will maintain a comprehensive and informative photo blog in both French and English, while also posting this information on social networks (Twitter, Facebook, etc.).


  FR / Notre but est ainsi de soutenir l'action de l'East Coast Greenway Alliance, une association à but non lucratif fondée en 1991 aux États-Unis. Celle-ci se bat pour la création de chemins naturels qui permettront un jour de se rendre jusqu’au Canada depuis le sud de la Floride, uniquement en utilisant des moyens de transports écologiques comme le vélo.

Nous espérons ainsi leur permettre d’étendre leur influence et d'inspirer des initiatives similaires à travers le monde. Nous espérons également que notre exemple contribuera à valoriser l’usage de moyens de transports qui, à l’instar du vélo, soient plus écologiques et favorisent les belles rencontres humaines. Une problématique qui s’étend bien au-delà du cadre américain.

  EN / Our goal is to spread knowledge of the East Coast Greenway project, which is a developing trail system, spanning nearly 3,000 miles as it winds its way between Canada and Key West, linking all the major cities of the eastern seaboard.

We hope to cast new light on the natural riches of the American East coast and by our example encourage people to make less use of their cars in favor of taking their bicycles or some other eco-friendly mode of transportation instead.



  FR / L’argent ainsi récolté nous permettra de couvrir les frais de matériel : vélos, pièces de rechanges, équipement sportif, ainsi que nous permettre de disposer d'un petit fond pour parer à tous les imprévus techniques qui pourraient subvenir au cours de ce périple. Plus nous récolterons d'argent, plus nous pourrons acheter du matériel de qualité, indispensable à la pleine réussite du projet.

Tout le reste du budget (équipement photo et vidéo, hébergement, etc.) est pris en charge par Green Pix Adventure.


  EN / The money will help us to buy all the necessary equipment: bikes, spare parts, special bags, specialist clothes, etc. It will also help us to deal with most unexpected events. The more money we raise, the more we'll be able to make this trip a success.

The rest of our budget (photo and video equipment, accommodation costs, etc.) will be taken care of entirely by Green Pix Adventure.


  FR / Voici une liste non-exhaustive des raisons pour lesquelles vous pourriez considérer de nous apporter votre aide :
  • Vous avez envie de soutenir un projet sportif un peu fou ;
  • Vous vous sentez concerné par la protection de notre environnement ;
  • Vous avez déjà été confrontés au manque de solutions offertes aux vélos, notamment dans les grandes villes ;
  • Vous pensez qu’il est important de réduire notre impact sur la planète et que cela passe par offrir aux gens des alternatives viables à la voiture ;
  • Vous avez envie de soutenir une jeune association dont les membres ont envie d’agir.

  EN / Here's some reasons you might want to help us:

  • You feel interested in the conservation of our environment.
  • You want to support a crazy sporting challenge.
  • You have already been confronted with the lack of solutions when you want to use your bike, especially in major cities.
  • You think it's important to support initiatives whose goal is to give people alternatives to using their cars.
  • You wish to give your support to a young non-profit organization whose members have a will to act for our future.

story:
Who We Are:

Our names are Jennifer Gonzalez and Steve Matzker.  We are recent photojournalism graduates from Southern Illinois University Carbondale.  As photographers, it is our desire to tell stories that make an impact. Through the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, and your support, we will have that opportunity.

http://pulitzercenter.org

http://pulitzercenter.org/blog/pulitzer-center-2013-student-fellows-announced-campus-consortium-partners 

 

What we are doing:

The Pulitzer Center has graciously awarded us with fellowship grants to document water rights issues in Nepal.  Our focus is over the trans boundary Kosi River, on the border of India and Nepal. India is advocating that a high dam be built within the Nepal border. We will document the impact the construction of this dam will have on the Nepalese people.  The proposed dam, desired by India for hydroelectricity and flood management, will displace tens of thousands of Nepalese citizens; destroy their villages, cropland, and businesses.  What will the Nepalese gain?  Both countries share the water, but who owns the rights, those upstream or downstream?  The richer country?  The one with more political might?  The major question, though, is how will this conflict be resolved?  

This project is important to us because we have a chance to give a voice to those who would otherwise not have this option.  We are excited to visually contribute to the dialogue of water rights issues and this is your chance to help us.

With your support, we can spend two months in the small Nepalese communities around the proposed dam site.  The funding we raise will allow us to document the people in an in-depth and intimate way.

 

What we need and what you get:

We need $4,000.00 for various expenses between now and our trip on August 5th 2013.  The funding will go towards passports and visas, immunization shots, travel and equipment insurance, plane tickets, transportation while in Nepal, fees for a translator, and accommodations in Nepal.  

In return for your support, and level of donation, you will receive personal post cards from Nepal, a personalized video greeting from Nepal, and customized prints upon our return.

We will still go if we do not reach our funding goal, but our time in the Nepalese communities will be cut drastically short and we will not be allowed to build the intimate relationships we need to tell their stories. 

The Impact

This story is important because it will add to the global discussion of water rights issues.  The story of water rights goes back thousands of years. And as the world becomes more populated and more countries vie for this natural resource, whether for its people or for its growing economies, this issue will only grow more heated.  

With your support, we can shed light that the impact of on going conflicts over water can have on individuals across the globe.  The story of the Nepalese is just a small window from which this issue can be viewed.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are aware that not everyone can contribute monetarily.  But there are other ways to help!  You can share this video with as many friends as possible and spread the word about our intentions to help tell the story of water rights issues.  

 

Thank You!

With your support, we can spend two months in the small Nepalese communities around the proposed dam site.  The funding we raise will allow us to document the people in an in-depth and intimate way.
 

What we need and what you get:
We need $4,000.00 for various expenses between now and our trip on August 5th 2013.  The funding will go towards passports and visas, immunization shots, travel and equipment insurance, plane tickets, transportation while in Nepal, fees for a translator, and accommodations in Nepal.  


In return for your support, and level of donation, you will receive personal post cards from Nepal, a personalized video greeting from Nepal, and customized prints upon our return.
We will still go if we do not reach our funding goal, but our time in the Nepalese communities will be cut drastically short and we will not be allowed to build the intimate relationships we need to tell their stories. 



The Impact
This story is important because it will add to the global discussion of water rights issues.  The story of water rights goes back thousands of years. And as the world becomes more populated and more countries vie for this natural resource, whether for its people or for its growing economies, this issue will only grow more heated.  
With your support, we can shed light that the impact of on going conflicts over water can have on individuals across the globe.  The story of the Nepalese is just a small window from which this issue can be viewed.


Other Ways You Can Help
We are aware that not everyone can contribute monetarily.  But there are other ways to help!  You can share this video with as many friends as possible and spread the word about our intentions to help tell the story of water rights issues.  
 
Thank You!

story:
Time for a Reality Check...

In the past year, over 300 campaigns to divest campus endowments from fossil fuels have been aunched across North America. This new wave in the climate movement – what the Nation and Rolling Stone magazines are calling the “largest student movement in decades” – has sparked a new energy in students pushing for their voices to be heard in shaping Canada and the world’s climate and energy future.

At the same time in Canada, the tar/oil sands have continued to expand in size, and in influence over politics and policies in Canada. The last two years have seen environmental policies rolled back, funding cut, and the launch of a $16 million tax-payer advertising campaign to sell bitumen to Canadians and the world. There has never been a more important time for a reality check on climate change, fossil fuels and Canada’s energy future.

That’s why this fall we are bringing together a group of leading academics, advocates and local community activists from the climate and energy community to organize a Tar Sands Reality Check speaking tour on campuses across Canada.

What We Need & What You Get

This movement is being led by grassroots community and student organizers, and while we have a lot when it comes to energy, momentum and desire for change, we need your help to raise $5000.00 to make the tour happen. We've already raised enough to cover some of the startup and core costs, but your donation will help us cover travel costs, promotions, bringing frontline community organizers and making the tour have a huge impact! 

The Impact

Last year, the Do the Math tour in the United States galvanized the climate movement in the US, and our goal is make this tour do the same for the Tar Sands movement in Canada. Right now, pipeline projects are threatening land and water all across Canada and we want to organize a tour that brings together and shows the rising movement to protect our planet, climate and future all across Canada. Your contribution will make this happen!

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, and with Five of your friends you think can donate $20-$100. 

2. Volunteer with a local group organizing a speaking date! Email divest@gofossilfree.ca for more info.

story:
WE MADE IT! feel free to keep donating and we will put your money to good use on these projects. and don't forget to continue enjoying our videos, updates, and photos! <3 <3 <3 THANK YOU for helping to make our dreams come true!

welcome to shagbark

welcome to my homestead - a six acre haven of sacred sanity nestled within red earth farms land trust in northeastern missouri. my neighbors are dancing rabbit ecovillage and sandhill community, though i like to think this little hollow fills a particular niche.

 Why are we raising money this way? click here to read more.

the dream life i'm manifesting here with my friends is primitive, comfortable, intensely local, and removed from the monetary economy (something you're helping to achieve!). not only that, it's a life and bit of land that's full of magic, welcoming to friends, and balancing beautifully on the edge of the best realities. your dollars in our hands are shifting into local meats raised as close to wild as possible, shelters made directly from our surroundings, ceramics made from the clay we dig, herbal medicines wildcrafted with love and care, hides tanned for clothing, eggs and milk and honey flowing into neighbors' homes. i hope you'll join in the magic that i've begun. to read more about shagbark and our home at red earth farms, click here.

what we need & what you get

when i tally up the costs to realize all our desires for a solid, sustainable home that can provide for myself and my loved ones, the amount i come up with is $4,000. that much support would give us the space to firmly establish so many good systems that we'd be able to continue growing our home on well under $1,000 a year. here's how it goes:

fencing - $800 - costs to use a co-op vehicle to harvest willow for woven fencing, to fell trees by hand from a local conservation department for split rail paddocks, a few good axes and hatchets, and the cost of a rockin' work party to bring our community together to help get paddocks set up to sustainably graze our goats and sheep. (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

animals - $550 - purchases sheep for fiber to provide clothing, linens, and stuffing for beds or pillows, and meat from lambs well into the future. also meat rabbit does to feed my (guard) dog and (mouser) cats as well as supplement our human diet, and enough heritage breed ducks/chickens to supply meat and eggs to our neighbors, a sustainable source of income long into the future (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

tools - $500 - enough tools for friends to help when they visit, and to process freely available raw materials into usable wool, wood, straw, etc. this is especially focused on specialized metal tools like scythe blades, broadaxe heads, and others that we can haft ourselves and repair on our own for decades of use (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

forge - $400 - pays a nearby friend to set up a small smithing operation on our land to provide our few metal needs and re-shape/re-work existing tools for ourselves and neighbors (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

ceramics - $600 - labor costs to have a local potter help us build a kiln and pottery wheel on our land so we can ditch the plastic and create our own crocks, bottles, jugs, and water storage barrels

sweets - $550 - support to build a dozen hives and start them with honey bees, as well as process that into raw honey, beeswax candles, wax for herbal salves, and mead (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

green stuff - $600 - purchases over a thousand saplings to provide human and critter food, shelter, erosion control, windbreaks, firewood, fencing, and lumber long into the future, as well as seed for annuals and perennials that will be used for a million things (dyes, fiber, soap, ink, medicine, livestock feed, mulch producers, beneficial insect promoters, and many other purposes) (WE RAISED THIS MONEY!)

campaign fees - $200 - roughly covers the fees indiegogo charges for helping us raise this magic money
 
the perks - i want my way of saying thanks to convey what our life is like to you - full of magic and wonder, made up of simple and small things. so your perks are:

-word of mouth thanks via the internet, where i share stories from my life with far-flung loved ones and friends
-a letter written with a homemade quill and walnut or pokeberry ink
-a poem sharing one of many sacred connections with the land
-a dreamcatcher made by us from willow, handspun yarn, and feathers
-a visit out here complete with tour and a luxurious massage or chiropractic therapy
-do you have questions about our lifestyle, or how you can take a step in this direction? anyone who contributes is welcome to a few e-mails/letters worth of advice, direction, or support from me in how you might bring your life closer to the dream world you imagine.
 

NEW PERKS!

-a wooden pipe hand carved by a supportive neighbor
-a hand thrown ceramic cup made by a friendly local potter
-1 oz. bottle of wildcrafted or respectfully harvested medicinal tincture
-a hand forged candlestick/rush light made by a friendly local smith

 

if the full amount we're trying to manifest isn't reached this time around, whatever money is gathered will go toward whichever of these projects feels the most urgent to us in moving forward more effectively on our homestead.
 

the impact

the work and play we're doing here at shagbark impacts our world in a number of ways. we try to act as an example of the best of both the future and the past, embracing primitive techniques, local materials, permaculture ethics and practice, and a desire for a comfortable, conscious lifestyle. we hope to model closed loop systems that can help others provide for themselves in a fulfilling way, letting go of our collective dependence on a failing monetary system. the standards we hold for living with each other bring about an atmosphere of joyful work, deep relaxation, and an openness that leads to happy, whole human beings. and of course, all our activities are done in concert with the desires and needs of the land and the wild critters who are already here - so these six acres of rock and soil and water and growth are more fully and lovingly nourished than ever they would be otherwise.

i can't tell you that i've already built a farm like this and succeeded. i have lived on farms for a handful of years, have been researching and studying and planning and practicing, and finally started my homestead adventure in 2009. a full time project since 2011, i now have friends on the land with me to help us expand into a shared homestead.

since it began, i have planted over 1000 trees, dug and sown three gardens, built two simple shelters, and a variety of shelters for livestock. i've got dairy goats, meat and fiber rabbits, meat and fiber sheep, and egg and meat chickens and ducks started already and only seek to improve their health, happiness, and quality of life by adding new blood and giving them the safest, most animal-happy shelter possible.

 

before i moved to shagbark i had never camped in my life. i've been living essentially outdoors for several years now, have gone without heat and without refrigeration or plumbing, have labored month after month to get these systems into place. i have run through hard earned savings and am at the threshold of success. it's hard to balance income-producing work and working on the land in a way that helps the land nourish us more fully. so i'm asking for your help to tip the balance, to give us that push into having home grown food through the winter, and enough surplus to sell and trade with neighbors, that will become our new bottom line over a cash economy. your donation helps us to live as the happiest feral primitive sustainable humans in existence.

other ways you can help

if, like me, you find extra dollars for helping others to be something beyond your reach, consider this: likely we've all got that one wealthy relative or friend who likes supporting cool ventures. or maybe you're surrounded by friends with really stable jobs who don't mind helping out people who are working hard at the work worth doing. if you really want to help out shagbark, ask those friends, those random philanthropists, if they're willing to support this dream-coming-true. even a few posts on your blog, twitter, facebook, etc can have a huge impact from folks who donate just a few dollars at a time. find the cutest picture from my farm and share it. who doesn't love seeing baby goats!? we're building a magical world, here, and i hope that when you share news of it with others that they will feel as inspired as you do.

story:
Save Our Salamanders and Protect the Rich Biodiversity of New England

 

PLEASE GIVE TODAY TO:

  • Build two wildlife crossings to funnel frogs, salamanders and other animals under Monkton Road in central Vermont
  • Create a safe connection for critical wildlife habitat divided by an increasingly busy road
  • Ensure the survival of one of the largest known populations of the blue-spotted salamander, a species of regional significance, as well as a diverse group of other amphibian species
  • Support science-based and grassroots conservation solutions

  • Participate in a project that will help improve the local and global prospects of amphibian conservation


Project Location

Click here: Location of both proposed wildlife crossings in Google Maps

When you click the link above you will see just how ideal this location is for a healthy amphibian population.  A large wetland abuts a steep, forested area perfect for breeding.  The only issue?  A well traveled road.


The Story

The Monkton Road Wildlife Crossing: Ensuring the survival of a critical amphibian migration corridor.

As this Indiegogo campaign unfolds, an ancient spring ritual is taking place throughout the Northern Hemisphere – the emergence of amphibians from their winter habitat to their breeding pools.  Sadly, one of the largest and most diverse amphibian populations in the northeastern United States must cross an increasingly busy road – which makes this site also one of the most threatened in the northeast.  For years, scores of volunteers have mobilized during peak movement times in the town of Monkton, Vermont in order to assist one of the larger known and most diverse populations of amphibians in the region to cross a busy road.  Despite the dedicated efforts of volunteers, more than 50% of the animals migrating across this stretch of road are getting killed during the annual journey between their upland habitat and vital wetlands where they reproduce.  As a result, a regionally significant population of amphibians is in peril of extirpation.  Traffic rates on this once-rural road are increasing at a rate that has biologists convinced that, without an infrastructure solution, this population will surely die out. 

The good news is that there is a solution.  Shovel-ready plans are complete and project bid documents are drafted.  The total cost for the construction of two wildlife crossing tunnels and associated guide fences at this location is $380,000.  Ground breaking is scheduled for 2014, as soon as a $45,000 funding gap is closed.  Public sources have provided the majority of project design and construction funds through competitive grants, and construction is on target for 2014 – with your help.

This is a multi-partner grassroots effort that has enjoyed global press attention for its innovative approach to reversing an ecological tragedy.  News outlets from as far away as Sidney, Australia and Taipei, China, were covering this story within hours of the announcement of our Federal Highway Administration Transportation Enhancement Grant award. The Lewis Creek Association and the Town of Monkton, Vermont are leading this collaborative partnership that includes federal agencies, state agencies, international non-governmental organizations, private philanthropists, and generous watershed neighbors.  This diverse partnership demonstrates the significance of this site – not just locally but far beyond this watershed.

Recent estimates suggest that one in three amphibian species is at risk of extinction.  By preserving Vermont's amphibians, we can help save important populations in the Northeastern United States and help lay the groundwork for future projects throughout the world.

“This is an exemplary enhancement project, and one that truly embodies the spirit of the [Federal Highway Administration] Transportation Enhancement Program.”  
- Patricia White, Director, Habitat and Highways Program, Defenders of Wildlife

“The fact that for many of these species, large percentages of the population must cross the road to access breeding sites indicates a significant risk of population loss due to road kill.” 
- Scott Jackson, Director, Natural Resources and Environmental Conservation Program, University of Massachusetts, Amherst

“This is one of the most important known amphibian crossings in the state.  It is hard to imagine that the Monkton Road population can sustain this level of mortality for many more years.” 
- James Andrews, Coordinator, Vermont Reptile and Amphibian Atlas Project


The Art

We were delighted when we learned that Woody Jackson had offered to create original artwork for our Indiegogo campaign.  Jackson is best known for producing the artwork seen on Ben & Jerry's ice cream cartons all over the world. 

Woody Jackson's Website

The three paintings he donated are below.






Project Partners

The Lewis Creek Association, a nonprofit organization registered as a 501(c)(3), has offered to accept and manage the tax-deductible donations collected from this Indiegogo campaign.


Lewis Creek Association


Town of Monkton, Vermont



The Vermont Agency of Transportation




The Vermont Fish & Wildlife Department


Gund Institute for Ecological Economics


The Middlebury Area Land Trust



Defenders of Wildlife


Trans Wild Alliance


Vermont Reptile & Amphibian Project


Peregrine Productions

story:
WHO WE ARE

Western Watersheds Project (WWP) is an effective environmental watchdog organization with a primary focus on ending public lands' livestock grazing and reducing the ecological damage it causes. For over twenty years, WWP has successfully worked to protect and restore the public lands, streams, and wildlife of the West.

A Wildlife Services airplane used in aerial gunning operations in Idaho. The wolf paw stickers near the door of the plane are the crew's way of boasting about the wolves they've killed. 

THE GOVERNMENT KILLING OF NATIVE WILDLIFE 

Our public lands provide some of the best remaining habitat for wildlife, including predators like bears, wolves, mountain lions, and coyotes. Unfortunately, when these animals prey on the unprotected private livestock like cattle and sheep grazing on these public lands, they are often killed by Wildlife Services, a taxpayer funded program of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. 

Wildlife Services kills millions of animals nationwide every year, more than 3,000 mammals in 2013 just in Idaho! The agency uses aerial gunning, neck snares, foothold traps, and toxic devices known as M-44s that spray sodium cyanide into the victim’s mouth, causing tremendous suffering and releasing toxic chemicals into the environment. Wildlife Services' in Idaho plans to eradicate coyotes, black bears, mountain lions, bobcats, foxes and other important carnivores from our wild lands for the benefit of private livestock and agricultural interests. Wildlife Services also plans to remove dozens of beaver dams using explosives that will harm bull trout, a protected species.


The secretive Wildlife Services program harms not just the target animals, but many other species are caught by mistake in the traps and snares, including pets of people using the public lands for recreation. It isn't just cruel, it's dangerous. 

It is also scientifically unsound. Research has shown the importance of maintaining key species in ecosystems, and the influence these species have on the health of the watershed as a whole. The function of the landscape depends on the presence of these strongly interactive species, and the federal agency is dead wrong that protecting livestock ought to be a government priority. 

In Idaho, Wildlife Services has not conducted a sufficient analysis of the impacts of its activities on the environment. Its new plan to blow up beaver dams has the potential to harm bull trout habitat, something the agency hasn't even considered. 

WWP intends to hold Wildlife Services accountable for killing native wildlife, endangering recreational users, poisoning the environment, and upsetting the ecological balance on millions of acres of land owned by all Americans. 

HOLDING WILDLIFE SERVICES ACCOUNTABLE

Western Watersheds Project intends to shut this agency down nationwide, but we're starting in Idaho, where some of the wildest habitat of the lower 48 states occurs. Here is our three-part plan for confronting the killing, and we must raise the resources necessary to follow through:

  1. Legal Action. WWP has put the government on notice that it must analyze and disclose the effects of its actions in Idaho. WWP intends to stop Wildlife Services’ renewal of its efforts in Idaho to eradicate coyotes, black bears, mountain lions, bobcats, foxes and other important carnivores from the landscape for the benefit of private livestock and agricultural interests. 
  2. Increased Transparency. WWP intends to begin tracking more of Wildlife Services' actions in order to better understand this out-of-control agency. We'll submit public records' requests, monitor responses to livestock conflicts, and keep an eye on their wildlife and habitat destruction.  
  3. Public Awareness. The public needs to understand what is happening and rally to end this unnecessary and inhumane killing. WWP will keep this issue in the public eye through media outreach, social media, and public participation.   

Earlier this year, members of Congress demanded an investigation of the program’s practices and the Agriculture Department commenced an audit of its wildlife control activities. Due to the lack of any regulatory framework to govern the programs of this agency and the gridlock in Congress, it's time for all of us to take action!

HOW YOU CAN HELP

By funding WWP's campaign, you'll be helping to support the work of our Senior Attorney, Kristin Ruether, who is bringing this legal challenge to Wildlife Services' Idaho programs. You'll also be helping to support all of the work that she and other staff will be doing to expose and end these unsound and unsupportable programs on public lands.


    WHAT YOU GET

    In addition to knowing your gift has the potential to help wild animals across the country, WWP is offering some perks that will help you experience the great outdoors, provide a better understanding of threats to the environment, and are just plain fun!

    WESTERN WATERSHEDS PROJECT WORKS THROUGHOUT THE WEST

    WWP works throughout the West to end the impacts of public lands livestock grazing.  To provide you with more context about WWP's work, the following are just a few examples of our current projects across in the Northern Rocky Mountains. If you're interested in learning more about our work in other regions, please visit www.westernwatersheds.org. 

    • Protecting the drinking water of Pocatello, Idaho free from e-coli contamination caused by waste from cattle grazing on in the Mink Creek watershed on lands managed by the Forest Service. 
    • Ending conflict between native predators and livestock in stunning mountains that surround Jackson Hole, Wyoming.

    The Upper Gros Ventre, near Jackson, WY.  Photo courtesy - Thomas Mangelsen

    • Working to protect and restore Copper Basin and the Big Lost River watershed from the degradation caused by livestock grazing on public lands.
story_txt:
WHO WE ARE
Western
Watersheds Project (WWP) is an effective environmental watchdog organization with a primary focus on ending public lands' livestock grazing and reducing the ecological damage it causes. For over twenty years, WWP has successfully worked to protect and restore the public lands, streams, and wildlife of the West.





A Wildlife Services airplane used in aerial gunning operations in Idaho. The wolf paw stickers near the door of the plane are the crew's way of boasting about the wolves they've killed. 
THE GOVERNMENT KILLING OF NATIVE WILDLIFE 
Our public lands provide some of the best remaining habitat for wildlife, including predators like bears, wolves, mountain lions, and coyotes. Unfortunately, when these animals prey on the unprotected private livestock like cattle and sheep grazing on these public lands, they are often killed by Wildlife Services, a
taxpayer funded program of the U.S. Department of Agriculture. 
Wildlife Services kills millions of animals nationwide every year, more than 3,000 mammals in
2013 just in Idaho! The agency uses aerial gunning, neck
snares, foothold traps, and toxic devices known as M-44s that spray sodium
cyanide into the victim’s mouth, causing tremendous suffering and releasing
toxic chemicals into the environment. Wildlife Services' in
Idaho plans to eradicate coyotes, black bears, mountain lions, bobcats, foxes and
other important carnivores from our wild lands for the benefit of private
livestock and agricultural interests. Wildlife Services also plans to remove
dozens of beaver dams using explosives that will harm bull trout, a protected
species. 



The secretive Wildlife Services program harms not just the target animals, but many other species are caught by mistake in the traps and snares, including pets of people using the public lands for recreation. It isn't just cruel, it's dangerous. 
It is also scientifically unsound. Research has shown the importance of maintaining key species in ecosystems, and the influence these species have on the health of the watershed as a whole. The function of the landscape depends on the presence of these strongly interactive species, and the federal agency is dead wrong that protecting livestock ought to be a government priority. 
In Idaho, Wildlife Services has not conducted a sufficient analysis of the impacts of its activities on the environment. Its new plan to blow up beaver dams has the potential to harm bull trout habitat, something the agency hasn't even considered.

Congress, it's time for all of us to take action!

In addition to knowing your gift has the
potential to help wild animals across the
country, WWP is offering some perks that will help you experience the great
outdoors, provide a better understanding of threats to the environment, and are
just plain fun!

If you're interested in learning more about our work in other regions, please visit www.westernwatersheds.org.

story:
North Shore Rescue performs approximately 90 search and rescue operations a year locally, as well as assisting other search and rescue teams in BC and Washington State.  The NSR is responsible for saving many lives over the years and is run by dedicated by volunteers who all have day jobs.  Unfortunately, in the last couple of months, thieves have targeted the rescue's equipment caches which are located on remote parts of the local mountain terrain and are imperative for saving lives.  The police are looking for the culprits, but in the meantime, this amazing organization needs our help. North Shore Rescue has lost 30 thousand dollars worth of equipment to thieves and they don't know how they're going to replace it. 

Please consider donating a small amount to show NSR how much we value their service.

Thank-you!

The Nat and Drew Show, 103.5 QMFM
(Nat, Drew, Erin and Scooter)
