story:
Short Summary

  • Peace and love! We are a collection of 6 beautiful souls who are currently short on funds to repair our bus and make it to Rainbow's national gathering in Utah. We hit a few snags along the way and now find ourselves stranded with no wheels and an infant. The bus, named "The Point", needs new brakes to make it safe for cross country travel to the gathering. This is the trip of a lifetime, and our chance to see the countries greatest wonders. We are 6 kids on a bus, looking to spend the summer learning, loving, and living. We understand that money is a hard thing to come by in times like these, and would greatly cherish any help we can receive. 

What We Need & What You Get

Repair costs are currently projected at $600 USD not including parts and fuel costs for the drive. Our perks include soulfully written poems, hand made jewelry out of precious stones and copper, as well as your name or message painted on our bus as a sponsor and helping hand to get us home! Any and all funds we receive will go into our gas tank, as well as our unforeseen repairs. 

The Impact

  • This trip comes to us after a very hard year, we all have, for one reason or another, experienced hardships that has gathered us all to meeting and forever changing our paths for the better. We wish to continue down this path of healing and learning to experience the gift of life itself. Rainbow is an amazing opportunity and environment that we just cannot afford to miss. Help us get home!

Risks & Challenges

  • We may fail to make it to the gathering on time if we do not act fast, and there is no way to tell if "The Point" will make it to Utah in one piece, but with your help we can do it. With the infant on the bus we need our ride to be as safe as possible. We are hard working individuals with deeply seeded morals and love for one another that is sure to push us in the right direction. We and more then willing to laugh in the face of our challenges and come out better people as long as we have the chance to do so.   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate money to our mission please pass the word along. If each person donates $5 we can easily make our goal on time. You can also help out by donating supplies, food, gas, art, books, and love!

Thank you so much!

story:
Shirley and Sue began Verdant Ground garden Co-op 10 years ago. "sustainability from the ground up" is the tag line.  We have grown a bit since then, actually expanding five fold!  The grower members work together and we share in the harvest, so it is literally "will work for food" Little did we know that it would also be growing community- what a delightful perk!

Our goal over the next couple of years is to focus on the co-op, become a non profit, and build the membership base.  we see room for someone to do markets, for workshops, for garden tours, for yoga in the gardens... all of which need more folks and more energy.

This wee cub tractor is going to be the back saver and time/energy saver.  It is a dream coming true!!    For now, we need your help to purchase the tractor.  We have traded for a cultivator which will be ready for fall, as we begin to collect implements. This feels like a positive way for us to continue to involve folks in our endeavors.  We will continue to barter to meet our requirements here, and the farmstand does provide seed $ for the following year, but mostly we rely on friends, and this also means friends we have yet to meet.

If 60 people offered $25, it is bought!  You can help out enormously by spreading this campaign to your friends and fam!  So, needless to say, if you are ever in northern Michigan, near Eastport, in summer or fall  -Stop on by! Or from your home, check out www.verdantground.org

story:
NEWSFLASH: Chief Cabinet Secretary Osamu Fujimura said the ruling party has started intensive discussions on the possibility of joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership by the Nov. 12-13 Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, meeting in Honolulu. from
AP Story Oct. 12

The lines in the sand have been drawn, let’s hope a wave of resistance can wash them away…

Moana Nui needs your help so that we can fly in some key people from around the Pacific to not only voice their concerns over new challenges as a result of new regional agreements like the Trans-Pacific Strategic and Economic Partnership Agreement (TPPA). A new challenge for Pacific Islanders is being called to confront what U.S. Sec. of State Clinton lays out in an op-ed called America's Pacific Century* (Oct 11, 2011).  She writes:

"...our work will proceed along six key lines of action: strengthening bilateral security alliances; deepening our working relationships with emerging powers, including with China; engaging with regional multilateral institutions; expanding trade and investment; forging a broad-based military presence; and advancing democracy and human rights.

This agenda will even further negatively impact Pacific Islanders and erode our work for stewarding our peoples, lands and resources. We have one opportunity to speak in a public voice while these agreements are being negotiated at a G-21 APEC summit in Honolulu at the same time.

For more information or if you would also like to attend our People's summit, contact: moananui2011@gmail.com

Adding to Perk 1: Free music download by KUPA'AINA.

MOANA NUI: Pacific Peoples, our Land and Economies

International Conference creating a forum for Pacific Island Peoples strategizing alternatives to APEC, Militarization and Globalization

When: November 9 - 11, 2011

Where:  Honolulu, Hawaii

Information:  http://moananui2011.org and http://ifg.org/programs/apec.html

Honolulu, HI—

Organized by a partnership of Pacific Islander cultural practitioners, scholars, and environmental and social activists, and in collaboration with the International Forum on Globalization (San Francisco), Moana Nui is intended to provide a voice for Pacific Islanders and set a direction for their economies in an era of powerful transnational corporations, global industrial expansion, and climate change.  


The three-day schedule will include a Pacific Island Open Forum where participants will begin to draft working guidelines that will frame a pathway to a Moana Nui Declaration.

The organizers of the Moana Nui Conference have planned for three days of panel presentations, public discussions and breakout sessions that include:

1) Indigenous Rights, Economies, Governance

2) Militarization in the Pacific

3) Globalization, Development and Geopolitics

4) Pacific Resources, Lands and Economies

5) APEC & TPPA: What We Must Know, What We Should Do

 

The Impact


APEC’s stated goal is the “promotion of free-trade and investments in the region and whose members make commitments to liberalizing regulations on trade and investment”.  As we have seen with the 2008 financial collapse of the housing market, as well as the struggles of independent farmers against GMO/agri-business over the last 20 years, "free-trade" is a doctrine that means “free of regulations,” another term for owning or leasing public resources for the benefit of shareholders profits.  For Pacific Islands, regional "investments" include new mining technologies that require the development of infrastructure and security that further alienates peoples from their lands and traditional resources.


Financial institutions and transnational corporations will be the largest recipients of this ongoing exploitation of people and resources.  The Pacific Ocean is about one-third the size of the earth, and it is what many Pacific Islanders from across these vast distances historically call “Moana Nui” (vast ocean). Why this should be of concern is that, these new investment projects threaten the bio-diversity of fragile reef systems and will vastly contribute to climate change, likely turning several small island populations into refugees.


This is the first time an international economic conference of this magnitude is taking place in Hawaii, on the shores of the United States Pacific Command Center.  Over $45 million is being spent on funding the security of APEC 2011 and over 15,000 people, including dignitaries, business executives, government trade ministers and representatives of financial institutions will be in attendance.


We need your help to raise awareness and protect this vital region from continued exploitation.   Your contributions will promote the restoration of the traditional stewardship of our land and ocean resources, a tradition that considers the balance of people and planet, placing it above profit. It is an arduous road, but our hope is that we might reduce
environmental degradation and resource depletion while working towards sustainable communities.

 

 

What We Need & What You Get


We aim to raise $15,000.  These funds will help to pay for organizational costs, airfare, video documentation, and promotional material.  If we are able to reach or exceed our goals, we will use these funds to make a larger impact towards challenging these economic and strategic negotiations taking place within APEC.  According to experts who have been critically following these negotiations, many of these new agreements will not only hurt labor or increase the costs of medicines and foods, but they will alienate people from their common resources.


These struggles between peoples and investment regimes will go on long after this conference is over, but your help is your commitment of support to the hundreds of new struggles that will pour our like a flood as a result of new investment agreements in the Pacific. 


Agreements like the Trans Pacific Strategic and Economic Partnership Agreement (TPPA) will likely move forward. Called a NAFTA on steroids, the TPPA is more like the Terminator IV unleashed on the Pacific.  These negotiations entail the building of infrastructure and implementing security, which means new ports and large scale developments over fragile reefs and small island economies, and will likely involve the participation of the military and private government contractors.


Throughout this short fundraising campaign, more perks will become available.  These will include: music downloads, art, signed books, videos, subscriptions, whatever our partners can commit to contributing with such short-notice.

 

Moana Nui is being presented by a partnership between the International Forum on Globalizaion (IFG) and Pua Mohala I Ka Po.



Participants include:

Walden Bello (Philippines) Member, House of Representatives, Philippines, Akbayan (Citizens' Action Party), Senior Analyst, Focus on the Global South;
Jon Osorio (Hawaii) Director of Hawaiian Studies, University of Hawaii, Manoa;
Victoria Tauli-Corpuz (Igorot, Philippines) Tebtebba Foundation. Former Director, UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues;
Lori Wallach (US) Public Citizen’s Global Trade Watch;
Kyle Kajihiro (Hawaii) DMZ Hawaii/Aloha Aina;
Mililani Trask (Hawaii) Vice Chair, General Assembly of Nations, Unrepresented Nations and Peoples Organizations (UNPO);
Dr. Joseph Gerson (US) Author, Director of Programs, American Friends Service Committee;
Anuradha Mittal (India) Director, Oakland Institute;
Richard Heinberg (US),  Senior Fellow, Post Carbon Institute, Author, "The End of Growth";
Christine Ahn (South Korea) International Peace Activist;
Santi Hitorangi (Rapanui), Arist, Farmer, Representative of Hito Clan;
Dr. Lisa Natividad (Guam) University of Guam;
Julian Aguon (Guam) Indigenous Chamoru Activist, Attorney, and Author;
Suzuyo Takazato (Okinawa) Co-Chair, Okinawa Women Act Against Military Violence;
Yumi Kikuchi (Japan/Hawaii) International Peace and Anti-Nuclear Activist;
Mayumi Oda (Japan/Hawaii) International Peace and Environmental Activist, Global Peace Campaign;
Arnie Saiki (Hawaii) Statehood Hawaii/Imi Pono Projects;
Jane Kelsey (New Zealand) Prof. of Law, University of Auckland, Author of Trans Pacific Partnership (TPP) Digest;
Adam Wolfenden (Australia) Trade Justice Campaigner, Pacific Network on Globalization (PANG);
Walter Ritte, Jr. (Molokai, Hawaii), Hawaiian sovereignty activist, Anti-GMO movement;
Meenakshi Raman, (Malaysia) Third World Network;
Sanya Reid Smith, (Malaysia)  Third World Network;
Dr. Noelani Goodyear (Hawaii) University of Hawaii;
Galina Angarova (Russia/Siberia) Pacific Environment;
Terri Keko’olani (Hawaii) DMZ Hawaii/Aloha Aina, Sovereignty Activist;
Q’orianka Kilcher (Peru) Executive Director, On-Q Initiative, Actress/Indigenous Activist; 
Moana Jackson (New Zealand/Maori) Director, Nga Kaiwhakamarama I Nga Ture (the Maori Legal Service); Maori Law & Philosophy degree programme, Te Wananga o Raukawa;
Koohan Paik (Hawaii), Film maker; Kauai Alliance for Peace & Social Justice; Co-Author, "The Superferry Chronicles;” 
Victor Menotti (US) Executive Director, International Forum on Globalization
Jerry Mander (US) Founder, Distinguished Fellow, International Forum on Globalization

Another way that you can help is also donate to IFG for their contribution to Moana Nui.  http://www.ifg.org/

Even if you are unable to help with funds, we thank you for giving this attention. 

Mālama ‘Āina, Mālama Kai,  Mālama Pono.

(Give care to the land, give care to the water, give care to what is just)

Recent Press:

Opposing paradigms converge on Hawaii Al Jazeera, Oct. 7th, 2011
Moana Nui Set to “Undress” APEC / Cómo desvestir a la APEC IPS-Inter Press Service, Oct. 3, 2011

 * was just removed from State Department website and is published in Foreign Policy Journal.

government contractors. 

Throughout this short fundraising campaign, more perks will become available.  These will include: music downloads, art,
signed books, videos, subscriptions, whatever our partners can commit to contributing with such short-notice. 
 
Moana Nui is being presented by a partnership between the International Forum on Globalizaion (IFG) and Pua Mohala I Ka Po. 

Participants include: 
Walden
Bello (Philippines) Member, House of Representatives, Philippines, Akbayan
(Citizens' Action Party), Senior Analyst, Focus on the Global South; Jon Osorio (Hawaii) Director of
Hawaiian Studies, University of Hawaii, Manoa; Victoria Tauli-Corpuz (Igorot, Philippines) Tebtebba Foundation.
Former Director, UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues;Lori Wallach (US) Public Citizen’s Global Trade Watch; Kyle Kajihiro (Hawaii) DMZ Hawaii/Aloha Aina; Mililani
Trask (Hawaii) Vice Chair, General Assembly of Nations, Unrepresented
Nations and Peoples Organizations (UNPO); Dr.
Joseph Gerson (US) Author, Director of Programs, American Friends Service
Committee; Anuradha Mittal (India)
Director, Oakland Institute; Richard
Heinberg (US),  Senior Fellow,
Post Carbon Institute, Author, "The End of Growth"; Christine Ahn (South Korea)
International Peace Activist; Santi
Hitorangi (Rapanui), Arist, Farmer, Representative of Hito Clan; Dr. Lisa Natividad (Guam) University of
Guam; Julian Aguon (Guam) Indigenous
Chamoru Activist, Attorney, and Author; Suzuyo
Takazato (Okinawa) Co-Chair, Okinawa Women Act Against Military Violence; Yumi Kikuchi (Japan/Hawaii)
International Peace and Anti-Nuclear Activist; Mayumi Oda (Japan/Hawaii) International Peace and Environmental
Activist, Global Peace Campaign; Arnie
Saiki (Hawaii) Statehood Hawaii/Imi Pono Projects; Jane
Kelsey (New Zealand) Prof. of Law, University of Auckland, Author of Trans
Pacific Partnership (TPP) Digest; Adam
Wolfenden (Australia) Trade Justice Campaigner, Pacific Network on
Globalization (PANG);Walter Ritte, Jr.
(Molokai, Hawaii), Hawaiian sovereignty activist, Anti-GMO movement; Meenakshi Raman, (Malaysia) Third World
Network; Sanya Reid Smith,
(Malaysia)  Third World Network; Dr. Noelani Goodyear (Hawaii) University
of Hawaii; Galina Angarova
(Russia/Siberia) Pacific Environment; Terri
Keko’olani (Hawaii) DMZ Hawaii/Aloha Aina, Sovereignty Activist; Q’orianka Kilcher (Peru) Executive
Director, On-Q Initiative, Actress/Indigenous Activist;  Moana
Jackson (New Zealand/Maori) Director, Nga Kaiwhakamarama I Nga Ture (the
Maori Legal Service); Maori Law & Philosophy degree programme, Te Wananga o
Raukawa; Koohan Paik (Hawaii), Film
maker; Kauai Alliance for Peace & Social Justice; Co-Author, "The
Superferry Chronicles;”  Victor
Menotti (US) Executive Director, International Forum on Globalization Jerry Mander (US) Founder,
Distinguished Fellow, International Forum on Globalization 
Another way that you can help is also donate to IFG for their contribution to Moana Nui.  http://www.ifg.org/ 


Even if you are unable to help with funds, we thank you for giving this attention.  
Mālama ‘Āina, Mālama Kai,  Mālama Pono. 
(Give care to the land, give care to the water, give care to what is just)
Recent Press: 
Opposing paradigms converge on Hawaii Al Jazeera, Oct. 7th, 2011Moana Nui Set to “Undress” APEC / Cómo desvestir a la APEC IPS-Inter Press Service, Oct. 3, 2011
 * was just removed from State Department website and is published in Foreign Policy Journal.

story:
Argali Sheep

Argali wild sheep are listed as Near Threatened throughout their range in Asia, and are of great conservation concern. Shy and easily displaced by livestock and human activity, more research is needed so that effective range management strategies can be developed in Mongolia - before Argali join the Endangered list. 

 

Mongolia - The Land of Blue Skies

I first travelled to Mongolia as a conservation volunteer in 2009, and instantly fell in love. The people are warm, the culture is unique and the wildlife and landscape are truly spectacular. I loved it so much that I returned a year later as a biology field assistant, and spent 3 months living in a traditional ger and working with a small team of great biologists. 

This year, since completing my Masters degree, I have the chance to go back again – but this time to do my own research.

 

The Expedition

In August & September I'll attach GPS collars to wild Argali, and then digitally map their locations over an 18 month period. This will allow me to build a picture of their grazing ecology; how much they might compete with other species of herbivore such as Ibex and domestic livestock, and the potential for conflict with humans.

The research is really important to Argali conservation, not least because competition from livestock grazing is likely to increase in the future. Therefore understanding the relationships between both wild & domestic herbivores is vital to creating effective conservation & management strategies.

Living conditions on this trip will be unique to Mongolia, and very different from Western-style living. During the trip I'll stay in a traditional Mongolian ger, without electricity or running water, and will cook & eat a traditional Mongol diet (meat, meat and meat). My ger-mates will be Mongolian biology students and the closest neighbours will be semi-nomadic herders a few km away, so I'll also get a chance to brush up on my Mongolian language skills (yes I can speak a bit of Mongolian!). As there's no internet or phone connection there, I'll keep a journal & post excerpts weekly on my return to give a flavour of life on the edge of the Gobi.


Why I Need YOU

As an aspiring conservation ecologist I’m completely independent, meaning the only way I can do this research is by finding imaginative sources of funding. That’s where you come in!

I hope to raise £1000 towards the GPS tracking equipment I need to collect this valuable scientific data. 

Please help this exciting and unique project by making a donation!

 

Thank-You 'Perks'

By helping the project with a donation, you’ll also be able to gain a unique insight into Argali research and conservation - and of life in the Land of Blue Skies. You’ll have access to updates on the project, and if you donate a pre-defined amount you can claim a thank-you gift. These include a postcard from basecamp, a print of an Argali wearing a GPS collar you helped pay for, a souvenir from Mongolia, and an invitation to a special presentation about the research trip.

This project is important not only to me (as the fulfilment of my wildest dreams!), but also to wildlife conservation in Mongolia and the advancement of scientific knowledge on an international level.


Please Share!

Please share this, on your facebook, twitter, through the sharing links, and with your friends, family, and everyone you know  – help me reach my target of £1000!

And if you’re interested in finding out more about me or the project, check out my new blog: http://thelothianlass.wordpress.com/

 

Thank You!!

Colleen McCulloch

:)

story:
If you'd like to get more involved and come down to Costa Rica to be one of our volunteers follow this link! 
 
PLEASE SPECIFY THAT YOU HEARD ABOUT US THROUGH INDIEGOGO 
 
APPLY HERE to Volunteer with the Eco Preservation Society in Costa Rica
 
Also see SEEDLINGS! An inside view of the work of the Eco Preservation Society in Costa Rica.  The results of your donation in action:

SEEDLINGS 1- Introducing the Team
SEEDLINGS 2 - Knowledge is Power
SEEDLINGS 3 - Our Sustainable Culture
SEEDLINGS 4 - The Life Giving System
SEEDLINGS 5 - The Germination Process

Learn More: The Active Conservationist Program
 

REWARD UPGRADE: We have upgraded the rewards:
$10 - One Tree Planted, Photo, and GPS.
$100 - 50 Trees Planted, Photo, GPS and Google Earth Tag.

The crisis is already here. The earth's resources are being depleted, the air's getting filthier, and it's only 2013! Isn't this something we should be watching in some sci-fi flick with a date in the distant future like 3029?? 

Research has shown that the Middle East, like Costa Rica, one of today's more popular vacation destinations, used to be lush with forests. But years and years of ancient civilizations cutting down all their trees, left the land exposed to the harsh sun, and it literally baked, turning it into the desert we see today. 
 
The Hawaiian Island of Lanai was deforested in the 19th century and its land still hasn't recovered. Wind erosion poses a constant problem and it's nearly impossible for vegetation to grow. Compare this with the beautiful islands located just a few miles away...
 
In Costa Rica the logging has already started. Huge areas have been deforested and the soil is turning hard. In the hot climate, without trees, the earth doesn't stand a chance. So that's where we come in. Eco Preservation Society has received the rights to go on to protected land and plant 40,000 baby trees. Once in the ground these trees will never be able to be cut down. We're getting at the problem early enough so that the root systems will be able to save the earth in these locations from the same fate as Lanai. But that's only one part of what we're doing. 
 
With our $12,500 goal we'll not only be able to get these trees planted, but we'll be able to start construction on totally green housing for our volunteers. With our amazing team we will be able to document our progress. Showing the world how to start a sustainable community, from construction of housing, to setting up our garden, to getting a clean energy source up and running. It's our hope that people who access these videos for free on YouTube etc. will implement some or all of these aspects in their own homes. Clean energy, growing your own food, living green, none of these things need to be done out on some farm. You can do them from the comfort of your own home, EASILY! Eco Preservation Society would love to show you how so you can share this knowledge and it can spread like wildfire (the good kind). 
 
OUR VISION IS HUGE
 
Once we get these initial 40,000 planted we will receive more trees and be able to go to more locations. At each new location we will set up different energy sources and implement different types of structures so that the local population can use whatever system works best for them. Our end goal is to set up these structures for volunteers all over the world so that no one can claim ignorance about living green.
 
With your donation you will receive a green certificate for helping the planet. 
 
To receive any award please put your email address either in the comments section or contact Sonia Kish personally through indiegogo 
 
Eco Preservation is a nonprofit. Your donations will go towards buying supplies, not into someone's pocket! 

Join our event on Facebook to gather support! 

CLICK HERE: to join our event on Facebook

CLICK HERE: to follow our progress on Facebook

story:
We want to live in a way that is less wasteful and more responsible. We are half way there but we need your help!


Meet SJ:I LOVE this planet and I think its SUPER important to do all I can to help protect and conserve what we got going on. Small day-to-day activities, as well as large life style changes have helped me to achieve a less wasteful existence. Sure, I am far from the exemplary Earth citizen but I do try to make a conscience effort every day. I am a 26 year old returned Peace Corps volunteer, Americorps volunteer and Student Conservation Association member. I served in Ecuador as a natural resource conservation volunteer in the Amazon. Having less really made me take a good look at my extravagant first world ways and adjust my ideas on what I need to live a good and happy life. It turns out, it’s really not much. I need the ones I love, air in my lungs, a few good things to eat and a place to call home! 
Here lies the problem….A PLACE TO CALL HOME. The past few years I have been bouncing around trying to figure myself out, go on great adventures, help others and protect my planet…South America, Central America and right here in the good ol’ USA. This past Summer I worked with the National Park Service mapping native endangered plants in West Virginia. The mapping project was created as an aid to help the park with poaching problems. In Ecuador, I worked with indigenous communities on eco tourism projects to save the forest from the big bad oil companies, single crop farming and logging. I would love to keep traveling and working on conservation projects….but I do need a place to call home….it would be great if I could just bring my home with me…transition to….TINY HOUSE ON WHEELS!

Meet Matt: 

In recognizing what I have, what I use, and what I actually need, I've decided it's not beyond me to not live beyond my means. I think it's a practical response to issues that have risen due to a standard of living that is unnecessary like wasted energy, water, space, and resources of all kinds. I'd like to be less of a contributor to waste, and along the way introduce these ideas to other people. I'm 25 and unlike SJ I have no particular involvement in conservation. My involvement  has been primarily limited to recycling and picking up trash when I see it,  but I am really excited to start living in a way that does less harm and hopefully some good. Not to mention the liberation of no mortgage.

 Ive visited 25  of our states and a little bit of Canada in a van playing music with friends, though it was only for a couple weeks for a couple summers, it gave me a taste of the road and I can't think of much I like more than being out there. Sj and I plan to visit national parks, maybe work in some, and take as much in as possible. 

 

This project has been one of the best experiences of my life. It's been an awesome creative outlet for me. Since beginning life as an adult working full time, time becomes less for making cool things. 

After college I managed a specialty hotdog restaurant for a couple years which was really fun and allowed me to be creative, while slang'n dogs was a good time, it was also a role that helped me grow and see what I was capable of. With no experience in actually building anything it's the biggest thing I've ever done and it's only proved to me again that doing anything is just putting your time and mind toward it, nothin to it but to do it. I'd like for others to maybe be inspired by that, whether building a small house or doing something bigger, I hope it  helps people feel more comfortable to try something.


What is sustainability?

According to the EPA "Sustainability is based on a simple principle: Everything that we need for our survival and well-being depends, either directly or indirectly, on our natural environment. Sustainability creates and maintains the conditions under which humans and nature can exist in productive harmony, that permit fulfilling the social, economic and other requirements of present and future generations."

Our tiny home will have components allowing us to use and waste less and reuse and recycle more 

  • Composting toilet - no this is not a "litter box". In Ecuador we built a composting toilet and it worked just fine. If we build it and use it right, it will not smell, it will not use any water and our waste can be used outside to enrich the soil (without being harmful and is completely safe to use)
  • Solar power 
  • Gravity fed water system - in the kitchen we will not need any type of pump we will just let gravity do all the work. 
  • Reclaimed building materials - reducing others waste, diverting materials from ending up in a landfill, supporting Habitat For Humanity ReStore and turning trash into treasure and making it look gooooooooood =]

What We Need

We are currently mid-build. We have around 7,600 invested in our tiny house so far. Initially, we planned on only spending 10,000 to build our dream home and start our traveling life. However, due to some unexpected mishaps we are going to need additional funds.This is why we are here asking for help. We are building our home outdoors and unfortunately we cannot control the weather. Our subfloor got completely flooded during a storm ( a storm strong enough to rip our tarps from our house ) and needed to be replaced...alot of extra work, time and money!

As you can see, we had to rip it all out. The insulation was mostly ruined, we did manage to rescue some of it from the water and will hopefully still be able to use some of it. The plywood flooring now covered in black mold is not really usable for our floor (we will try to use it in some other way if possible). But honestly the damage could have been much worse, so we thank our lucky stars. 
We still need to purchase/obtain:
  • Insulation for the remainder of our floor, walls and roof
  • Interior wall sheathing
  • Siding (we are looking for reclaimed wood...hopefully barn wood) 
  • Flooring
  • Solar Panel System
  • Heater
  • Sinks
  • Composting toliet materials
  • Counter tops and cabinets 
  • Horse trough (for the bathtub) 
  • Stove burners, refrigerator
  • Front Door
  • Underlayment for roofing panels
  • And alot of small odds and ends 
Not 100% sure how much all of this will cost but we are using as many reclaimed materials as we can find (which are usually less expensive or free) and we are also great bargain shoppers! We still need alot of items to complete our house but we honestly think an extra 2,500 will totally make it  possible.
To give you an idea of what our money has gone towards so far here is a basic breakdown:
  • Trailer - $3,250
  • Trailer Customization - $491
  • 2x4 / 2x6 lumber - $1,380
  • Plywood - $643
  • Hardware, structural reinforcements (Simpson Strong Ties) - $446
  • Insulation - $206
  • Subfloor Materials (aluminum flashing, insulating foam, metal fastners, liquid nail) - $187
  • Windows - $360 (found a giant window at the ReStore for $7!!) =] 
  • Drillbits - $59
  • Tarps- $203
  • Metal Roofing Panels - $300
 
The Impact

Once our tiny home is finished we plan on traveling the country, volunteering with organizations that have conservation efforts in mind, possibly working with the Student Conservation Association again or signing up for another Americorps project and eventually going back to school...again...we will forever be students of life.

We will be able to live in a more environmentally conscious  way, independent from societies 'norms' and the hold of the electric and gas companies. We will be using solar energy on a daily basis, a composting toilet and living a more simple tiny life. We will be taking up less space and spending less money. 

While traveling we will have a platform to spread the word about the "tiny lifestyle" and possibly get a few other tiny dreams started. The hardest part is just starting!

Also I can finally take Walter and Weeze with me when I am volunteering. My cats no longer have to feel abandoned by me.


Risks & Challenges
  1. Not having an indoor space to build and trying to build our home out doors. Like I said, we can not control the weather! We have already had massive water damage to our subfloor and we had to re sand the bottom of our trailer (which was the absolute hardest part of this build so far) to remove all the rust and then re paint it...all on our backs, upside down, underneath the trailer. I am still pulling tiny pieces of metal from my legs and arms.
  2. Having enough money to even start this project! We both moved back home with our parents to help save on bills and rent while we build our home. And, just like every other 20 something year old in the United States....we have massive student loans...which doesn't make it easy to save and buy building materials. 
  3. The thought of epic failure...driving down the highway and pieces of our home falling off and being carried away. The thought of not having enough money to finish or getting stuck in some aspect of construction and not being able to move forward. Building something from scratch when you have never really built anything before is very scary. However, without risk there is no reward! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us out, no big deal! We honestly feel kind of weird asking strangers for money but we figure...you help us now and we can help you later with your endeavors. And if you have no spare change in your pockets just share this campaign with your friends and neighbors or post it on social media.  

Or just...start recycling...

We are building our home outdoors and unfortunately we cannot control the weather. Our subfloor got completely flooded during a storm ( a storm strong enough to rip our tarps from our house ) and needed to be replaced...alot of extra work, time and money!


As you can see, we had to rip it all out. The insulation was mostly ruined, we did manage to rescue some of it from the water and will hopefully still be able to use some of it. The plywood flooring now covered in black mold is not really usable for our floor (we will try to use it in some other way if possible). But honestly the damage could have been much worse, so we thank our lucky stars. 
We still need to purchase/obtain:


Insulation for the remainder of our floor, walls and roof
Interior wall sheathing

Siding (we are looking for reclaimed wood...hopefully barn wood) 

Flooring

Solar Panel System
Heater

Sinks

Composting toliet materials

Counter tops and cabinets 

Horse trough (for the bathtub) 

Stove burners, refrigerator

Front Door
Underlayment for roofing panels
And alot of small odds and ends 


Not 100% sure how much all of this will cost but we are using as many reclaimed materials as we can find (which are usually less expensive or free) and we are also great bargain shoppers! We still need alot of items to complete our house but we honestly think an extra 2,500 will totally make it  possible.
To give you an idea of what our money has gone towards so far here is a basic breakdown:

Trailer - $3,250

Trailer Customization - $491

2x4 / 2x6 lumber - $1,380

Plywood - $643

Hardware, structural reinforcements (Simpson Strong Ties) - $446

Insulation - $206

Subfloor Materials (aluminum flashing, insulating foam, metal fastners, liquid nail) - $187

Windows - $360 (found a giant window at the ReStore for $7!!) =] 

Drillbits - $59

Tarps- $203

Metal Roofing Panels - $300

 


The Impact

 Once our tiny home is finished we plan on traveling the country, volunteering with organizations that have conservation efforts in mind, possibly working with the Student Conservation Association again or signing up for another Americorps project and eventually going back to school...again...we will forever be students of life.
We will be able to live in a more environmentally conscious  way, independent from societies 'norms' and the hold of the electric and gas companies. We will be using solar energy on a daily basis, a composting toilet and living a more simple tiny life. We will be taking up less space and spending less money. 
While traveling we will have a platform to spread the word about the "tiny lifestyle" and possibly get a few other tiny dreams started. The hardest part is just starting!
Also I can finally take Walter and Weeze with me when I am volunteering. My cats no longer have to feel abandoned by me.



 

Risks & Challenges



Not having an indoor space to build and trying to build our home out doors. Like I said, we can not control the weather! We have already had massive water damage to our subfloor and we had to re sand the bottom of our trailer (which was the absolute hardest part of this build so far) to remove all the rust and then re paint it...all on our backs, upside down, underneath the trailer. I am still pulling tiny pieces of metal from my legs and arms.

Having enough money to even start this project! We both moved back home with our parents to help save on bills and rent while we build our home. And, just like every other 20 something year old in the United States....we have massive student loans...which doesn't make it easy to save and buy building materials. 

The thought of epic failure...driving down the highway and pieces of our home falling off and being carried away. The thought of not having enough money to finish or getting stuck in some aspect of construction and not being able to move forward. Building something from scratch when you have never really built anything before is very scary. However, without risk there is no reward! 

    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't help us out, no big deal! We honestly feel kind of weird asking strangers for money but we figure...you help us now and we can help you later with your endeavors. And if you have no spare change in your pockets just share this campaign with your friends and neighbors or post it on social media.  
Or just...start recycling...

story:
The Santa Barbara South Coast has all the resources we need to live vitally well with the water we have. Sweetwater Collaborative is weaving those resources together to establish permanent water security now and for future generations. We need your help to expand water wisdom throughout the entire community and strengthen creative collaboration to do so. 

The last three years have been declared the driest in California recorded history.  Over 50% of water consumption in southern CA is for landscapes.  Switching from lawns and lush temperate or tropical plants to native or Mediterranean plants, combined with onsite rainwater harvesting and greywater reuse can cut landscape water use by as much as 70%. Re-landscaping is one of the keys to adapting to drier climate conditions.

Since well before the current drought crisis, Sweetwater Collaborative has been helping people transform their landscapes with features that sharply reduce water consumption. We’ve converted lawns to breathtakingly beautiful water saving paradises.  We include as many edibles as possible with the water available.

The drought crisis requires Sweetwater Collaborative to step up our pace of community education and training, landscape transformation, and stakeholder collaboration, to help bring us lasting water security. We need financial support to advance to this essential next stage of our service to Santa Barbara. Your tax-deductible contribution will go to our own 501(c)3 non-profit organization Nurturing Across Cultures, known locally as Interplay, and be 100% earmarked for Sweetwater Collaborative. 

A food forest that replaced a lawn, 9 mo after downspouts were directed into the landscape, and fruit trees and other plants were put in, in Sweetwater workshops.

$10,000 is our goal for this campaign.  This will prime the pump by enabling us to bring more partners and resources together to effectively adapt our community to the drought and drier climate conditions ahead. Your contribution is leveraged to keep our workshop and training costs low, and continue to provide free community educational events and services.

Now is the time to act!   Even in drought, directing roof runoff into the soil can delay the need for irrigation for three months after the rainy season has ended.  We can save water in tanks to use in annual veggie gardens in between or after rains. Areas sheet-mulched to remove lawns need the water the sky provides even in dry years to complete the cycle of eradicating the grass.

Please contribute generously today. Water is life. Everything else depends on it. Water security for Santa Barbara is the most important investment you can make in our future. Our campaign is for 28 days, through the end of December.  Let’s end the year with a deep commitment to healing our community's relationship with the water cycle, now and for  the future.  Sweetwater Collaborative is all of us; let's invest in ourselves and our community.


The following graph represents some research Sweetwater has participated in and supported. It compares the costs of various options for meeting our water needs on the South Coast. The vertical blue line is our additional water need due to drought. The blue bars are the estimated amount of water available to meet that additional need from each option. The dark green bars are the minimum cost in $ per acre foot of water. The light green is the upper end cost in $ per acre foot. And the red bars compare the climate cost of each option, as carbon is emitted through power generation to get the water.  

IPR stands for Indirect Potable Reuse--directing treated waste water into groundwater instead of the ocean and then putting it back into the water supply after it's finished purifying through natural forces and treated to potable standards. Banked means stored in groundwater for a drought emergency.

As can be seen, by far the most costly option in both money and adverse climate impact is desalination. The least costly in both of these ways are deeper conservation through re-landscaping, eliminating lawn watering, and infiltration of rainwater into groundwater.

Graph used with permission from oasisdesign.net

Sweetwater Collaborative hosted a series of community Drought Forums in the summer and fall of 2014.  For our Drought  Policy Forum, we researched and wrote a preliminary report--Exploring Our Options: Santa Barbara Communities Collaborative Water Resources Stewardship for Drought and Beyond.

Read our report that summarizes the preliminary results of that research.

We collaborated with environmental educators, landscape professionals, policy advisers, government workers, and non-profit leaders to ask important questions about practical drought adaptation and long-term water system alternatives, including desalination.

Below please find our key findings.

Water is at the heart of all life, but our water security is threatened by drought and the climate crisis. Together we are developing secure ways to get the most out of our water and live well with the water we have. We are grateful for your partnership and generosity, whatever you can contribute. Thank you.

story:
In the forests of Cofre de Perote and its surroundings, with the help of researchers at the University of Veracruz, INECOL and UNAM, we aim to carry out a conservation programme which involves:

  • Bat community assessment
  • Determination of factors limiting and influencing the spatial distribution of bats
  • Researching the foraging ecology and habitat use of one of the most abundant montane frugivorous bat species, the highland yellow-shouldered bat.
  • Raising community awareness

Community awareness and education is also key in this project as the natural habitats of bats are declining due to deforestation. For this reason, we also aim to:

  • Reach local audience with a strong scientific basis and first-hand experience from field researchers
  • Interviews with other researchers, locals, visitors, and indigenous people to document a wide spectrum of the study site

 

MY STORY

I am dealing with bats since 2007 and a considerable part of my research activity is devoted to these amazing creatures. In the last three years I worked for one of the biggest organizations dedicated to conservation in tropics (Operation Wallacea), as a bat scientist. Since then, performing scientific research focused on tropical bats is one of my biggest dreams, but as a Hungarian, my situation is pretty hard to make this dream come true due to the lack of opportunities.

Photo By Pamela Thompson

How can you help?

  • Every little thing does its magic (each dollar counts)
  • Please help us to make some noise about this project by sending the link to your friends or posting to your social media sites.
  • If you want to contribute to the research project itself, please contact me. 
  • The incoming funds from this campaign will only be used for conducting this research. As a reward, donors of the project will appear in the publications if requested.

 

BACKGROUND, CONSERVATION SIGNIFICANCE


Tropical montane ecosystems are highly threatened by climate change and deforestation. These factors modify microclimate and vegetation structure at given altitudes, pushing montane plant and animal communities upslope, therefore increasing the probability of population fragmentation and ultimately the extinction of some species. Forest-dwelling bats are also concerned, as the occurrence of many species is highly dependent on elevation as well as the forest quality.



Photos By Anikó Kurali

Veracruz is one of the three states representing the highest biodiversity in Mexico, also home to neotropical cloud forests, however change in land use given by livestock and agriculture resulted a decline of natural forests. The area where we gonna work is well-studied from botanical aspect, however extensive zoological surveys, including bat research has not yet taken place.

Photo By Anikó Kurali

Frugivorous bats have a significant contribution to forest regeneration in the tropics, due to their particular importance as seed dispersers. For this reason they are perfect subjects of conservation studies investigating the effect of habitat fragmentation on biodiversity.  However, very little is known about the ecology of many tropical bat species, they are very understudied compared to other bats in the world, while they are highly concerned in habitat modifications and climate change. 

Photo By Anikó Kurali

…HOW?

Our study will involve extensive fieldwork in Cofre de Perote and the surrounding area (Central Veracruz, Mexico), using mark/recapture techniques, collecting droppings for diet analysis, as well as radio-tracking of the individuals. Biometric data will be collected from each of the captured individuals, a few (max 30) target individuals will be equipped with radio-transmitter, and then released immediately in their living habitat. Radio-tracking is a particularly effective method for studying foraging ecology and habitat use of animals (home range, foraging activity and roosting location). These radio-transmitters have small weights (0.5-1 g) suitable for placing them on small bats, because they are less than 5% of the body weight and bats can carry them without problem (they show no adverse effects).

Photo By Anikó Kurali

Photos By Pamela Thompson

 

The Impact

Saving Bats: Bat community assessment will provide information about bat population health and species distribution, which is highly unknown in Cofre de Perote and the surrounding area. With community assessment (via mist-netting and using bat detectors) we will identify keystone species with a focus on threats to their environment. We also shed light on the factors affecting bat community composition, diet and movements in the forests of Cofre de Perote and its surrounding.

Habitat Conservation: We will identify „hotspots” where the ecosystem services provided by bats may have key importance for the certain locality, where conservation efforts should be concentrated  and where bat community includes endangered or vulnerable species, in order to propose specific conservation strategies in different elevations.

Community Awareness: We will develop relationships with local and national governmental agencies to enforce existing environmental laws and assist in the development of future protective legislation. We will provide information to local stakeholders and propose specific management strategies for improving and maintaining habitat conditions in different elevations that are essential for bats. We will educate the community to engage in sustainable practices and develop cooperative relationships with local schools

COLLABORATORS INVOLVED IN THE PROJECT:


University of Veracruz: I will spend min. 1 year at the University of Veracruz, thanks to the National Mexican Governmental Scholarship (AMEXCID), which helps me to cover my expenses for housing, visa, insurance and travel and his is an absolute honor and privilege, however due to budget cuts, we are required to seek private funding for a part of the project equipment.

BIOVERA Project - Exploration and explanation of biodiversity patterns along gradients of climate, soil and disturbance in Central Veracruz Mexico. The project is now growing intensively, we intend to contribute to the project with zoological input, including this research. 

Radio-tracking of the bats is a distinct component which would otherwise (in the absence of financial support) not take place. We are seeking for fund to purchase the necessary equipment for radio-telemetry.
 

 

*

story:
The Spot Box

The average UK woman uses (and throws away) 11,000 tampons and pads in her lifetime. In the UK alone 4 million tampons and pads are flushed down the toilet or sent to landfill every day where they start to rot and release greenhouse gasses. There is also an additional waste problem associated with the products
such as plastic tampon applicators and pad wrappers and the use of energy, water and resources used in the manufacturing processes of these disposable items. 


Changing to biodegradable or reusable sanitary products is a small step that makes a massive change to the environment! it can also save you money and improve your health!! 


The Spot Box provides a simple way to access biodegradable and reusable sanitary products, They are delivered right to your door in discreet packaging and can come with gifts and treats to see you through your monthly cycle!

What We Need 

The Spot Box needs £1000 for start up costs!

£400- To stock our cupboards full of lovely biodegradable and reusable sanitary products as well as beautiful organic, fair trade  goodies and treats to make your monthlies feel like a walk in the park!

£100- To help us print marketing materials to promote The Spot Box and provide information on the impact of sanitary products to environments and communities 

£100- To help us buy stationary for our office including posting materials, filing systems, paper and pens all recycled of course!! 

£400- For an awesome new website where you can purchase The Spot Box, all the other amazing reusable, biodegradable and organic products as well as finding out lots of info on health, the environment and new exciting news in women's  hygiene products from across the globe.


 For every single donation you will be listed as a contributor on our website and receive your first Spot Box free when you  sign up for monthly subscription!


The Impact

Switching to biodegradable and reusable sanitary products will prevent MILLIONS of damaging pads and tampons from being sent to landfill or flushed down the toilet where they will rot producing damaging green house gasses, cause obstructions for wildlife and cause long term damage to our environment.

Switching to Biodegradable and reusable sanitary products can also improve personal health, the lack of perfumes for example can prevent itching, irritation and imbalanced vaginal PH and there is massively reduced risk of toxic shock syndrome from 100% cotton tampons!!!

But are the products as effective as high-street non biodegradable brands?/ Do they smell? /Will it cost more?/ Are they quick and easy to use?


Above are some of the issues/ questions we have encountered during our extensive market research, we understand for some women changing from products they know and have trusted for years is a scary step, especially when talking about such a personal subject! We have however tried and tested all of the product range and have found:
They are as  100% effective as big high-street brands
They are unperformed but do not cause any foul orders
The individual boxes for biodegradable products cost around £3 per box very much in line with non biodegradable products. Reusable products cost between £15-£25 but can be used again and again for years at a time, so in the long run you will be saving money. The Spot Box that comes with a pick-a-mix variety of pads, tampons and a selection of gifts will cost between £5-£10, you will be able to sign up for a monthly superscription to The Spot Box, order on a box-by-box basis or simply order the pads/tampons on there own.
All of the products are simple to use! The biodegradable products work exactly the same as non biodegradable products simply use them then dispose of them (either in your usual waste bin or compost) no mess, no fuss, no issue. The reusable are a little different and do require some level of cleaning before you reuse them, this dose not need to be a long drawn out process with the moon cup for example simply tip it out pour over some water an it is ready for use again!
If you would like any further information or have any questions of your own please send us a message via our Facebook page at: 
  https://www.facebook.com/pages/The-Spot-Online/180046112143719?ref=hl
We are always happy to help

I love this project but can afford £0 donation how can I help?

We know exactly what it is like to have £0 in the kitty but still really want to help a project succeed! Although without donations we will never get this project off the ground we also need people to share our message with the world!

So please if you can, share this page with all of your friends, family, co-workers! use social network, have discussions, start a debate!

If you would like to help us even more apply to become a member of our street team get sent a street team promotion pack and a sample of our products in exchange for spreading the word of The Spot Box and The Spot On line

We need all the support we can receive but together with the smallest of changes we can make a MASSIVE impact on our health and the health of the enviroment.


Much Love and Many Thanks

Team Spot Box

We are always happy to help

    I love this project but can afford £0 donation how can I help? We know exactly what it is like to have £0 in the kitty but still really want to help a project succeed! Although without donations we will never get this project off the ground we also need people to share our message with the world!
So please if you can, share this page with all of your friends, family, co-workers! use social network, have discussions, start a debate!
If you would like to help us even more apply to become a member of our street team get sent a street team promotion pack and a sample of our products in exchange for spreading the word of The Spot Box and The Spot On line
We need all the support we can receive but together with the smallest of changes we can make a MASSIVE impact on our health and the health of the enviroment.

Much Love and Many Thanks
Team Spot Box

story:
Jumpstart the Biochar Revolution in Haiti!

We are Carbon Roots International (CRI), a non-profit based in the United States, and we're working to bring biochar to Haiti and the wider developing world.

A couple years ago, we learned about biochar, and began tinkering around in our backyards with different uses and production technologies; after the 2010 earthquake in Haiti, we decided to establish CRI and start the biochar revolution in Haiti, where it's needed most.  

A quick primer: biochar is a sustainable, charcoal-based soil amendment that substantially increases crop yields, rebuilds the soil, and sequesters carbon. Biochar fosters a healthy ecosystem of microorganisms - it's like a coral reef in the soil! For a country like Haiti, which has severely depleted soil and declining food production, biochar represents a carbon negative way to substantially raise crop yields without the input of chemical fertilizers.  For farmers like Pepe (see video above), this is HUGE! 

Biochar is the next big thing in sustainable agriculture and international development, and we are helping Haitian farmers to lead the way.

After 18 months of refining biochar production technology to its simplest form, we are on the verge of completing our pilot project in the La Coupe valley of Haiti. This will prove that biochar can work in Haiti, and that it has a future in the wider developing world. We need your help to complete our field trials and begin to bring biochar to scale in rural Haiti!

Visit our website to learn more about our work with Haitian farmers, visit:

CarbonRootsInternational.org

What We Need & What You Get

With your help we can raise $5,000. By investing in Haitian farmers, your funds will:

  • $2,500 will go to farmer training, and
  • $2,500 will go to equipment production

Be one of our first 10 donors and receive our $25 perk (two unique CRI postcards) at a $10 level!

Our goal is to reach 100 farmers with training and equipment - if we all fall short of our fundraising goal, your support will still allow us to train and equip numerous Haitian farmers and start the sustainable revolution!

The Impact

Our CharBon ("GoodChar" in Haitian Creole) campaign will provide economic opportunities for poor Haitian farmers by increasing crop yields, improve the environment by rebuilding the soil with applied nutrients, and help combat climate change by sequestering carbon in the ground.  Specifically, the campaign will:

  • Provide individual training to farmers in biochar production and use, giving them a self-sustained source of income.
  • Supply farmers with biochar kilns to become local entrepreneurs in their community.
  • Play a vital role in curbing deforestation, improving Haitian food security, and even combating global climate change!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our campaign!
  • Follow Carbon Roots International on Facebook and Twitter!

story:
What We Do

Reunity Resources is a Santa Fe-based non profit with a mission to reunite our waste streams with value for our community.  

We have spent nearly a year working with City government on approval for commercial food scraps collection for compost, and City Council has just approved the contract!

However, The City is not providing funding for the program.  The funding must come from YOU!

Provided we reach our campaign goal, we will begin coordinating logistics with restaurant, hotel and grocery store clients in January 2014 (only 5 weeks away!) and begin collecting their food scraps in March 2014.  

We have partnered with The City of Santa Fe Environmental Services Division to make a big impact with this program.  We will be scrupulously collecting and sharing data with the City to show the value of food scraps collection to our community and environment. As hotels, restaurants and institutions partner with us, we will be doing trash audits and closely observing how their waste streams change in order to reduce trash collection costs for local businesses and government.   

Our program is designed to divert up to 2,000,000 pounds of food scraps from the landfill in its first year of operation.  This is enough organic material to create a pile of apple cores, red chiles, moldy bread and rotten lettuce leaves as high as Mount Everest----this is a BIG DEAL!   

In landfills, food scraps are buried and we lose the opportunity to make compost, which replaces the need for chemical fertilizers, retains moisture, and provides nutrients for healthy plant growth. Furthermore, when left in landfills, this organic matter creates methane- a greenhouse gas that traps 21 times more heat than CO2.

We are taking the steps toward large scale zero waste reality.  Less than 30% of what ends up in our landfills actually belongs there. Of the 70% that does NOT belong there, at least a quarter is COMPOSTABLE.

U.S. soil is currently eroding at 17 times the rate at which it forms: We need nutrient-rich compost to rejuvenate our exhausted soils and grow healthier food!  

Let's feed the earth that feed us and help reduce global warming.

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising $143,000 to launch this community compost program.  This money will be invested in the equipment, people, and materials necessary to educate about, separate, collect and haul food scraps to the composting site.  Once operational, the program will be self-sustaining from revenues generated from fees for service. We currently work and are contracted with over 60 restaurants and hotels.  Our unique nonprofit social enterprise model, to date, has been entirely self-sustaining.

The money we raise will be allocated as follows:

Equipment and Materials: $29,431.00

5 NEW JOBS:  $98,145.00          (Interested in a Green Job? Contact us!)

Marketing:  $6,050.00

Insurances: $9,505.00

Many of us want to participate in creating sustainability for our communities but we don't know how.  This campaign is an opportunity for you to participate in an imperative zero waste initiative, for you to say YES to clean air, clean water, full-circle systems and food security.  Let your voice be heard!  Together, we can tell the world we are committed to making changes on a community level for the benefit of all.  

We can also offer you fun and practical perks to help you build your community, keep your resources out of the landfill, and help you grow your own food.  

We will share our progress with you here through update videos and notes, and we will be thrilled to share the fruitfulness of your contributions with footage of our first food scraps collection in March 2014! 

How will we reach this goal?  You.

Santa Fe is a city of approximately 70,000.  If 1,000 people can support this program with a $100 dollar contribution, we will be 70% to our goal---that's 1/70 of our municipality, less than 1.5% of our city's population.  If we can show our support in creating the kind of City we want to live in with a financial contribution, we will reach our goal in no time flat! 

Of course, we know not everyone can donate $100 dollars, and we encourage and appreciate support of all sizes.  For a $20 contribution, you can join like-minded folks for an excellent all-ages launch party on Spring Equinox, featuring local music, phenom DJ Bacon (Ben Wright), a silent auction, face painting and more.  

Additionally, we are seeking 5-10 Founders willing to make a generous contribution of $5,000 to $10,000 to make a BIG IMPACT on this program and a BIG IMPACT on their community.

We are a 501(c)3 non-profit organization, and your donation is tax-deductible. 

As an innovative public-private partnership in municipal composting, our program will provide a valuable model to other cities and organizations around the world--we encourage donations from other communities--let us test this program design and share our best practices with you for your city's success!

If you would like to make a contribution but don't particularly want to use the internet to do so, we understand.

Our mailing address is:

Reunity Resources                                                                                                              

1000 Cordova Place #650  Santa Fe, NM 87505


Other Ways You Can Help

If giving money is not your thing, we would really appreciate you sharing your voice.  Tell five friends.  Share our campaign with your network.  You can use the Indiegogo "Share" tools, or you can pass the link and video around on facebook, twitter, etc.

If you're in the Santa Fe area and would like to work with us on this project, please, get on our website or facebook page and contact us.  We want to get to know you!

Every person who hears the mission counts, and every dollar that goes to this campaign makes a zero waste community closer to reality. 

If your business is interested in participating in the program or becoming a sponsor, please contact us at (505) 629-0836.

 

A Great Big Thank You To: 

Cristina McCandless, Phil Loomis, Kim Muller, Dafyd Rawlings, Poki Piottin, Trinidad Mendez, Jaime Cobb, Rachelle Woods, Karen Connaughton, Alex, Leo, Sally, Hyder, Tania Bolle and family, Myoko, Cece, Addy and all of Leo and Hyder's friends, Cowgirl BBQ, Sam McCarthy, Awesome Harvest, Steve Dulfur, and Payne's.

The City of Santa Fe Staff, Environmental Services Division, City Council, City Commissioners, Public Utilities Division, Economic Development Department, SWMA

story:
Short Summary

Meet Antonio: an inspirational young man from an isolated rural community in El Salvador who is passionate and commited to making a difference in this world. I first met Antonio in 2009, a young man who had just had the blindfold ripped from his eyes watching Al Gore's An Inconvenient Truth. Coming through an education system that leaves most people at the equivalent of a 3rd grade level in any industrialized country, the system does little to prepare young people for the global challenges that we are now facing. In fact, most have never heard of climate change.

From the first day that I met Antonio, I promised myself that I would do everything I could to help him realise his full potential and it has been a fantastic journey for us both. Over the last three years, as Antonio has walked the path to bring about deep, sustainable change both within his life and those around me I have seen a star shine brighter and brighter.

And now - at his brightest yet - Antonio is working as a dedicated and talented young facilitator for the Youth Leaders for the Pachamama climate congresses. In a person-to-person movement that is fast gaining momentum, Antonio works at a grassroots level with young people from 15-25 years of age...helping to wake up a generation of young change-makers, igniting their passion and working together to co-create our sustainable future!

What We Need & What You Get

The Youth Leaders for the Pachamama congress is a three-day workshop that provides empowerment and leadership skills, the latest science about global challenges and innovative solutions, and skilled support to help participants develop their sustainability action plan to implement in their community.

Each congress is for a maximum of 30 people, a size which allows trust to be developed and deep bonds to be formed. The experience is a completely unique experience for every person that participates, and in more then 90% of cases it is completely life changing. 

Antonio's goal is to raise $6,500 ($6,000 + fees and commission) to support these congresses, which will provide scholarships for more than 300 youth to attend. The cost of each congress includes materials, food, transport, venue, volunteer facilitator expenses, a Youth Leaders for the Pachamama t-shirt as well as an unforgettable, life-changing experience!!

If the goal is not reached, the funds will still provide scholarships for as many youth as we raise money for.

The Impact

When you make a donation, it isn't just a one-time impact - it is far deeper. In Guatemala and El Salvador (in the world's 3rd largest biodiversity hotspot), almost 50% of the population are 18 years of age and under. That's a scary statistic when you think about how UNINFORMED and UNPREPARED these young people are to lead the way into a healthy and sustainable future. At a time when humanity faces some of its most pressing social, economic and environmental issues it is essential that we have leaders that are informed, educated and aware about these issues and empowered and inspired to creatively innovate new solutions. That's what the Youth Leaders for the Pachamama congress can do. In the short time that we have been running these congresses over 19 new youth environmental groups have started up, more then 90% of past participants are actively involved in environmental projects, and many innovative and creative new initiatives have blossomed from these inspirational young leaders. Here are a few examples:

- A demonstration house teaching about urban sustainability with workshops on nutrition, recycling, composting, urban gardening, permaculture, green technology, superfoods and MUCH more (www.elinfinito.org)

- A green and environmentally friendly shelter/safe house for children from Santa Tomás in San Salvador, providing after-hours and weekend programs to teach about living sustainably and being green!

- a clean-up-the beach campaign in El Ahumado, Guatemala!!

- a recycling rally and adopt-a-kilometer clean-up campaign in San Salvador

- an "eco-brick" building project using plastic PET bottles and trash from the streets

- a 'seed-savers' fair to reintroduce local, traditional food and preserve indigenous seeds which are fast disappearing due to the introduction of GMO crops and seeds

These are just a few examples of the innovation, creativity and passion of these youth...so help us to unlease more and see what they can come up with!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you support this project, or know people you think might be interested, please help get the word out - whether via the Facebook and Twitter buttons on this page, email or by visiting the website (www.projectseres.org) - make Antonio's first fundraiser a brilliant success!!!

story:
Hello, my name is Jocelyn Sawyer.

On May 24th, I participated in a nonviolent direct action protest against the dangerous mining practices of Alpha Natural Resources.  Along with four other activists from the RAMPS Campaign, I peacefully blockaded the road leading to Alpha's corporate headquarters in Bristol, VA, shutting down work for most of the morning.  For our action, my friends and I were sentenced to five days in jail and over $3,500 in fines and legal fees.


Why Alpha?

Alpha, formerly Massey Energy, conducts extremely destructive mountaintop removal (MTR) mining. Forests are razed; the top 400 feet or more of a mountain is literally blasted away to expose coal seams; and "rubble" that used to be the mountain's top -- laden with toxic byproducts -- is dumped into valleys, creating "valley fills" that bury and pollute streams. All this because it is a more "economical" way to mine coal, which means higher profits for coal executives.

After coal is mined, destruction continues when liquid waste ("slurry") is stored in impoundments, giant earthen dams that hold back billions of gallons of toxic sludge and are notorious for their poor construction.  One of Alpha's impoundments, the Brushy Fork slurry impoundment in Raleigh County, WV, is the largest earthen dam in the Western hemisphere -- but that hasn't stopped Alpha from plans to expand the impoundment. Soon, over 9 BILLION gallons of toxic coal sludge will be sitting over the homes of people like my friend Junior Walk (see video above).


Why I Protest

The fight against MTR is a fight for the land and people of Appalachia, for the right to clean air and water and a dignified life, and for the future of our planet. It is a fight against environmental injustice, government corruption, and corporate control.

For me, this action was about taking a stand against extreme fossil fuel extraction everywhere: From my home state of New York, here hydrofracking is an imminent threat, to the tar sands of Alberta and the mines of Black Mesa, fossil fuel extraction allows few to profit at the expense of many.

When I locked down to that road on May 24th, I wanted to target the heart of the MTR operation: those who profit from poisoning people.  We were sent to jail for our nonviolent action, but coal profiteers get off scott-free, which means that we have a lot of work to do.  But I also know that our movement is being heard, and the CEO of Alpha couldn't ignore us that morning when we kept him from getting to work.  I have no regrets.


Support Us!

On July 25, we pleaded guilty to blockading a public roadway.  We were sentenced to five days in jail and over $3,500 in fines and fees, and I have an intial fundraising goal of $1,500 for this page.

We are hoping to get this money paid off quickly, as we are on active probation until all of the fines and fees are paid.  Every little bit helps! If you have even a couple dollars to chip in, we would all be very grateful. It is the support of others like you that allows this kind of bold direct action to happen.


For More Information...

Visit the RAMPS campaign website to see press about our action:
http://rampscampaign.org/alpha-hq-shut-down-by-demonstrators-tank-of-dirty-water/
http://rampscampaign.org/4-who-blocked-alphamassey-hq-sentenced-to-jail/

Check out the iLoveMountains or Mountain Justice websites for more information about MTR mining:
http://ilovemountains.org/resources
http://mountainjustice.org/facts/steps.php

Aurora Lights has more info about the Brushy Fork impoundment:
http://auroralights.org/map_project/theme.php?theme=crm&article=2

And please feel free to contact me with any further questions.

 

Thank you so much for your support!

~ Jocelyn

Soon, over 9 BILLION gallons of toxic coal sludge will be sitting over the homes of people like my friend Junior Walk (see video above).

Why I Protest
The fight against MTR is a fight for the land and people of Appalachia, for the right to clean air and water and a dignified life, and for the future of our planet. It is a fight against environmental injustice, government corruption, and corporate control.
For me, this action was about taking a stand against extreme fossil fuel extraction everywhere: From my home state of New York, here hydrofracking is an imminent threat, to the tar sands of Alberta and the mines of Black Mesa, fossil fuel extraction allows few to profit at the expense of many.
When I locked down to that road on May 24th, I wanted to target the heart of the MTR operation: those who profit from poisoning people.  We were sent to jail for our nonviolent action, but coal profiteers get off scott-free, which means that we have a lot of work to do.  But I also know that our movement is being heard, and the CEO of Alpha couldn't ignore us that morning when we kept him from getting to work.  I have no regrets.

Support Us!
On July 25, we pleaded guilty to blockading a public roadway.  We were sentenced to five days in jail and over $3,500 in fines and fees, and I have an intial fundraising goal of $1,500 for this page.
We are hoping to get this money paid off quickly, as we are on active probation until all of the fines and fees are paid.  Every little bit helps! If you have even a couple dollars to chip in, we would all be very grateful. It is the support of others like you that allows this kind of bold direct action to happen.

For More Information...
Visit the RAMPS campaign website to see press about our action:http://rampscampaign.org/alpha-hq-shut-down-by-demonstrators-tank-of-dirty-water/http://rampscampaign.org/4-who-blocked-alphamassey-hq-sentenced-to-jail/
Check out the iLoveMountains or Mountain Justice websites for more information about MTR mining:http://ilovemountains.org/resourceshttp://mountainjustice.org/facts/steps.php
Aurora Lights has more info about the Brushy Fork impoundment:http://auroralights.org/map_project/theme.php?theme=crm&article=2
And please feel free to contact me with any further questions.
 
Thank you so much for your support!
~ Jocelyn

story:
Hamjambo tena! (“How are you again!” in Kiswahili)

First of all, thank you to everyone who supported my last indiegogo fundraiser. I raised $6,228 after deducting fees. With that money, we successfully drilled a borehole on August 8 with a yield of 3000L/hr! The new borehole will supply safe water to 300 households and directly affects the UN Millennium Development Goal (MDG) #7.c – to increase the number of people with sustainable access to safe water. It was an incredible moment, when water splashed out of the ground. I couldn't have done it without Mahugi's tireless effort in finding a driller and coordinating the project. We were also very lucky to have Mr. Ruben, the original hydrogeologist who conducted the survey, come down from Mwanza to monitor the drilling. The borehole is not the focus of my research but having heard a large village (Lyaudusi) is without clean water, I wasn’t going to turn a blind eye!

The main part of my field research here focuses on an existing piped water supply that has not been operating for months due to poor management. After diagnosing the problem through data collection and semi-structured interviews, I held a meeting with the Board members to pitch my recommendations. I stressed the need to supply water every day and introduce a new pricing system whereby villagers pay 25 Tanzanian shillings per 20L bucket. The Board agreed with all of my recommendations including ones around management, collection, and monitoring. We decided to hold a 3-day trial period to test the meters, as well as the new management and pricing system. We encountered several challenges, but the overall result was very positive and encouraging. I held another Board meeting and we agreed that after all water user groups receive training and revise their constitution, we are going to relaunch the scheme as early as this week. 

My project deliverables are to give recommendations. However, this did not seem very satisfying or fulfilling to me. I wanted to see change and a glimpse of an operational scheme while I am still here. The money collected from the fundraiser really helped me implement a lot of the recommendations I wanted to see in action. It gave me the flexibility to test out my ideas and observe its results. Unfortunately, my initial budgeting fell short of the total cost. The breakdown of the costs and shortfall is listed below. I am hoping to raise another USD $675. Again, I appreciate your help very much and I will hopefully give you an update soon!

COST TSH USD
1-month electricity  650,000  401.23
Trial period electricity  150,000  92.59
Meter servicing  40,000  24.69
Meeting room (x2)  60,000  37.04
Stationaries  80,000  49.38
Drilling  9,600,000  5,925.93
Fund transfer cost  324,000  200.00
Surveyor  200,000  123.46
Total Cost:  11,104,000 6,854.32
Raised as of Aug 9:   6,228.70
Short:   (625.62)
Short (incl. indiegogo fee):   (675.00)

 

Asante sana! (Thank you very much!)
