These videos will help homeowners understand how solar can be used in the home and how to determine if their home or property is suitable for solar.GSSVS #1:  Sunshine Daydream (Click link to see early release video.)This video covers the basics of solar energy and the ways in which we can capture solar energy for use in our homes.GSSVS #2:  Efficiency First!You can perhaps skip this one, but I’ll be pissed ; )This video will cover the basics of how you can strive to use less energy in your home through investments in energy efficient appliances and simple changes in behaviors—yes the C word—Conservation.GSSVS#3:  Is My Home Solar Friendly?Here in the third video of the Go Solar Starter Video Series we cut to the chase and help you become a solar sleuth. Specifically, you will learn how to do a quick assessment of your home and property for good solar access.GSSVS #4:  Box of SunIn the final video in the Go Solar Starter Video Series, you will learn about all of the major components of a home solar energy system that can power your home for decades to come.Go Solar Pro Video Series (GSPVS)Educational videos for those who understand solar energy basics and household energy use concepts but need additional information about the process of going solar. These videos are designed to help homeowners feel confident to engage a local, qualified solar installer.GSPVS #1:  Solar Accounting (Click link to see early release video.)Solar saves you money because you stop paying the utility and produce your own power—what a Deal! In the solar biz they call the process of accounting for the electricity you produce with solar versus what you consume in your home as net metering.GSPVS #2:  Plug Your Home into the SunThis video will cover the process of connecting a home solar energy system to the power grid through your home electric meter. In the solar biz they call this interconnection. GSPVS #3:  How Many Solar Panels Would I Need?In this video, the Go Solar Coach will walk you through the process of determining how many solar panels you will most likely need for your roof or ground mounted home PV system to meet your household electricity needs.GSPVS #4:  Selecting a Qualified Installer & Financing Your Solar SystemSelecting a quality solar installer and finding the best way to finance your new investment are always BIG concerns, again the Go Solar Coach to the rescue! In this video we will cover how to select a qualified installer and all the different ways to pay for solar from crowd source funding, bank financing, to leasing.How You Can HelpFinancial contributions to the campaign will entitle you to free Go Solar Coach branded merchandise and advanced access to the educational videos.Sticker 2.5" x 4"Drink KoozieTie Dyed T-ShirtOther support is welcome, including marketing advice and support, and promoting the campaign to your networks. Be part of the Solar Revolution, spread the word about this Go Solar Coach campaign...I would be Grateful!
Share it on Facebook 
Email it to five friends
THANK YOU!The Go Solar Coach believes in paying it forward and will donate 5% of all proceeds from this campaign to the Solar Electric Light Fund, a non-profit dedicated to designing and implementing solar energy solutions to assist the 1.5 billion people living in energy poverty with their economic, educational, health care and agricultural development.

story:
Short Summary

All donations will be managed responsibility by a Company called Green Connexion. www.greenconnexion.co.za

On a surf trip to Sumatra, Indonesia, a group of environmentally conscious businessmen from the landscape, horticultural and green industry came across the most disturbing scene.

It was the tropical paradise as we imagined - the most beautiful beaches, amazing waves and friendly local people. But what we did not expect was mountains of plastic waste on those beaches, discarded fishing nets and rubbish in those waves, and sadly a sense of helplessness amongst the locals. 

After spending some time there and realising the far-reaching impact this plastic waste is having, as well as the complete lack of infrastructure to deal with it, we decided it is time to clean up the beaches of the Indian Ocean, starting with Sumatra!

Our plan is to start on the ground - collect all the plastic and rubbish off the beaches from Bali Village in the South all the way to Jimmys Left in the North. The clean up will include the collection of rubbish off the beaches of all the famous surf spots including:

·  Bali Village

·  Way Jambu

·  Ucur Bocur

·  Mandiri beach

·  The Peak

·  Krui Left and Right

·  Jennys Right

·  Jimmys Left and Right

The campaign will include the clean up of all the beaches through the employment and empowerment of local Indonesian communities to collect all the existing rubbish. The rubbish will then be separated into items that can be recycled and used in any way possible such as the manufacturing of polytimber and the reuse of bottles ext.

The next part of the plan will be to install rubbish bins and signage in all the settlements and villages in conjunction with an education campaign teaching the local communities about the destruction plastic rubbish has on our ocean and tourism of Sumatra.

The next mission is to identify a landfill site for all the rubbish and the logistics in collecting the rubbish from the bins to the delivery and control off all the un-recyclable rubbish.

Identify a land fill site, create an polytimber manufacturing facility and engage with local government with an environmental plan and establish environmental policies for the island of Sumatra.


What We Need & What You Get

We have identified the flowing deliverable and activities to make this project a success:

·  Salaries of the local people  $ 144 000.00

·  Installation of bins at all the surf spots and villages  $ 25 000.00

·  Identification and purchase of land for a landfill site  $ 25 000.00 

·  Trucks to collect the rubbish  $ 100 00.00

·  Petrol and salaries of the truck drivers   $ 40 000.00

·  An education campaign  $ 20 000.00

·  Proclamation of the famous waves and beaches  $ 30 000.00

·  Establishment of polytimber manufacturing facility  $ 50 000.00

·  Consulting with local government to ensure sustainability   $ 10 000.00

·  Professional administration and consulting of donated funds  $ 36 900.00

Total:  $ 480 900.00

We are calling out to all the environmentally conscious people living on our beautiful earth to donate a little something to our cause and hopefully one day you can travel and enjoy perfect waves, friendly people and clean beaches.

Enjoy your next trip and we hope you find the perfect clean barrel!


The Impact

Clean the beaches of the Indian Ocean islands, starting with Sumatra

Remove the environmentally hazardous plastic waste from the fragile marine ecosystem

Ensure the sustainability of these beautiful travel locations as tourist destinations

Jobs for poor communities

Risks & Challenges

Uneducated communities and people

Lack of existing infrastructure

Other Ways You Can Help

Share and spread the word......Enjoy your next wave.

story:
Who are we?

A decade ago we set out to start a chimera, because the consequences of waste and carelessness, despite the reality exposed globally in Kyoto.

The large number of studies, forums, promises of change, deterioration, poisoning and destruction of our home, the earth, is every day increasing: we continue destroying our forests, polluting and destroying our water and soil.

 In order to stop these problems a group of professionals decide to form a team, each one gave the individual experience, the result was the Agrotropical Net and technical package, we call Agrotropical Technology a real solution, sustainable and profitable in order to regain and maintain the productive soil, grow food productions in order to obtain two or three times the production in a third part of the land used with traditional techniques.
It is applicable in the total tropical countries: more than a hundred.

We ask your help to produce commercial levels of the Agrotropical Net making it affordable for the vast majority of agricultural producers, especially the smaller ones they are the most needed from such help.

We need your help too in order to cost the protection results of our research, and to found the culture school of our technology and spread these knowledge to other regions and countries.

Many thanks for your help.

 

Exploitation and Air Management

The air is used, not only as mean of obtaining of CO2 for the plant, but
as water resource and transportation mechanism of species that enrich the
natural environment.

Continuous Biological Activity

(Process of the living organisms)

So, instead of “Cycles”, a dynamic balance is produced, in other words,
everything is developed continually.

A HABITAT is developed.

In the Tropics, the radiation is more intense, which inhibits the growing of the plants, the hothouse doesn’t filter it. The plants are 80% water, 17% carbonic gas and 3% other 14 elements, therefor, plants take CO2 of the air, which has only 0.03%, when limiting its flow in the hothouse, the plant is at risk. They grow very well in the hothouse, but are weak nutritionally.

The plastic color and the changes that present with the usage, affect the plants, directly.


Benefits for the people

By filtering out ultraviolet radiation up to 40%, protects skin cells directly
exposed to the sun, eliminating the effect of "sunburn"  making it more comfortable and healthy work environment and the summer vacations too.


Every images and explanations that we have presented are the result of research and work on more than 40 crops in all climatic zones, from cool to warm.

Our team:

 

Regards and gratitudes.

story:
Conversation Earth:  Real Reality TV for the Conscientious Audience!

CAN WE MAKE IT TO $25,000????

A very special thanks to the 70+ supporters who helped us reach our basic goal.

Two supporters have approached us with a new challenge. They understand the show’s first season budget is much higher than what we’ve raised, so they want us to stretch to $25,000! With two weeks left in the campaign, here is what they are prepared to do. On the day we hit $20,000 supporter #1 will send us a check for another $5,000. If we make it to $25,000 here before midnight on Halloween, supporter #2 will also mail a $5,000 check. That would put us at $35,000 total, covering over half the first season budget.
              If you share our vision, please keep the love coming!  Thank you.

Conversation Earth will be a television series featuring interviews with the world’s most forward-thinking visionaries about life on Earth. This is a welcome chance to dig deep and seek understanding of what lies ahead and why we’re headed there. The discussions will challenge our thinking, and in some cases turn our world upside down!

We’re asking your help to fund editing the first episodes, getting distribution in place, and publicizing the series.  Donations are tax-deductible in the U.S.


ABOUT THE TV SERIES

Conversation Earth provides surprising, apolitical perspectives on the most important issues of our time: 

  • How does humankind relate to our home planet?
  • What does our future look like?
  • What are the important decisions we face?
  • How will they impact our lives and the lives of our children?
  • Why do we make the choices we make?

This is an interview-based, documentary-style television series to be aired on networks around the world and the Internet.  Each episode will examine the decisions humankind is currently making, how those choices are affecting the quality of our lives, the livability of our cities, the health of our environment, and future prospects for our children.  The questions posed address the way society views progress and success.  

CONVERSATIONS WILL EXPLORE:

·  Living a Satisfying Life                                        ·  Sustainability

·  Cultural Operating Systems                                ·  Defining a Healthy Economy

·  Limits to Growth                                                  ·  Crowd Behavior

·  Population Growth                                              ·  Common Worldviews

·  Cultural Programming                                         ·  Rights of Nature

·  Irrational Behavior                                               ·  How We Became Consumers

Many interviews explore whether or not we are in need of a paradigm change. Some interviews look at alternative models of success that don’t rely on perpetual growth in the size of economies or populations. Topics include community development, conservation, education, happiness, psychology, human (especially women’s) rights, migration, messaging in the media, and public policy. 

For our groundbreaking 2011 documentary, GrowthBusters: Hooked on Growth, we interviewed dozens of the brightest scientists, economists, educators, authors, and social critics about various aspects of how we are interacting with the earth.  They offered insightful and unprecedented perspectives on issues that determine why our civilization is unsustainable and how we might get on a better path. 

A FEW OF THE MANY INTERVIEWS ALREADY FILMED:

Al Bartlett, Professor Emeritus of Physics, University of Colorado; Author, Laws Relating to Sustainability

Herman Daly, former World Bank senior economist; father of ecological economics

Paul Ehrlich, Biologist; Professor of Population Studies, Stanford University; Author, The Population Bomb

Katie Elmore Mota, Vice President of Population Media Center

Lisa Hymas, Senior Editor, Grist

Bill McKibben, 350.org founder; Author, Deep Economy and The End of Nature

Stephanie Mills, gained instant fame when she announced in her 1969 college graduation speech that she would not be conceiving children, to do her part in stopping population growth

Raj Patel, Fellow, Institute for Food and Development Policy; Author, The Value of Nothing and Stuffed and Starving

Bill Ryerson, President, Population Institute and Population Media Center

Sarah Susanka, Author, The Not So Big Life

Rex Weyler, Co-Founder, Greenpeace International


WHERE YOU COME IN…

It isn’t easy to sell a thoughtful tv show so we have to make this pop!  We need your help for the following to ensure this is a successful series…

  • Editing
  • Publicity
  • Additional interviews/footage
  • Web design

Producing the entire first season of the series will require more than $15,000. We can supplement our Indiegogo proceeds by applying for foundation grants, but that will slow us down. Please help us exceed this fundraising goal so we can stop raising money and get to work producing the show!

And for helping us bring this to life, here are a few peeks at the perks!

GROWTHBUSTERS BUMPER STICKER!

ENDANGERED SPECIES CONDOMS FROM THE CENTER FOR BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY!

GROWTHBUSTERS FILM CREW T-SHIRT!

GROWTHBUSTERS: HOOKED ON GROWTH DVD!

FIRST EDITION COPY OF THE POPULATION BOMB AUTOGRAPHED BY PAUL EHRLICH!


GROWTHBUSTERS POSTER FEATURING AND AUTOGRAPHED BY THE LATE PROF. AL BARTLETT!

And there are many more exciting perks!

If you’d like to donate but aren’t into online or credit card transactions, you can mail a check to Citizen-Powered Media, 2930 Orion Drive, Colorado Springs, CO  80906, put Indiegogo or Conversation Earth in the memo line and we’ll add your contribution to the campaign.

In case you aren’t convinced yet, here is why Conversation Earth is SO important.

The topics of these episodes impact everyone.  Because the questions posed address the root of our social and environmental challenges, there isn’t an issue that is left out of the conversation.  But they will be especially engaging for the generations that hold the future of the planet in their hands.  Once these issues are in the public consciousness and better understood, there will be growing support for the social and policy changes necessary to maintain a sustainable equilibrium on the planet.  Just read what others are saying about the project...

"Dave Gardner has sought out some of the brightest thinkers on the planet for the Conversation Earth interview series. I respect and support his work and heartily recommend you do the same!"

~ Bill Ryerson, Chairman & CEO, Population Institute; President, Population Media Center


"Industrial society is hurtling in a direction enormously different than we expected. The unique constellation of savants presented in Conversation Earth helps us understand the forces propelling us there. It is a timely and important set of discussions." 

~ Dennis Meadows, co-author, The Limits to Growth


"Conversation Earth is about the most serious problem facing humanity -- how to keep our insane addiction to growth from causing a collapse of civilization.  Every human being should be exposed to this series.”

~ Paul R. Ehrlich, Bing Professor of Population Studies & President, Center for Conservation Biology, Stanford University; Author, The Population Bomb


"Our society's obsession with GDP growth is at the root of our most challenging crises. GDP growth simply doesn't deliver good results--not even jobs. Please support GrowthBusters in their efforts to find the cure for growth addiction."

~ James Gustave Speth, Administrator, United Nations Development Programme 1993-1999; Environmental Advisor to U.S. President Jimmy Carter 1977-1981; Co-founder, Natural Resources Defense Council; Founder/President, World Resources Institute  1982-1993; Author, America the Possible: Manifesto for a New Economy


"'Growth as usual' has become a pathway to environmental and economic destruction, not human fulfillment.  Someone or something has to change the human growth paradigm before it is too late, and GrowthBusters is a bold attempt to do just that."

~ Robert Walker, President, Population Institute 


"I think your campaign to wake people up to madness of perpetual growth is vitally important."

~ Chris Palmer, Director, Center for Environmental Filmmaking, American University School of Communication; President, One World One Ocean Foundation; Author, Shooting in the Wild


"Growthbusters has the courage to take on two of the most controversial topics in America today, our country's economic system and human overpopulation, and put it on television???? Wow! I am sending Dave Gardner a bullet proof vest right now. Bravo!"  

~ Alexandra Paul, Film & Television Actress; Host of Wild Waters, Winning Women and Earth Talk Today 


"On a finite planet you simply cannot have constant growth of either the economy or human population. Support GrowthBusters in their work!"

~ Jenny Goldie, President, Sustainable Population Australia


"The GrowthBusters project is addressing the most critical challenge facing our civilization – becoming truly sustainable. Please support the work they are doing."

~ Simon Ross, CEO of Population Matters


"GrowthBusters addresses the most dangerous addiction afflicting our society - growth addiction. I wish every success for this project and encourage you to support this important work."

~ Samuel Alexander, author of Entropia: Life Beyond Industrial Civilisation, co-founder of The Simplicity Collective


"GrowthBusters addresses the most dangerous addiction afflicting our society - growth addiction. I wish every success for this project and encourage you to support this important work." 

~ Kieran Suckling, Executive Director, Center for Biological Diversity


"The GrowthBusters project is addressing the most critical challenge facing our civilization – becoming truly sustainable. Please support the work they are doing." 

~Richard D. Lamm, Colorado Governor 1975-1987; Co-Director, Institute for Public Policy Studies, University of Denver


Want to see a longer preview of the TV Series?



If you want to contribute but can’t or if you want to do more than just donate…

Other ways to help:

Share this campaign with your friends, family, and networks!  This is the most important thing anyone can do for this campaign and this movement.

Like the GrowthBusters Facebook page and subscribe to our newsletter to stay up-to-date with the campaign, tv series developments, related growthbusting issues, and our other projects.


OUR OTHER INITIATIVES:

Growth Bias Busted is a media watchdog website that shines a spotlight on the growth bias in modern journalism.  Everyday we post a news article from a major publication that illustrates this very bias or breaks the mold.  Check it out and join the conversation at www.growthbiasbusted.org

GrowthBusters YouTube Channel: As time and budget permit, we publish engaging videos related to achieving sustainable balance and redefining the good life. Check out our videos and subscribe to the channel here.

How to Save the Planet (And Reclaim the Good Life) (working title) is our first book project. It’s an anthology of sustainability related articles and essays from the world’s leading scholars, economists, environmentalists, and scientists.  This incredible collection of writings will be available for purchase in 2014 so stay tuned.

GrowthBusters: Hooked on Growth is our 2011 documentary that highlights Dave’s mission to show and combat our obsession with economic and population growth.  The film is still being shown in screenings and festivals.  It is available for purchase or online rental at www.growthbusters.org.  Once we have the time/money stay tuned for the sequel!


Who we are, why we do this, and why you’re wonderful for being a part of it:

DAVE GARDNER

In my 35-year directing career, I have produced and directed a PBS series and award-winning films for over a dozen Fortune 500 companies, including several airlines, Coca-Cola, IBM, and even Enron. I perfected the art of spin as I helped the biggest public relations firms do reputation management and damage control for oil and chemical companies.

But in 2001 I woke up and began focusing my camera on our modern society and what drives us to worship everlasting growth, even in the face of overwhelming evidence we’ve hit the limits to growth. My first documentary on the subject, GrowthBusters: Hooked on Growth, premiered to a standing-room-only audience in Washington DC in 2011.

I founded the non-profit, Citizen-Powered Media, in 2006 to produce the GrowthBusters documentary, which has now grown into an ongoing movement to bring attention to our society’s misplaced notions of progress and success.

I live next to the Rocky Mountains in Colorado Springs, Colorado, where several days a week I get to step out the front door and hike to take a break from saving the planet. I speak regularly about growth addiction to groups and on television and radio.

I'm truly blessed to have your help so that I might make a difference in this world, a difference that will give all the children of the world a shot at living a good life!


LYNSEY TAMSEN JONES

I am a California based filmmaker temporarily lost in Austin, TX.  I studied Cinema and Documentary Studies under Bill Nichols at San Francisco State University before working on features, commercials, television, and documentary films.  I have 8 years experience in the industry and have worked on projects around the world.  When I’m not working you can find me hiking, kayaking, practicing yoga, riding my bicycle, and painstakingly attempting to teach myself how to tend a healthy vegetable garden in the Texas heat.

My niche was found early on when I discovered that art and environmentalism could have a symbiotic relationship in nonfiction film.  So I joined the GrowthBusters team in 2010 to work toward this exact end.  After working in and seeing the power of television first hand, I am is thrilled to be working on Conversation Earth, and I truly believe this is the best way to reach people who want to do better by themselves and the planet.

I really appreciate your support on this project and truly believe that being a part of this means being a part of an essential social, environmental, and philosophical paradigm change.

THANK YOU!

of Nothing and Stuffed
and Starving
Bill Ryerson,
President,
Population Institute and Population Media Center
Sarah Susanka,
Author, The Not So Big Life
Rex Weyler,
Co-Founder, Greenpeace International

WHERE YOU COME IN…
It isn’t easy
to sell a thoughtful tv show so we have to make this pop!  We need your help for the following to ensure
this is a successful series… 


Editing
Publicity
Additional interviews/footage
Web design





Producing the entire first season
of the series will require more than $15,000. We can supplement our Indiegogo
proceeds by applying for foundation grants, but that will slow us down. Please
help us exceed this fundraising goal so we can stop raising money and get to
work producing the show!

And for helping us bring this to life, here are a few
peeks at the perks!
GROWTHBUSTERS BUMPER STICKER!


ENDANGERED SPECIES CONDOMS FROM THE CENTER FOR BIOLOGICAL DIVERSITY!



GROWTHBUSTERS FILM CREW T-SHIRT!



GROWTHBUSTERS: HOOKED ON GROWTH DVD!



FIRST EDITION COPY OF THE POPULATION BOMB AUTOGRAPHED BY PAUL EHRLICH!





GROWTHBUSTERS POSTER FEATURING AND AUTOGRAPHED BY THE LATE PROF. AL BARTLETT!




And there are many more exciting perks!
If you’d like to donate but aren’t
into online or credit card transactions, you can mail a check to
Citizen-Powered Media, 2930 Orion Drive, Colorado Springs, CO  80906, put Indiegogo or Conversation Earth in
the memo line and we’ll add your contribution to the campaign. 
In case you aren’t convinced yet, here is why
Conversation Earth is SO important.

The topics of these episodes impact everyone.  Because the questions posed address the root
of our social and environmental challenges, there isn’t an issue that is left
out of the conversation.  But they will
be especially engaging for the generations that hold the future of the planet
in their hands.  Once these issues are in
the public consciousness and better understood, there will be growing support
for the social and policy changes necessary to maintain a sustainable
equilibrium on the planet.  Just read what others are saying about the project...

"Dave Gardner has sought out some of the brightest thinkers on the planet for the Conversation Earth interview series. I respect and support his work and heartily recommend you do the same!"
~ Bill Ryerson, Chairman & CEO, Population Institute; President, Population Media Center

"Industrial society is hurtling in a direction enormously different than we expected. The unique constellation of savants presented in Conversation Earth helps us understand the forces propelling us there. It is a timely and important set of discussions." 
~ Dennis Meadows, co-author, The Limits to Growth


"Conversation Earth is about the most serious problem
facing humanity -- how to keep our insane addiction to growth from causing a
collapse of civilization.  Every human being should be exposed to this
series.”
~ Paul R. Ehrlich, Bing Professor of Population Studies & President, Center
for Conservation Biology, Stanford University; Author, The Population
Bomb


"Our society's obsession with GDP growth is at the root of our most challenging crises. GDP growth simply doesn't deliver good results--not even jobs. Please support GrowthBusters in their efforts to find the cure for growth addiction."
~ James Gustave Speth, Administrator, United Nations Development Programme 1993-1999; Environmental Advisor to U.S. President Jimmy Carter 1977-1981; Co-founder, Natural Resources Defense Council; Founder/President, World Resources Institute  1982-1993; Author, America the Possible: Manifesto for a New Economy

"'Growth as usual' has become a pathway to environmental and
economic destruction, not human fulfillment.  Someone or something has to
change the human growth paradigm before it is too late, and GrowthBusters is a
bold attempt to do just that."
~ Robert Walker, President, Population Institute 



"I think your campaign to wake people up to madness of
perpetual growth is vitally important." 
~ Chris Palmer, Director, Center for Environmental Filmmaking, American University School of Communication; President, One World One Ocean Foundation; Author, Shooting
in the Wild



"Growthbusters has the courage to take on two of the most
controversial topics in America today, our country's economic system and human
overpopulation, and put it on television???? Wow! I am sending Dave Gardner a
bullet proof vest right now. Bravo!"  
~ Alexandra Paul, Film & Television Actress; Host of Wild Waters, Winning Women and Earth
Talk Today 



"On a finite planet you simply cannot have constant
growth of either the economy or human population. Support GrowthBusters in
their work!"
~ Jenny Goldie, President, Sustainable Population Australia

"The GrowthBusters project is addressing the
most critical challenge facing our civilization – becoming truly sustainable.
Please support the work they are doing."
~ Simon Ross, CEO of Population Matters

"GrowthBusters addresses the most dangerous
addiction afflicting our society - growth addiction. I wish every success for
this project and encourage you to support this important work." 
~ Samuel Alexander, author of Entropia: Life
Beyond Industrial Civilisation, co-founder of The Simplicity Collective





"GrowthBusters addresses the most dangerous addiction
afflicting our society - growth addiction. I wish every success for this project
and encourage you to support this important work."  
~ Kieran Suckling, Executive Director, Center for Biological
Diversity



"The GrowthBusters project is addressing the most critical challenge facing our civilization – becoming truly sustainable. Please support the work they are doing." 
~Richard D. Lamm, Colorado Governor 1975-1987; Co-Director, Institute for Public Policy Studies, University of Denver

Want to see a longer preview of the TV Series?



If you want
to contribute but can’t or if you want to do more than just donate…
Other ways to help:
Share this campaign with your
friends, family, and networks!  This is
the most important thing anyone can do for this campaign and this movement.
Like the GrowthBusters Facebook page and subscribe to our newsletter to stay up-to-date with the
campaign, tv series developments, related growthbusting issues, and our other
projects.


OUR OTHER INITIATIVES:
Growth Bias Busted is a media watchdog website that shines a spotlight on the growth bias
in modern journalism.  Everyday we post a
news article from a major publication that illustrates this very bias or breaks
the mold.  Check it out and join the
conversation at www.growthbiasbusted.org
GrowthBusters YouTube Channel: As time and budget permit, we
publish engaging videos related to achieving sustainable balance and redefining
the good life. Check out our videos and subscribe to the channel here.

How to Save the Planet (And Reclaim the Good Life) (working title) is our first book project. It’s an
anthology of sustainability related articles and essays from the world’s
leading scholars, economists, environmentalists, and scientists.  This incredible collection of writings will
be available for purchase in 2014 so stay tuned.
GrowthBusters: Hooked on Growth is our 2011 documentary that highlights Dave’s
mission to show and combat our obsession with economic and population
growth.  The film is still being shown in
screenings and festivals.  It is
available for purchase or online rental at www.growthbusters.org.  Once we have
the time/money stay tuned for the sequel!

Who we are, why we do this, and why you’re wonderful
for being a part of it:

DAVE GARDNER

In
my 35-year directing career, I have produced and directed a PBS series and
award-winning films for over a dozen Fortune 500 companies, including several
airlines, Coca-Cola, IBM, and even Enron. I perfected the art of spin as I
helped the biggest public relations firms do reputation management and damage
control for oil and chemical companies.
But
in 2001 I woke up and began focusing my camera on our modern society and what
drives us to worship everlasting growth, even in the face of overwhelming
evidence we’ve hit the limits to growth. My first documentary on the subject, GrowthBusters: Hooked on Growth,
premiered to a standing-room-only audience in Washington DC in 2011.
I
founded the non-profit, Citizen-Powered Media, in 2006 to produce the GrowthBusters documentary, which has now
grown into an ongoing movement to bring attention to our society’s misplaced
notions of progress and success. 
I
live next to the Rocky Mountains in Colorado Springs, Colorado, where several
days a week I get to step out the front door and hike to take a break from
saving the planet. I speak regularly about growth addiction to groups and on
television and radio. 
I'm truly blessed to have your help so that I might make a difference in this world, a difference that will give all the children of the world a shot at living a good life!

LYNSEY TAMSEN JONES

I am a California based
filmmaker temporarily lost in Austin, TX. 
I studied Cinema and Documentary Studies under Bill Nichols at San
Francisco State University before working on features, commercials, television,
and documentary films.  I have 8 years experience
in the industry and have worked on projects around the world.  When I’m not working you can find me hiking,
kayaking, practicing yoga, riding my bicycle, and painstakingly attempting to
teach myself how to tend a healthy vegetable garden in the Texas heat.
My niche was found early on when
I discovered that art and environmentalism could have a symbiotic relationship
in nonfiction film.  So I joined the GrowthBusters
team in 2010 to work toward this exact end. 
After working in and seeing the power of television first hand, I am is
thrilled to be working on Conversation
Earth, and I truly believe this is the best way to reach people who want to
do better by themselves and the planet.
I really appreciate your support on this project and truly believe that being a part of this means being a part of an essential social, environmental, and philosophical paradigm change.
THANK YOU!

story:
Thank you for visiting my project fundraising page. As you know, I have always been interested in the environment and equally wanted to visit Machu Picchu. 

I've finally taken the plunge (bucket list!) and have enrolled as a volunteer for Crees, a charity in Peru who are working to maintain a sustainable future for the inhabitants and wildlife of the Manu Biosphere Reserve in the Amazon Rainforest.
I will be working as part of a team on a range of projects such as the Blue Headed Macaw Project, Forest Regeneration and creating Biogardens for the local people to combat malnutrition. 
I am funding the trip myself, however Crees ask that volunteers raise a minimum of £1000 towards the projects by August. I will leaving in October for a month. 
If you would like to contribute to the charity, I would be very grateful for your support. This has been a lifetime goal of mine and to achieve it would be amazing. 
Ken

story:
UPDATE: We received a matching donation of $5,000 from Karen and Phil Drayer. That means for every two books bought, they'll donate one more to children in need! With their energy behind us, let's finish strong! 

Campaign Overview

Not only is the Salish Sea extraordinarily beautiful, but it also plays a vital role in our economy and our way of life. Increasingly, the sea and its surrounding watersheds are challenged by an ever-growing list of threats. As with any difficult issue, the more we understand and care about the problem, the more likely we are solve it.

To inspire today's youth and tomorrow’s leaders to connect with and protect our unique inland sea, SeaDoc and Little Big Foot publishing are releasing Explore the Salish Sea: A Nature Guide for Kids. It inspires outdoor exploration, ownership of this place, and action to take care of it. Through this IndieGoGo campaign, we intend to share this important new book in schools, outdoor camps and libraries with every 5th and 6th grade student regardless of their ability to pay.

Low-income families are disproportionately affected by environmental degradation. There are about 81,000 5th graders in Washington State, and 43 percent are low-income. More than half live in counties next to Puget Sound, meaning there are more than 20,000 low-income 5th graders in Washington to whom we'd like to provide books annually. 

The SeaDoc Society is based on Orcas Island in the Salish Sea and is a program of the UC Davis Karen C. Drayer Wildlife Health Center.

Short Summary

The SeaDoc Society protects the health of marine wildlife and their ecosystems through science and education. Science Director Dr. Joe Gaydos and Board Member Audrey Benedict wrote Explore the Salish Sea: A Nature Guide for Kids to engage 5th and 6th grade students so that they may connect with and protect the Salish Sea. Featuring close to 100 incredible photographs and compelling stories, the book is aligned with Washington State core science learning standards.

This IndieGoGo campaign lets you give the gift of knowledge, passion and ownership of place to students. (You can buy a  book for a student who otherwise couldn't afford it, books for a whole class or even books for a whole district!). You'll be inspiring tomorrow's ocean conservation leaders and helping protect the Salish Sea for generations to come!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support the campaign today, consider sharing it with friends and family who care about protecting the Salish Sea. Send an email, make a phone call or share on social media. 

You can also subscribe to the SeaDoc Society’s newsletter to follow our work and learn about the Sea. When the book is released on April 17, visit a local bookstore and consider buying a copy! 

About the book

The SeaDoc Society has published a book for the next generation. Filled with beautiful photography and engaging stories, Explore the Salish Sea: A Nature Guide for Kids inspires children to explore the unique marine ecosystem that encompasses the coastal waters from Seattle’s Puget Sound up to the Strait of Juan de Fuca and the Georgia Strait of British Columbia.

Discover the Salish Sea and learn about its vibrant ecosystem in this engaging non-fiction narrative that inspires outdoor exploration. Filled with full-color photography, this book covers wildlife habitats, geodiversity, intertidal and subtidal sea life, and highlights what is unique to this Pacific Northwest ecosystem.

JOSEPH K. GAYDOS is chief scientist for the SeaDoc Society, a marine science and conservation program focused on the Salish Sea. He is a licensed wildlife veterinarian and has a PhD in wildlife health. For over a decade he has been studying the fish and wildlife of the Salish Sea.

AUDREY DELELLA BENEDICT is a biologist, writer, and passionate advocate for the conservation of the global ocean and Arctic and alpine environments the world over. She is founder and director of Cloud Ridge Naturalists, a nonprofit natural history educational organization now in its fourth decade. She is currently a member of the board of the SeaDoc Society and served for nearly a decade as a trustee for the Colorado chapter of The Nature Conservancy, from which she received the prestigious One Conservancy Award in 2003 for her work in Ecuador. Audrey splits her time between her home at 9,000 feet along the Colorado Front Range and her off-grid cottage on San Juan’s Frost Island.

story:
Who We Are


In Our Nature (InOurNatureMag.com)  is a student-run publication founded at Northwestern University in November 2014. It was started by three students, who at the time were all sophomores majoring in journalism. They all had a passion for environmental issues and wanted to hone their journalistic skills by reporting on the subject that they felt most passionate about. However, despite attending an institution that boasts having one of the best journalism programs in the country, there was no outlet that focused primarily on environmental issues. In Our Nature was thus created to fill this need, both in order to give writers an outlet, as well as serving as a source for readers. Since then, the publication has grown to a 7-person editorial board with a staff of about 20 contributors. In Our Nature has consistently been publishing content 3-5 times every week and has gained access to events such as the Chicago Green Fest, the Dalai Lama's birthday celebration, and more.

The online publication aims to engage and entertain readers with all aspects of the environment, nature and sustainability. Our goal is to make environmental topics more accessible to the general public. Our coverage ranges from news about events in Evanston/Chicago and worldy news, to fun features about animals, to opinion pieces that allow contributors to voice their opinion and spark social action.

Why We Need Your Help

Because In Our Nature is student-run, we do not yet have a strong financial base. Thus, most of the funds to sustain our publication have come out of the pockets of the editors and staff members. Our editorial board and staff are all college students, so we want to make sure our contributors aren't forced to make financial sacrifices in order to participate in our publication.

Here is what we need funds for:

  • web-hosting services to keep our website up and running
  • domain name licensing
  • subsidies for writers to cover events (transportation, admission costs, etc.)
  • promotional materials to spread the word and thus engage more readers about environmental issues (stickers, business cards, printing flyers, social media advertisements, etc.)

The Impact

Environmental issues are a threat to the health of the planet and its inhabitants in the coming years. Our goal as a publication is to engage college-aged readers to realize the importance of these topics and to do their part to engage with the issues at hand and combat climate change. We want to make spark the interest of people who are not "typical environmentalists" and engage the average person in issues relating to the environment. By supporting In Our Nature, you'll be helping accomplish our goal of engaging people in environmental conservation and sustainability.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate monetarily, you can still help us accomplish our mission! Here's how:

  • Like us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram and invite your friends to like our page.
  • Share our campaign and encourage those in your networks to donate!
  • Write something for us! If you like to summarize research articles, have opinions you want to share, or have a cool experience you want to blog about, or anything else you'd like to see published, email us your submission at InOurNatureMag@gmail.com

story:
Overview

We are a group of University of Tennessee Students supporting Ijams Nature Center, the only nonprofit nature center in the Greater Knoxville area. We all love the outdoors and know how important it has been during COVID-19. We recognize the importance of protecting and preserving the natural world around us.

Who we are

We are Charlie Akin, Alex Anderson, Garrett Lopes, Jacob Kane, and Alex Stratton, and we are  students at the University of Tennessee. We are supporting the only nature center in Knoxville, Ijams Nature Center. We all love the outdoors and know how important it has been during Covid-19. We recognize the importance of the nature surrounding us.

Why Ijams

Ijams Nature Center is a nonprofit organization in Knoxville, Tennessee, founded in 1975. It features more than 315 acres of green space with 12+ miles for hiking and mountain biking, paddling, climbing, swimming and more. We are all avid nature lovers and love supporting local, so Ijams is the perfect non profit for us.

 

You can help with this important work. Your donation will allow Ijams to add four weed wrenches to its invasive plant removal arsenal. Non-native, invasive species choke out the native plants, which are crucial to biodiversity and local wildlife.

 

These tools are not cheap and that is why we need your help. Weed wrenches are critical tools that allow woody invasive, nonnative plants to be removed by the root. With your help, Ijams can better restore and preserve East Tennessee’s native habitats.

 

With your donation you will be able to choose from one of our many perks: a pint glass, stickers, or a shout-out on our Instagram! 

Risks & Challenges

One challenge we face is that people are often more likely to donate to causes perceived as having higher social importance, such as feeding the hungry or helping the homeless. However, all of us rely on the planet for survival, and Ijams’ mission to inspire people to protect the natural world through education and engaging outdoor experiences.  

Another possible risk is the possibility of not reaching the goal from donations. Indiegogo could refund donations, which would result in the group not being able raise funds for Ijams or fulfill perks for donating.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Tell your friends to share and donaten to the campaign. If you have any more questions about Ijams Nature Center...

 

Visit Ijams nature centers website here (https://www.ijams.org/) 

 

Ijams Facebook here (https://www.facebook.com/ijamsnaturecenter/) 

 

Any questions about the campaign?

Email Charlie Akin- dakin1@vols.utk.edu

story:
Film Biz is doing everything it can to help us overcome our bad consumer habits and give back to our community at the same time. They are a group to be admired and supported! Film Biz fosters the creative talents of all those trying to pave their way into the film industry by making independent filmmaking so much more sustainable and affordable. They deserve all the support we can give.

Annie Ford, Props Master

 

We need the help of our industry to do what we do.

Over 40% of the props, wardrobe and set dressing we receive goes right out to local charities, arts programs, worthy causes and, now, emergency response. 

75% of our overhead is earned income from the prop shop - an incredibly high percentage for your average non-profit.  However, to get to 100% of operations costs we have to fundraise every year and we appeal to YOU.  

Many employee hours and lots of our rented space is dedicated to serving our neighborhood via processing, preparing and deliveies - all drain out resources, but we would not do it any other way.

 

We do more than give to charity.  In 2012...

  • Received donations from 642 productions and diverted 123 tons from the waste stream
  • Hosted eco classes & workshops, Reuse birthday parties, environmental training seminar Green Vendor Expo curated and produced by Film Biz Recycling and many other Gowanus community events.
  • Hired a full-time upcycler in the Upcycle GALA-RE
  • Provided space for City Council Member Brad Lander's participatory budget training.
  • FBR presented ISES NYC Sustainability Summit, Eco-Focus Press Event, ABC/Disney Earth Day Event and Grow NYC

 

When Sandy hit, we were able to be first responders, just by doing what we do everyday.

By virtue of what we do everyday, we were well prepared as first responders to alleviate Sandy’s impact; our unique position to help its victims underscores our importance to our community and the necessary role we play as a vital link between the film industry and charitable institutions.  

  • Halloween was practically cancelled, so the FBR staff threw a "Cabin Fever Arts'" party for disappointed neighborhood kids.
  • We were a hub for Sandy donations, volunteer meeting space and information.
  • We donated over $9,000 of inventory to relief efforts.
  • We housed two Gowanus businesses and one Art Department from flooded offices.
  • We helped Build it Green, Eastern Effects, Gowanus Ballroom and The Action Center restock and rebuild with furniture and office supplies
  • We donated 10% of our auction proceeds to The Red Hook Initiative.  ($300)

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

It's tough all over.  Between a kooky economy and a string of devestating news this year your donation budget may be stretched thin.   

Some people just can’t contribute funds, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Volunteer!  Your time is valuable!  Help us sort and distribute!
  • Share!  Forward this to your friends and vendors in the film industry and beyond!
  • Like us, Follow us and share our mission with the world.
story_txt:
Film Biz is doing everything it can to help us overcome our bad consumer habits and give back to our community at the same time. They are a group to be admired and supported! Film Biz fosters the creative talents of all those trying to pave their way into the film industry by making independent filmmaking so much more sustainable and affordable. They deserve all the support we can give.
Annie Ford, Props Master
 
We need the help of our industry to do what we do.
Over 40% of the props, wardrobe and set dressing we receive goes right out to local charities, arts programs, worthy causes and, now, emergency response. 
75% of our overhead is earned income from the prop shop - an incredibly high percentage for your average non-profit.  However, to get to 100% of operations costs we have to fundraise every year and we appeal to YOU.  
Many employee hours and lots of our rented space is dedicated to serving our neighborhood via processing, preparing and deliveies - all drain out resources, but we would not do it any other way.
 
We do more than give to charity.  In 2012...



Received donations from 642 productions and diverted 123 tons from the waste stream
Hosted eco classes & workshops, Reuse birthday parties, environmental training seminar Green Vendor Expo curated and produced by Film Biz Recycling and many other Gowanus community events.
Hired a full-time upcycler in the Upcycle GALA-RE
Provided space for City Council Member Brad Lander's participatory budget training.
FBR presented ISES NYC Sustainability Summit, Eco-Focus Press Event, ABC/Disney Earth Day Event and Grow NYC



 
When Sandy hit, we were able to be first responders, just by doing what we do everyday.
By virtue of what we do everyday, we were well prepared as first responders to alleviate Sandy’s impact; our unique position to help its victims underscores our importance to our community and the necessary role we play as a vital link between the film industry and charitable institutions.  

Halloween was practically cancelled, so the FBR staff threw a "Cabin Fever Arts'" party for disappointed neighborhood kids.
We were a hub for Sandy donations, volunteer meeting space and information.
We donated over $9,000 of inventory to relief efforts.
We housed two Gowanus businesses and one Art Department from flooded offices.
We helped Build it Green, Eastern Effects, Gowanus Ballroom and The Action Center restock and rebuild with furniture and office supplies
We donated 10% of our auction proceeds to The Red Hook Initiative.  ($300)

 
 


Other Ways You Can Help
It's tough all over.  Between a kooky economy and a string of devestating news this year your donation budget may be stretched thin.   
Some people just can’t contribute funds, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

Volunteer!  Your time is valuable!  Help us sort and distribute!
Share!  Forward this to your friends and vendors in the film industry and beyond!
Like us, Follow us and share our mission with the world.

story:
Our Story

Flying-foxes are in trouble. Nature's natural flying gardeners are keystone pollinators and seed dispersers for so many Australian Eucalypt and Rainforest trees, but our large and beautiful bats are dwindling in numbers due to continual habitat loss. We need your help to re-grow rainforest.

NightWings is an ambitious and unique project. A property has been purchased south of the Daintree River in Far North Queensland, backing onto the World Heritage listed Daintree National Park: an area recognised as having the highest biodiversity rate in Australia. The 37 acres (15ha) site will encompass a small area for low impact, ecologically sustainable Visitor, Education and Interpretive Centre, and Bat Hospital. We envision to also build a café and gift shop in the future once the revegetation is established. However, the majority of the land is being turned over to the exciting task of turning old cane land into complex lowland rainforest, combined with forest walks for a stunning and authentic ecotourism experience. The site already contains mature and new rainforest planting, and transects have revealed a myriad of fauna, including 11 EVNT (Endangered, Vulnerable, & Near Threatened) listed species. These include: the Southern Cassowary, Bennett’s Tree Kangaroo, Grey Goshawk, Grey Falcon, Raja Shelduck, Rufous Owl, Ghost bat, Large-eared Horseshoe bat, the endangered Australian Lace-lid Frog, Spectacled Flying-fox and flora like the vulnerably listed Black Palm. Government transects have revealed at least 65 additional species of Mammals, Birds, Reptiles and Amphibians on this property. All (such as these handreared baby Northern Brown Bandicoots) will benefit from increased planting.

Divided into planting stages over 6 years, the whole project will require over 70,000 trees to be planted. This will provide a fast-growing framework for animals to bring in secondary seed direct from the surrounding forest. The first stage of 5.4 acres (2.2ha) (encompassing the visually-blended centre) will create a significant 60 metre wide corridor linking mature lowland rainforest to the mangroves at the Daintree River mouth for the first time in around 100 years.

Working with experts in regeneration like Rainforest Rescue, Douglas Shire Council and in consultation with the traditional Kuku Yalanji people, our aim is to create a centre of excellence in conservation, bat rehabilitation and ecologically diverse land management.

You can help be part of this significant project by donating a tree (or two or six). Stage 1 will be planted from December 2015 - March 2016, and will require 10,000 trees. Work has already begun on seed acquisition, germination and potting seedlings, but we still need to raise an additional $9,000 for 3,000 of those trees to be grown by Douglas Shire Council Native Nursery.

For any enquiries, please contact us on nightwings.centre@gmail.com

Visit our website for more at www.nightwings.net

Thank you in advance

Annie Schoenberger, Connie Kerr and Dave Pinson, (the NightWings team).

We are Annie, Connie and Dave and together we have over 40 years experience in Wildlife Care and Rehabilitation, in particular specialising in Bats and Flying-foxes. We therefore fully understand the importance of providing suitable habitat for wildlife. Our aim is that by increasing the habitat of this ecologically diverse and valuable area, we will be able to provide new homes and feeding areas for much of our local wildlife.

What We Need & What You Get

In a previous campaign (thanks to amazing generosity) we raised $10,476. This allowed us to go ahead and pay deposits to Rainforest Rescue to secure the growing of 6000 trees, and to purchase pots and growing medium for the 1000+ trees we are growing ourselves. What we need now in this new campaign is $9000 to secure and fund 3000 mixed rainforest trees from Douglas Shire Native Nursery, to bring the total growing to 10,000 trees. The Council Nursery have been incredibly helpful, are fully supportive of our project, and have given us a good price. Now we need to raise the required funds to make sure that the baby trees are grown and reach the right size for planting out at the right time.

We offer a range of perks ranging from certificates to postcard prints, to large photographic prints, and tote bags and throw pillows. Apart from perks, you will also receive the satisfaction that you have helped create some brand new rainforest in tropical north Queensland; a legacy for the future.

The Impact

Every $10.00 you donate will provide funds for the growth, watering, planting, weed control and maintenance of a tree, and each tree will provide just over one square metre of brand new rainforest.

As this land is old sugarcane fields it is going to require 3 stages of land preparation before the trees can be planted and will then require ongoing weed control for at least 2 years after planting until established. This is where your contribution will go.

Your donation will leave a legacy, turning this......

into this

The Future 

We will continue to liaise and work with organisations such as Rainforest Rescue and the Douglas Shire Council throughout all stages of this project. By providing the initial framework trees, we will provide the necessary requirements to bring in rainforest doves, cassowaries, flying-foxes and other animals who will then in turn bring in seed from the surrounding forests to rapidly increase species diversity, with the final aim being rich and complex mature lowland rainforest.

Flying-foxes plant trees wherever they go, but they also need trees in which to feed and roost. Your donation can help secure more valuable trees for guys like these. The photo below was 'the class of 2015', a whole huggle of juvenile Spectacled Flying-foxes raised from little orphans by us last season. This photo was taken just before they were all moved into the Kuranda release cage - soon to take their place in the wild once more. Please help us to help bats just like them.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our project and needs far and wide with your family, friends and work colleagues. Remember, every single tree will create one square meter of brand new rainforest for perpetuity. Alternatively you may wish to conduct a mini fundraiser with your family, workplace or neighbourhood, and donate the funds raised to our project.

In the future we will be opening the Centre to the public and would invite everyone to come and visit to see the growth and progress of your trees.

Every donor will receive a personalised electronic emailed certificate acknowledging your valued contribution. NB: please email us your name as you would like it on the certificate, as we have no way of knowing.

For any enquiries, please do not hesitate to contact us on nightwings.centre@gmail.com and don't forget to follow us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/nightwings.centre or via our website at www.nightwings.com

story:
Summary

On my birthday, July 31, 2013, I adopted Borinquen Beach. I told my friends to donate their time and energy to my cause instead of giving me presents. On that day we cleared out the park entrance to the beach and installed a sign I made. For more than a year prior to this event I attempted to involve and get the help of multiple government agencies. Nobody claimed responsibility or wanted to help me, so I decided to do it myself.

(FIRST DAY) 

These areas, which encompass more then 280+ acres are intrinsically beautiful  and amazing. Within this concentrated area you could find: world class surfing, historical landmarks (Spanish Light House Ruins), endangered species, and a multitude of recreational sports like: hiking, horseback-riding,  mountain biking, beautiful walking trails, fishing and snorkeling. What most people don't realize is that this abandoned  area was apart of Ramey Air Force Base, and was frequented by the President of the United States.   Since the Air Force left, the place has become  completely abandoned. All infrastructure, facilities and amenities are gone or destroyed. The roads accessing the beach are washed out, the gazebos, picnic tables, bathrooms, and trashcans are all gone. Criminality in the area is a concern and citizens of the community are afraid to go down and visit. But we have begun to change all of that! 


Since I first adopted this area and I have realized I could get more done if I worked with a team. So I decided to formerly  incorporate “Rescate Playas Borinquen” nonprofit organization to channel the energy of people who want to help restore the local area(s). In short, our goal is to "make these areas more accessible, safe and enjoyable for the public, via all forms of maintenance and hard work necesary to restore the area to its former glory."  

(BEFORE/AFTER IMAGE)

Sadly, there is only so much we could do with a limited budget.  We would like to start restoring some of the facilities  that once were there starting with the pavilion, or "bohio"picnic area.  The cement pavilion, whats left of the gazebo, is 50x50ft which equates to 2,500 square feet. The estimated construction cost is 15.00$ per 1 sq/ft. If you do the math, 2,500 square feet by 15.00$ per square foot is equivalent to 37,500$.  This is the rough construction estimate. This was once the  focal point of many community gatherings and had been there for over 50 years. Help us bring  this area back!  You may see the changes and impacts we have already made via our facebook page: Rescate Playas Borinquen. Add us :)  RESCATE PLAYAS BORINQUEN  or email at rescateplayasbqn@gmail.com. Since we started our compressive revatalization project of the recreational areas, criminality has gone down, the area looks clean and inviting, and most importantly families are coming back to their beaches!!! Imagine how much more we could do if we had some funds. Only 1/4 of a mile from the local air port this area has great potential for low impact ecotourism and just a place to enjoy. Thanks for your consideration Mario Torres. 

(SEE BELOW BEFORE/AFTER PROPOSED AREA)


Who I Am: 

My name is Mario Torres and with the exception of several college semesters, I have lived in the former Ramey AFB, Aguadilla, Puerto Rico area for over 17 years. I am currently working at the U.S. Coast Guard Exchange and I am also a small business owner and artist. You are welcomed to check out my website: www.mariofelipetorres.com . I was apart of the Ramey Historical Society and I am an active member of my community and the founder of my nonprofit.

story:
This is our last adventure...

Be sure to Like us on FaceBook and share the link! 

I am a television and radio broadcaster with a passion for the sea...  and I want to get a layman's view of how it has changed in the 35 years since my last long voyage. From all accounts the oceans are in a bad way - and all life on earth depends on them. We want to see for ourselves and report back to you directly...

My brother and I will be filming life aboard and at sea every day, making short videos and uploading them every week to share our discoveries and experiences with you. Eventually I'll be able to complete the book I began on the first voyage and called Trade Wind Gypsies

Although we have bought and paid for the 37' yacht, marine/satellite connectivity to upload the latest stories is expensive. We believe it is a vitally important story to tell so we will shoot, edit and produce the videos entirely at our expense. But we need your help to get them uploaded and onto YouTube. Your contribution will go to buying the marine satellite equipment and help pay for the program uploads. 

What you'll get is immediate access to each week's video (more than 100 videos in total!) Your $25 will also get you a free download of the ebook on the voyage when it is completed. 

Although this adventure is sure to have it highs and lows and should prove both  engaging and entertaining, there is a serious side. We'll also be streaming back as much scientific data as we can collect to various universities for their research into the health of the world's oceans. We're even taking a Geiger Counter to check radiation levels that may have occurred since the Fukushima disaster.

We know not everyone is able to help directly... But be a Gypsy, follow the voyage, tell your friends. Do all you can to raise awareness of the threats facing the oceans and their sea life - threats from pollution, overfishing, garbage, sewage, chemicals, plastics, climate change and acidification. 

Be a virtual Trade Wind Gypsy... Let's get blown away - together!

story:
Hi there! 

My name's Edith, and I just graduated from York University's Sociology program. I'm going to be applying to graduate school but first, I wanted to fulfill my lifelong dream of going to Tanzania. The sociologist in me didn't feel it was right to just go there on vacation, though, so I'm planning a four-month volunteer trip from January to May. The two projects I'll be working with are Kiviwama Young Activists for the Environment and Kili Kids Centre. Most of the money raised will go directly to the charities I'll be working with, and some will go to help me out with visas, vaccinations and basic accommodations while I'm there. 

The first, Kiviwama, is where the bulk of the money from this campaign will be going. They are a local organization established in 1999 in response to National Water Week. The focus of this week was to care for and plant indigenous trees, as deforestation around the slopes of Kilimanjaro has drastically reduced the supply of clean drinking water from the glacial springs that supply the villages below. Since their inception, they have grown and planted 300, 000 trees around the Moshi area.  They start the trees in their nursery, which is where I'll be working most of the time. However, they need extra funds as well as physical labour to actually plant the trees in the surrounding villages. That's where your generous donations will help! 

The second project, Kili Kids Centre, is an orphanage housing 29 children that also has a permaculture and sustainability project on the farm alongside the orphanage. When I'm not volunteering planting trees with Kiviwama, I'll be working on the farm to provide food to the children living at Kili Kids. 

Both these projects mesh right in with my academic interest in sustainable food sourcing and environmental protection, so I'm hoping that in addition to helping out these amazing charities, I'll also gain some valuable experience in my field. 

I'm doing all this through a charity called Path to Africa, which is run by a couple of lovely people who also own Hostel Hoff, which is where I'll be staying while there. They are two locals who wanted to offer an opportunity to volunteer with projects in their community where money and time goes directly to those projects. A part of the proceeds from Hostel Hoff go back into local charities through Path to Africa, and all the money raised for Kili Kids Centre and Kiviwama goes directly to those organizations. 

Here's the links to Path to Africa and Hostel Hoff if you want to check it out for yourself: 

http://www.pathtoafrica.org
http://www.hostelhoff.com

The Breakdown

Assuming I reach my goal, the funds will be distributed like this. If not, then I'll prioritize the funding for Kiviwama as well as my vaccinations: 

1860$ goes to Hostel Hoff for accommodations, a  portion of which is redistributed back into the community through their charity, Path to Africa

1300$ goes to Kiviwama Young Activists for the Environment, 100$ per weekly tree-planting trip

250$ goes towards a mandatory volunteer visa that I need to work in Tanzania for 3 months

500$ goes towards vaccinations, similarly necessary, as this is my first trip to Africa and I don't have any of the required vaccines yet

If I raise any extra money, I'll split it equally between helping me cover the cost of my plane ticket and donate the other half straight to Path to Africa. 

Every little bit helps, and I'm going to keep a blog while I'm there so we can keep in touch and you can see what I'm doing.

But if you can't donate, please share my campaign so I can help out these awesome charities and achieve my dream!

The first, Kiviwama, is where the bulk of the money from this campaign will be going. They are a local organization established in 1999 in response to National Water Week. The focus of this week was to care for and plant indigenous trees, as deforestation around the slopes of Kilimanjaro has drastically reduced the supply of clean drinking water from the glacial springs that supply the villages below. Since their inception, they have grown and planted 300, 000 trees around the Moshi area.  They start the trees in their nursery, which is where I'll be working most of the time. However, they need extra funds as well as physical labour to actually plant the trees in the surrounding villages. That's where your generous donations will help! 
The second project, Kili Kids Centre, is an orphanage housing 29 children that also has a permaculture and sustainability project on the farm alongside the orphanage. When I'm not volunteering planting trees with Kiviwama, I'll be working on the farm to provide food to the children living at Kili Kids. 
Both these projects mesh right in with my academic interest in sustainable food sourcing and environmental protection, so I'm hoping that in addition to helping out these amazing charities, I'll also gain some valuable experience in my field. 
I'm doing all this through a charity called Path to Africa, which is run by a couple of lovely people who also own Hostel Hoff, which is where I'll be staying while there. They are two locals who wanted to offer an opportunity to volunteer with projects in their community where money and time goes directly to those projects. A part of the proceeds from Hostel Hoff go back into local charities through Path to Africa, and all the money raised for Kili Kids Centre and Kiviwama goes directly to those organizations. 
Here's the links to Path to Africa and Hostel Hoff if you want to check it out for yourself: 

http://www.pathtoafrica.org
http://www.hostelhoff.com

The Breakdown
 Assuming I reach my goal, the funds will be distributed like this. If not, then I'll prioritize the funding for Kiviwama as well as my vaccinations: 
1860$ goes to Hostel Hoff for accommodations, a  portion of which is redistributed back into the community through their charity, Path to Africa
1300$ goes to Kiviwama Young Activists for the Environment, 100$ per weekly tree-planting trip
250$ goes towards a mandatory volunteer visa that I need to work in Tanzania for 3 months
500$ goes towards vaccinations, similarly necessary, as this is my first trip to Africa and I don't have any of the required vaccines yet
If I raise any extra money, I'll split it equally between helping me cover the cost of my plane ticket and donate the other half straight to Path to Africa. 
Every little bit helps, and I'm going to keep a blog while I'm there so we can keep in touch and you can see what I'm doing.
But if you can't donate, please share my campaign so I can help out these awesome charities and achieve my dream!

story:
Short Summary

Super typhoon ‘Haiyan’ hit the Philippines on November 8th 2013. It is the worst storm to ever have made landfall in modern history and turned the Philippines from a paradise into a disaster area. Restoring electricity in the affected area is vital for its recovery.

After every disaster, it usually takes months to put electric utilities in order so as to bring the grid back to life. During all those months, the majority of the people in the Philippines are left without access to electricity.

    Electricity is vital for the affected territory as it provides:

    1. Refrigeration: preservation of medicines, vaccines, food;
    2. Water: pumping and making the water drinkable is impossible without electricity;
    3. Telecom, using phone or internet: communication with families, rescue teams, Red Cross;
    4. Light: the day should not be over when the sun goes down.

    The PowerTower by InnoVentum is a hybrid wind-solar energy station that is robust, easy to install and made of renewable and recycled materials. It provides 4000-5000 kWh of green energy per year – day and night, thanks to the complementarity of solar panels and a wind turbine. It is built with highest quality materials and is the result of 6000 engineering hours of calculations and testing.

    A brief note about who we are: InnoVentum is a Swedish company founded in Malmö in 2010. We are focusing on giving power to the people by decentralizing the production of green energy. We offer the most carbon-neutral wind-solar energy solutions on the Planet by using renewable materials (wood) for the majority of the tower construction and recycled materials for the rest of the solution.

    InnoVentum has already donated one PowerTower and now we turn to you in order to finance 1 more tower. By joining forces to fund the production and installation of 2 PowerTowers we will change the life of thousands of people for decades to come – in the area that needs it most. The installations will have no negative effect on the environment, unlike diesel generators that are commonly used in such circumstances and poison already damaged environment. Your help makes a difference!

    What We Need & What You Get

    What We Need:

    Our goal with this campaign is to make donations REAL and DIRECT: For every 300.000 SEK (46.000 USD) donated, one new PowerTower will be installed – without any losses in bribes. The 46.000 USD covers purchase of goods and services exclusively related to preparing, transporting and installing the hybrid solutions. Donating the PowerTower directly and managing transport through a reliable and experienced partner also makes it difficult for anyone to remove any percentage.

    Out of the funds donated to the Power to the Philippines campaign, 100% gives light to those living in darkness. InnoVentum will not receive any financial dividends or profits from this campaign. 

      • Please donate as much as you can – there is no lower and upper limit - each and every contribution counts! If we do not reach the goal, your funds will still be directed to install as many towers as possible – be it even just one more tower. Please note that Indiegogo charges a higher percentage for service if we do not reach the goal, so it is in your and our interest to reach the target and allocate as much money as possible for the good cause!
      • All money above the target will be put towards additional installations at the locations defined in collaboration with the Children’s Mission in the Philippines. Maybe we can reach 10?
      • You can receive all updates on the installation process by following our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/InnoVentum and the News section on our website:http://www.innoventum.se/category/news/power-to-the-philippines/

    What You Get (Perks):

    Since our campaign is designed in a way that all possible funds help people in need, we won't be able to provide generous perks for smaller contributions. Should you donate 600 USD or more, we will include your name in our project movie. For contributions above 15000 USD your name will appear on the installed PowerTower in the Philippines, confirming that it was your generous contribution that made this installation happen. You will also get a 1:20 PowerTower Model kit and a thank you diploma. And remember that a good deed and contribution will pay itself off in the long run!

    The Impact

    The first PowerTower is being installed at the Hills of Grace near Manila. Our installation site for the second PowerTower will be the Scandinavian Village in the northern part of Tacloban that was built in the 1990s by the Children's Mission (Barnmissionen in Swedish). This village consists of 300 houses and several schools. In total, 2500 people live in the village, which has been devastated by the typhoon. The houses have been repaired, but the village is still without any supply of electricity.

    The Children’s Mission has bought a 5,5 kW diesel generator, but they only run it 4 hours per day due to noise and pollution. The generator provides power to LED lights around one schoolyard, outlets for charging phones and pocket lights. There is no electricity for refrigeration and there are some electric pumps for water that would need electricity.

    By contributing to this initiative you will therefore improve the life of thousands of people and will do so in the most sustainable way.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you support our cause please do not hesitate to share our campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+ or any other social media, as well as through the Indiegogo sharing tools! Check out our crowdfundingforum.com thread too. Many thanks in advance!
