story:
Environmental Cleanup & Land Remediation Project

Who we are

TERC, LLC is a land reclamation and environmental cleanup company that specializes in only the illegal tire dumps across the State of Texas.  Where ever we go we work in close coordination with the TCEQ (Texas Commission for Environmental Quality or the State version of the EPA) and local municipalities.  In our five year history we have removed well over 3.5 million tires from illegal tire dumps throughout the State.  The majority of of these cleanups were completed at no cost to the State, County, or City.  This particular dump site has never received funding from the local City, County, or the State.  All avenues of additional funding, (the State, City of Whitesboro, Grayson County, Grayson County RC&D and the Texoma COG or Council of Governments) including special project grants, have been exhausted. 

100% of the funds raised from this campaign will go toward the cost of processing and removal of all the tires that are littering this property, potentially threatening the general health and quality of life in the surrounding areas.  

The magnitude of this campaign is hard to measure as there are potentially over a million gallons of water contained within the piles of tires on this illegal tire dump.  Texas, especially North Texas, was hit hard last year by the onset of West Nile and with approximately 300,000 tires sitting in a pile and holding up to three gallons of water each it is the ideal breeding ground for millions of mosquito larvae.  These larvae will eventually hatch and be available to carry the virus.  Your funding will illuminate the tires on this property from continuing to be a breeding ground for mosquitoes.  Removing the tires would also eliminate the chance of an environmental catastrophe in the form of an uncontrollable tire fire.  A tire fire of this size could burn for weeks, even months, pumping toxic waste into the air and oily waste water into the soil and ground water.  This property lies 3 miles from the 12th largest lake in the US, Lake Texoma, which is a major water source for much of Grayson, Collin, Dallas and other Counties.  

Your contribution will make a huge difference in preventing potentially billions of dollars in damage to the environment.

What We Need and What You Get

We are asking for $100,000 to process and remove the remaining approximately 300,000 tires from the site.  It costs us roughly .85 to $1.25 to process and remove each tire to an approved facility.  Our company will make up the difference in cost since we already have all the associated equipment and logistics in place.  As well, we have spent a sizable amount of money on the prevention of further illegal dumping on this property.  100% of the funds will go to pay for the labor to process the tires, the labor and fuel to load the scrap tire material into trucks and most importantly the actual trucking to remove the scrap tire material from the site to an approved facility.  If we don’t reach our goal whatever money has been donated will be used to process and remove as many tires as possible. 

Every tire removed reduces the fire and mosquito risk by an enormous amount. 

What you get besides helping your fellow man and the environment are some pretty exciting perks.  As you notice we are giving away bonsai trees.  As an additional benefit towards this cleanup, but not the main focus, we have partnered with Carbon Tree Farms of Keller and will be turning 17 acres of this property into a tree farm at the conclusion of the cleanup.  What better way to turn a dump into something beautiful and to make up for lost time.

The Impact

The impact your donation will make is that you will have a direct immediate effect on the number of tires currently on the site.  You are actively preventing a very real epidemic.  

We feel that the property began with an estimated 350,000 tires and we have removed just over 49,000 which has reduced the spread of West Nile and eliminated some of the risk of an environmental catastrophe.  A direct immediate threat exists to the air, ground and water quality for thousands of residents for Grayson and surrounding counties as well as livestock, crops, and other native plants and animals. Removing this threat as fast as possible is paramount and time is not on our side.  With warmer weather already here in North Texas the Mosquito epidemic is literally coming back to life.  Should this site not be cleaned up it would cost millions to spray and eradicate the mosquitoes in order to prevent West Nile and multi-millions to put out the fire with continuing damage in the millions as well. 

Many of you have asked to see pictures of all our different products and their different uses.  See the gallery for pics and descriptions.

TERC is zero landfill company and all scrap tire material removed from the site will be sent to approved state certified end users that will use the material as an alternative fuel source to coal, also known as energy recovery.   

TERC is a Christian and Veteran owned business.   

For further information message me here or on Facebook.  And above all……THANK YOU

Here are some links that should be helpful in explaining this epidemic and its importance.

Links:

Lake Texoma

(http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lake_Texoma

http://www.laketexoma.com/information

http://www.laketexomaonline.com/home.asp

http://corpslakes.usace.army.mil/visitors/projects.cfm?Id=M574945

 

Tire Dumps

http://1800recycling.com/2010/06/sea-rubber-truth-tire-recycling/

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tire_recycling

http://www.epa.gov/osw/conserve/materials/tires/faq.htm

http://www.tceq.state.tx.us/compliance/tires/recycling.html

 

Tire Fires

http://www.valleycentral.com/news/story.aspx?id=647772#.UWiCgU0o7IU

http://www.epa.gov/osw/conserve/materials/tires/fires.htm

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9sfmE_eY6oA

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9sfmE_eY6oA

http://www.youtube.com/watch?NR=1&v=9lDRPCh8G5s&feature=endscreen

 

Mosquitoes and West Nile

http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/video/west-nile-virus-fighting-deadly-outbreak-17277245

http://animal.discovery.com/tv-shows/other/videos/killer-outbreaks-west-nile-virus.htm

http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvbid/westnile/index.htm

http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/west-nile-virus/DS00438/DSECTION=symptoms

http://fortworthtexas.gov/westnilevirus/

http://www.kten.com/story/5353345/west-nile-virus-in-grayson-county

http://www.kxii.com/home/headlines/Grayson-Co-develops-West-Nile-prevention-strategy-166476086.html

story:
Je côtoie les abeilles depuis maintenant quatre ans et force m'est de constater qu'elles ont énormément à offrir et que j'adore prendre soin d'elles. 

Je souhaite entamer une  production de miel mais aussi expérimenter avec le venim d'abeille pour soulager les personnes atteintes de douleurs chroniques (déjà quelques amiEs se sont portés volontaires ! ) et éventuellement l'inhalation d'air de la ruche pour apaiser les états anxieux (oui oui!). 

Les dollars amassés serviront uniquement à acheter les abeilles et le  matériel apicole:  ruches, traitements, suppléments naturels pour les abeilles, beesuit, trappe à pollen, outils d'extraction, outils d'apithérapie. 

S'il vous est impossible de me soutenir financièrement, pas de soucis! Merci de semer des fleurs riches en pollen et nectar autour de vous pour soutenir les pollinisateurs en leur offrant de la nourriture et de partager ce projet auprès de celles et ceux que ça pourrait intéresser :) 

Un grand MERCI! Bees and Love ! ♥

...................................................................................................................................................................


I have been around bees for four years now and I have to admit that they are wonderful beings to be with and have A LOT to offer! 

My goal is to get 4 hives at first, produce honey, but also experiment with bee venim to help soothe the chronic pain linked to pathologies like multiples sclerosis and arthritis (a few friends are already willing to test it! ) and inhalation from the hives to lower levels of stress and anxiety (yes!) . 

All the money will go to buy beekeeping material and bees:  hives, beesuit, extraction tools, natural supplements for the bees, apitherapy material. 

If you cannot help support my project financially , no worries! You can support the pollinators by planting pollen and nectar rich plants to have them happy with plenty of food.. and share my project with the people around you! 

THANK YOU SO MUCH!
It's all happening!!! Bees and Love! ♥

story:
Our campaign goal is set to $2,000 USD. This is the minimum GCC needs to return to Burma and give on the ground assistance for one full month. We really need $33,000 for the year. If we can get 2000 people to give around $15USD then we can accomplish our goal. Read on to learn why we need your help!!!!!!

WHO ARE WE?

We are Green Communities Consulting (GCC) - a team of dedicated experts and volunteers helping communities in Burma. GCC works closely with communities, organizations and youth practitioners in land use planning, resource management, and sustainable design. Go to www.greencc.org to find out more!

GCC’s mission: empowerment through integrating environmental practices in community led development.

Three of our six projects:

  • Cha Nu Nu’s Model Organic Farm and Agro-forestry project (Karen State)
  • San Myint & Thuzar Win’s Model Farm and Seed Bank project (Inle Lake)
  • San Htay’s Biodiversity, Native Species, and Organic Farming project (Rakhine State)

By contributing to this cause, you will:

  1. allow young practitioners to positively change their lives and reach thousands of others along the way,
  2. protect the environment,
  3. contribute towards peace, and
  4. help build a better world.

Together we will touch the lives of thousands.

THE BREAK DOWN

In an ideal world we need to raise at least $30,000 to continue the work. That is a lot of money. So, our fundraiser is broken down into three goals:

First                 $16,500 USD (six months of funding)

Each month's costs are $2,750 USD (roughly $16,500 for six months). This will enable GCC to consult on youth projects and conduct community and youth trainings as well as other activities. Each month's operation costs also includes $250 of seed money for youth projects. Once this goal is reached we move to the next goal!

Second           $5,000 USD (registration)

NGO registration and other associated costs are estimated at $5,000 USD to register in the United States. 

Third                $16,500 USD (six more months of funding)

This goal marker works the same as goal one. Each month's operation costs also includes $250 of seed money for youth projects.

Any additional funds raised at this point on will be split two ways. Half will go towards student projects this year, and half will go towards setting up a financially sustainable future for GCC projects.

The Perks:

  • In the near future, GCC will work on a model rooftop garden on a small mud brick building. Look to the right to see what you get for $10, $50, $250, and $1,000 donations.
  • If you contributed, you are eligible to receive special GCC updates, project news, and photos. To be added to this list please send an e-mail to jonathan.rhodes@greencc.org and let us know you contributed in the subject line!

So, what happens if we don’t make our goal? It is A-OKEY! At least we tried. The money will still go (in order of priority) to pay for me to assist youth projects, help fund the projects, and register GCC in the United States.

THE IMPACT

We are in a unique position to help. My work helps ensure the environment does not get left behind. Even though we are a young organization, we have provided assistance in a number of ways: the construction of the Eco-Village Foundation and successfully provided help with the conceptualization of a number of youth projects.

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Low on cash? That’s fine. We understand not everyone can give money. There are other ways you can help.

  1. First go to our website and check out the various project videos. We need your help selecting the last three projects.
  2. You can also spread the word about us. Get our name out there and share Green Communities Consulting with the world. Like us on facebook, follow our twitter, join our blog discussions.
  3. Or, you can get involved in a deeper way. Volunteer with us. Check out our get involved page to learn more. Much of our work relies on volunteer remote experts. Help us today!
story_txt:
Our campaign goal is set to $2,000 USD. This is the minimum GCC needs to return to Burma and give on the ground assistance for one full month. We really need $33,000 for the year. If we can get 2000 people to give around $15USD then we can accomplish our goal. Read on to learn why we need your help!!!!!! 
WHO ARE WE?
We are Green Communities Consulting (GCC) - a team of dedicated experts and volunteers helping communities in Burma. GCC works closely with communities, organizations and youth practitioners in land use planning, resource management, and sustainable design. Go to www.greencc.org to find out more!

story:
Tears trickled from Rashida Ali-Campbell’s eyes Friday morning as she watched volunteers turn old tires and empty beer cans into a haven for the have-nots in her West Philadelphia neighborhood.

“Have you ever wanted something so much?” she asked. “So many people are helping make this dream come true. This is what I have prayed for.”Tires stuffed with hundreds of pounds of dirt will form walls. Old oven doors will serve as roof shingles. When she is done with what used to be a warehouse at 675 N. 41st Street, it will be a studio with a garden adorned with fruit trees and vegetables.More to the point, it will be a haven for the neighborhood.“I want this for people who can’t afford it and are living in survival mode,” said Ali-Campbell, the founder of Love Loving Love, a nonprofit that en- courages healthy habits through eating and exer- cise, especially for troubled children.Ali-Campbell spent periods of her childhood homeless, and lived for three years in foster care. She sees a reflection of her youth in the kids living in West Philadelphia, where the mean household income is less than $40,000 a year.To build the community garden, Love Loving Love teamed with a New Mexico company, Earth- ship Biotecture, which builds similar structures around the world.Their ecofriendly design extends beyond construction materials. Solar panels generate power.

Cisterns collect and purify rainwater. The runoff from showers and sinks is recy- cled to water the planters. The buildings are entirely off the grid. They are cheap to build and there are no utility bills.“The idea is we should live in buildings that are in harmony with our environment,” said Earthship’s Jonah Reynolds.Danelle Nelson, one of about 20 volunteers working Friday, changed her work schedule so she could spend her days at the construction site. She’s been working at her tech support job early in the morning and late at night, allowing her to spend days with her hands deep in dirt, dust, and cement.“I can’t wait to do more,” the Lansdowne woman said. “I don’t mind switching up my hours be- cause it’s such a fantastic project.”Making the garden studio a re- ality continues to be a challenge. Ali-Campbell had trouble con- vincing city government the home wouldn’t look like something out of The Flintstones, she said. She has worked hard to reach out to her neighbors, one of whom complained to the police because he thought the piles of tires at the site were the result of illegal dumping.

story:
The Project

I am the founder of the plant sync, an umbrella organization established on Earth Day, 2015. The plant sync is committed to bringing climate change action to non-food gardening (see more on Facebook and theplantsync.com). Lighting the Seeds is one of our programs that will directly reduce the carbon footprint of the plant sync's operations and inspire other indoor gardeners to do likewise. The founder of the plant sync has a Ph.D. in plant genetics and more than thirty years of experience growing plants in various indoor environments. Our experience and passion to fight climate change motivate us to implement simple, pragmatic, and inexpensive solutions.

The plant sync will reduce the global carbon footprint by using, testing, and promoting the most efficient supplementary lighting solutions for home seed starters. To this day, University publications and other reputable sources continue to recommend fluorescent lamps for hobbyist indoor seed starting. The increasing use of LED lighting for growing plants has resulted in numerous products on the market. But many of these LED lighting solutions are designed for professional horticultural applications. They are often priced out of reach of someone who just wants to get a head start growing tomatoes (e.g.) in their basement. The plant sync has tested LED lighting in typical settings for seed starting for homeowners. Our results show that inexpensive and readily available LED shoplight fixtures work as well or better than fluorescent lamps. Our objectives for this campaign are threefold:

  1. Replace all our fluorescent lamps in our own operations with more efficient LED fixtures.   This will directly and immediately lower our carbon footprint.
  2. Conduct side-by-side experiments between fluorescent and LED lamps under conditions relevant to hobbyist seed starters and indoor plant growers.
  3. Expand the impact on mitigating climate change by promoting the use of more efficient lighting for home seed starters and indoor plant enthusiasts -- with hard data and professional marketing.

The Funding

We need $5000 to purchase lighting materials and seeds. To have the greatest instructional impact we will also pay for professional marketing of our results. Here's the breakdown:

  • Replace fluorescent fixtures with LED fixtures: $2000.00
  • Full spectrum quantum light meter and mounting accessories: $600.00
  • Experimental LED fixtures for experiments: $1000.00
  • (3) temperature loggers: $225.00
  • Seed supplies: $75.00
  • Miscellaneous supplies: $100.00
  • Instructional video: $1000
  • Total: $5000

We have chosen flexible funding because we can directly reduce greenhouse gas emissions for each $40.00 received. Each LED fixture costs about $40.00. Every replacement fixture reduces our power draw and the attendant greenhouse gas emissions.

The Perks

Any contribution to our campaign benefits the environment by causing a direct reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. See our Perks for more!

Keys to Success

Lighting the Seeds of Climate Change Action is guaranteed to succeed even if we raise only $40.00.

  • We have already reduced our carbon footprint through replacement lighting technology.
  • Further replacement of lighting in $40.00 increments immediately reduces our carbon footprint.
  • Our experiments are simple and our instructional marketing message will be straightforward.

Help Us Out!

Even without funding you can help by following us on Facebook and Twitter and promoting our campaign. Thanks!

story:
WCSV needs you to help save local raptors!

 

WCSV is the only wildlife hospital in Santa Clara County that rehabilitates raptors, which include falcons, hawks, owls, and turkey vultures. This is an expensive process! The cost to rehabilitate the red shouldered hawk featured in this video exceeded $5000 in vet care, surgical supplies, medications and food.

Most injured birds come in after being hit by a car, caught by other animals, or from rodenticide poisoning. Many raptors are orphaned when nests are destroyed by tree trimming or strong winds. The typical length of stay at the center for each raptor is about 60 days, but some are in care for much longer while waiting for a molt before release.

Our raptor aviaries are in almost daily use and most are over 20 years old with necessary repairs and rotting wooden roofs that need to be replaced.

 

Here's how your donation will return raptors to the wild!

$25  replace and upgrade a perch

$50  repair a hawk-box 

$100  provide 1 week of medication for a single raptor

$250  provide food for one falcon from baby to adult 

$500  repair the roof on a small aviary

story:
About GtB

Greening the Beige (GtB) is a volunteer network dedicated to raising environmental awareness through hosting art and community events. Supported by artists, musicians, designers, filmmakers, students, teachers, NGO affiliates, businesses and other residents in Beijing, the ultimate aim of this project is to address widespread pollution problems and sustainability issues by fostering creative thinking and doing.

 

Our Impact

Since 2007 GtB has grown to include nearly 1,000 active participants who all share the same desire: to make Beijing (and ultimately the world at large) a greener place to live!

 

Over the last 5 years, the GtB volunteer network has presented an annual public event series to demonstrate an array of "eco" creativity, such as:

 

- live music, dance, comedy, experimental and unusual performances

- interactive eco-art creations for public display

- hands-on workshops

- premiere art showcases

 - distinguished guest presentations

- local and international independent film screenings

- and eco-fashion shows


As immediate experience and personal exchange fuels individual and community action, all GtB events are designed to engage positive social interaction. GtB has helped strengthen and establish ties between diverse cross-sections of Beijing's "green" community over the years. Youthful and youth oriented, the network has included students from 8 of the capital's top universities and high-schools, with well over 500 young people directly involved in GtB's creative efforts since Day 1. What's more, GtB boasts 500+ team members and contributors who hail from across China, as well as from every continent around the globe.

GtB has been a catalyst for collaboration and change, encouraging more than 5,000 others from around the world to join and contribute to (both) the local and global sustainability movement. GtB aims to continue broadening its reach as an international network, increase further involvement throughout China, and present better community eco-art projects, ideas, and events this year in Beijing.

But GtB can't do much without YOU!!!!!

What We Need & What You Get

Help us keep GtB's good green ship afloat by supporting this campaign. Based on previous years' experience and the wish-list for 2012, we need a minimum of $5,000 to continue operations this year, which will help cover the following:

- recycled paper and soy ink promotional materials ($300)

- event venue and insurance costs ($500)

- art and supply storage expenses/fees ($500)

- web hosting and necessary upgrades for our open-information source online platform ($700)

- equipment and transportation rental ($800)

- volunteer stipends ($1,000)

- art scholarships and supplies ($1,200)

 

Thanks to our generous and green-hearted members, GtB will award a number of "perks" to our contributors from around the world. Give what you can and in turn you'll get one of our many fabulous green treats listed to the right! GtB promises you'll feel good and green when you give.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Beyond financial contributions, GtB needs your help spreading the word! If you haven't already, please sign-up as a member of the GtB website (it's FREE!), "like" us on Facebook, join us on Douban, or follow GtB on Weibo, and invite 5 friends to do the same. Once you're there, please share your green ideas and promote your green events within our network! GtB is always grateful to receive all kinds of various green gifts and energy.

story:
Short Summary

    • Rony Lamur is a son of middle class working family, born in Haiti. Spent most of his life in Brooklyn, New York, where he encounters many bad experiences and friends. After realizing the need to improve himself, he moved to Arizona where he received two bachelor degrees, one in political sciences and one in French at the University of Arizona. He also received his masters in Educational Leadership from Northern Arizona University. Rony Lamur founded United Youth of Tomorrow Inc, which is a foundation designed to help less fortunate kids and young adults around the globe. Rony Lamur, went back to Haiti in 2011 to help out after the devastated earthquake. Rony Lamur is also very active in his community and beyond. He works with many different organizations such as the Bridge Ministry which feeds about 500 to 700 homeless every Sunday in the downtown Phoenix area. Rony Lamur is also mentoring and many children and their families from all across the states.
  • Here in the United States, we have many options when it comes to clean drinking water.  We each has a brand preference, a color preference and or even a flavor preference.  However, many of us are not aware that not too far from us in Haiti, our neighbors, our brothers, sisters are dying at a very fast daily rate due to lack of clean, safe drinking water.  With this project, we will dig a well and build a water station which will provide clean drinking water to about 70,000 Haitians.  This water station will not only provide clean drinking water but it will more importantly save lives and help with agriculture as well. Your help is very crucial in making this project a reality.  No donation is too small nor too big.
  • With a donation of any amount, you will save many lives.  This project will not become a reality without your help.  Please partner up with us by making a donation and helping us spread the words in your community, your work, your church and all.  Together we can make a difference and save lives......
  • This project will cost approximately $12,500. Every penny will go to the project.  The estimated amount will cover: 
  •                         1) The digging of the water well
  •                          2) The construction of the water station
  •                         3) materials for the projects
  •                         4) Labor

  • As a contributor and partner of this project, we will build a mural with your names on it as our sponsor.  You will also receive thank you letters and pictures from the residents of Masson where the station will be built. 
  • Any amout raised will go toward starting the project.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • The realization of this project highly depend on your partnership.  You can be a partner by sharing and spreading the words within your circles, your friends and family, your work and other social media.
  • where you are talking about this project, use the indiegogo share tools to make it easier.

story:
A big hello from Permaculture farmers in El Salvador!

When you think of the small Central American country El Salvador, what is the first thing that comes to mind? For most people it is images of the massacres, disappearances and violence it suffered during the civil war of 1980s – and most recently gang violence that has made El Salvador one of the most dangerous counties in the world. The Permaculture Institute of El Salvador (IPES) is trying to change that by planting new images – images of hope and the real alternatives we have been building the past 10 years since the Permaculture Institute was founded. 

A decade of experimenting, demonstrating and teaching natural ways of living and farming and finally our Government and UN agencies are showing interest.

But right at this crucial moment, we are running out of funds. We are at the “tipping point” and just need one big push from our friends.

Will you help us keep the permaculture movement alive in El Salvador?

A movement of subsistence farmers

We are a growing movement of subsistence farmers from the northern highlands, the indigenous Kakawira lands, the coastal plains and lakeside villages of El Salvador. With support from our friends around the world, we are building networks of families and villages, of women and young people – sharing seeds and sharing knowledge of how to live wisely and care for the land that feeds us.

Permaculture enables farmers to experiment and share knowledge and seeds in an ever expanding, self-replicating system of mutual aid. A total investment of £260 per family per year over three years can lead to an improvement in family income of approximately £600 per year thereafter.

Spreading the wisdom

Permaculture reminds us of the simple practical wisdom of our grandparents – of how to make the very best of our small plots of land. We’re improving our soil, diversifying our crops, cleaning our water sources, recycling our waste and planting medicinal gardens. We have demonstration plots in hundreds of communities to show what can be done and our Education Centre in Suchitoto is visited by thousands of people and organisations every year, all looking for solutions to our country’s terrible poverty and environmental vulnerability.

 We need your help

We’re all volunteers – women, men and young people – and whilst we’re waiting for our Government and development agencies to back up their interest with financial support, we need $25,000 to keep going. We need money for transport to teach in new communities; some small expenses to pay someone else to work our land whilst we are teaching; and money to keep our Demonstration Site and small office open. 

Will you support us through this tipping point in our work and help us transform our war torn, climate stricken country into an example of what ordinary people can do for themselves?

If you want to help…

  • Then press the “add to favourites” and the “like” button this site. This will boost our “gogofactor” on Indiegogo.com and up the chances for being noticed by more people.
  • Help create awareness about what we’re doing by linking to this site on your Facebook, Twitter or home page. We need all the attention we can get!
  • Send a mail to volunteer@permacultura.com.sv and we’ll forward e-mails and newsletters to you, which you can send out to your network.
  • Create a fundraising event, make a garage or bake sale or have an auction of promises.
  • Give a donation by pressing the button on the right side of this page.

 Impact of donations

  • $5 will teach one farming family to how to make compost
  • $20 will provide a family with climate resistant seeds 
  • $50 will help 10 families get their produce to the local farmers market
  • $100 will pay for 20 leaders to meet and support each other to teach Permaculture in their villages
  • $200 will fund a visit of 50 famers to our Demonstration Site
  • $500 will teach training skills to 6 Permaculture Apprentices
  • $1,000 will pay for a volunteer to teach a whole village for a year

 

To learn more about our work, visit our website at www.permacultura.com.sv

 

IPES in the media:

The Esperanza Project: Permaculture Institute heals the wounds of war

Permanent Culture Now: Planting seeds of hope in El Salvador

story:
About PLAN: The Post-Landfill Action Network

PLAN is a start-up nonprofit that helps college students create programs that reduce waste on campus. We provide start-up funding, leadership training, educational resources and discounts to help launch and support self-sustaining, student-led waste reduction programs in campus communities. Our vision is a nation-wide movement of student leaders working together to build a post-landfill society where the very concept of waste is obsolete. Your support will help kickstart this project and allow us to reach a point of self-suitability in just a few years.

We are excited to announce that Tom's of Maine will be matching up to $20,000 in contributions! We are very excited to have this pioneering company join our mission to build a zero-waste world. Please contribute now to double your impact!

Table of Contents: Click To Jump!

  1. Upcycled Perks for Donors
  2. How Plan Started
  3. Our Phased Approach
  4. Why We Need a PLAN
  5. Our Work So Far
  6. What Your Donation Supports
  7. How You Can Help
  8. Our Board of Directors, Advisors, and Community Supporters

Upcycled Perks for Donors

To say "thank you" for your donation, we've made a variety of upcycled gifts that you can choose from! Each of the items were handmade by PLAN volunteers using recycled materials, and will be sent out at the conclusion of the campaign in September. Below, you can see pictures of all the items, as well as a table that explains your choices at each donation level; or, see the perk listings on the right side of this page for more details about what you'll get. We'll reach out to you after you donate to determine what perks you would like to recieve.

You can also click here to skip this section and continue reading about PLAN instead.

How PLAN Started: Trash 2 Treasure at the University of New Hampshire (UNH T2T)

In 2010 a group of undergraduates at the University of New Hampshire noticed that students threw away thousands of reusable items when they moved out. They learned that each spring, the amount of waste sent to the local landfill jumped from 25 tons to a staggering 105 tons. 

The students fundraised over $9,000 to launch a program that diverted reusable goods away from the local landfill by collecting them in the spring and selling them at a yard sale over move-in weekend. The sale was an enormous success, earning more than enough to cover the program's costs. In its first 3 years, UNH T2T has:

  • Diverted over 100 tons of waste from UNH's waste stream
  • Achieved over $30,000 in sales
  • Donated 5 tons of food and clothing to local shelters
  • Saved UNH $10,000 in waste disposal costs
  • Saved students and families an estimated $125,000 by selling goods at steep discounts compared to local big box stores

Our Phased Approach

Following the early success of Trash 2 Treasure at UNH, the students behind the program began working to bring this initiative to other schools. They created PLAN: The Post-Landfill Action Network. PLAN will work with student groups and universities in each of three phases.

Phase 1: Accelerated Launch

Paying for year-one expenses like truck and storage rental is the largest barrier to starting a move-out waste reduction program. That’s where our Accelerated Launch program comes in. Through a competitive application process, we will identify student leaders to receive start-up funding to launch a PLAN program on their campus. We’ll work closely with those students and administrators to get the program off the ground so that it is self-sustaining by its second year. The application for Accelerated Launch is available now at PostLandfill.org/Apply!

Phase 2: Membership Network

For campuses with existing move-out waste reduction programs, we offer membership services that help students and universities expand and improve their ongoing initiatives. Membership benefits include consulting services, discounts on program costs like truck and storage rental, access to online resources and education, and other customized support.

Phase 3: Beyond the Sale

Reducing move-out waste is just the beginning. In Phase 3, we will guide student organizers through a step-by-step campus waste audit. We’ll work with students, administrators, and our network of sustainability partners to design new ways to reduce waste on campus year-round. Additionally, revenue from the yard sale can be used to fund new and innovative sustainability initiatives on campus like organic gardening or renewable energy generation.

Why We Need a PLAN

The way we use and dispose of Earth’s resources is fundamentally broken. We extract resources to make consumer goods, which soon end up in landfills. But our planet’s resources are not infinite, and our trash is toxic. Eliminating waste helps solve both ends of this problem. In the spirit of “think globally, act locally,” PLAN is beginning by tackling waste on college campuses – where students recognize that we must protect the planet we will inherit. 

Our Work So Far

Over a year ago, we began laying the foundation for the expansion of this program to the national scale. Today we have huge momentum, a dedicated team of organizers and advisors, and a wide network of supporters in the sustainability arena. Here are some of our recent successes:

  • Secured a 6-month residency at the New Hampshire Innovation and Commercialization Center, a shared working space in downtown Durham. 
  • Established a partnership agreement with the University of New Hampshire to pilot Phase 3 waste reduction initiatives and conduct a full waste audit. 
  • Received the $10,000 Samuel Huntington Public Service Award.
  • Established two paid PLAN internships supported by UNH’s Center on Social Innovation and Finance and the Steelman Fellowship through UNH’s College of Health and Human Services.

What Your Donation Supports

We’re passionate about helping other students bring this program to their campus – but to build out PLAN on a national scale, we need your support. Your donation will help kickstart our work as a national nonprofit. 

Together with a team of advisors in nonprofit management, business development and social entrepreneurship, we’ve put together a three year roadmap for PLAN, after which point we will be independently sustained by membership fees from the schools we work with. That roadmap has us on track to meet the following goals:

Year One: 3 new Accelerated Launch programs, 12 member schools
Year Two: 6 new Accelerated Launch programs, 24 member schools
Year Three: 8 new Accelerated Launch programs, 60 member schools

We can reduce thousands of tons of waste by reaching these schools – but first, we have to meet our fundraising goals. Your donation will support our ongoing development work including:

  • Creation of resources for students like best-practice guides and waste and sustainability fact sheets.
  • Outreach to university sustainability offices and direct engagement with student groups to identify common challenges and opportunities to launch new programs and improve and expand existing initiatives.
  • Development of our nonprofit business infrastructure including strategic and financial planning, incorporation and 501(c)(3) certification, web development, and more.
  • Expansion of our network of sustainable business partners including trucking, storage, waste-hauling, composting and recycling companies.

Additionally, IndieGoGo recieves a small percentage of funds raised as a platform fee. Reaching or exceeding our goal of $50,000 signficantly reduces this fee. Our goal reflects a very conservative projection for PLAN's growth – but there are dozens of schools who are eager to work with us. Exceeding our goal of $50,000 will allow us to reach more campuses more quickly and reduce far more waste on each campus. The more we raise, the more we can do!

Update [7/12/13]: Donations will pass through our nonprofit fiscal sponsor, Climate Counts. This allows your contribution to be tax deductible via Climate Counts' 501(c)(3) designation, while PLAN's own 501(c)(3) application is under review. 

How You Can Help

There are lots of ways you can support PLAN and this fundraising campaign. 

  • Donate! Your contribution will help us keep thousands of tons of toxic trash out of landfills near college communities. Every donation helps us reach our goal. Plus, you'll get some cool upcycled rewards handmade by PLAN volunteers!
  • Share this campaign on social media pages, by email, or by carefully reading the URL to your mom over the phone. Besides donating, sharing is the best thing you can do to help us meet our goal! Click to go to your Facebook or Twitter, and see below for a template post or email you can use to easily share this project.
  • Like PLAN on Facebook or follow us on Twitter so we can stay in touch!
  • Contact us! Do you know of a company who we should partner with, an artist who turns trash into treasures, or a student group ready to bring PLAN to their campus? Write to Alex@PostLandfill.org.

To make sharing easy, we've written out some text that you can copy, paste, and adapt as you please. Thank you for sharing this fundraiser widely!

Dear _______,

I am writing to share with you a project that I feel is very imporant. PLAN: The Post-Landfill Action Network is a nonprofit being launched by a group of recent graduates from the University of New Hampshire. As students, they started a program to reduce waste by collecting items students would have otherwise thrown out at the end of the school year then selling it all at a yard sale over move-in weekend. Their initiative at UNH was so successful that they've created PLAN, which will provide start-up funding and support to students at other schools who want to create waste reduction initiatives on their own campuses. 

To cover start-up expenses and the first round of funding for schools, PLAN launched an online fundraiser to raise $50,000 by September 5. They're off to a good start but still need more support – so I'm writing to ask your help. Visit http://igg.me/at/PLAN to see a video from their team and read more about the project. They're also offering handmade upcycled items as perks for donors. If you're not able to make a donation, you can also support PLAN by passing this along to 5 people who you know particularly care about the planet. You can also like and follow them on Facebook and Twitter! Thank you!

The People Behind PLAN

Our Board of Directors

Our Team of Advisors

Supporters in the Community and at UNH

Credits

We'd like to extend our sincere thanks to everyone who has helped shape PLAN and to everyone who has contributed to the success of UNH Trash 2 Treasure over the last three years. We would especially like to thank the following individuals for their contributions to this page:

Our IndieGoGo video was produced and edited by Scott Ripley.

The photos of our upcycled perks were taken by Raya Al-Hashmi. Raya is a recent UNH graduate and an aspiring photojournalist – check out her website here.

We would also like to thank to our local supporters: Eco Kids, Scythe Supply, Charlie Preston, Devitt Liptak Design and Déjà vu Consignment Shoppe

 

Click here to return to the top of the page to donate now!

story:
Want to Do Some Good?

A third of the people on the planet are in hand-to-mouth poverty. 
Hopeless, isn't it? 
But what if you could change that - How would you do it?
In the 70's we had the Green Revolution. Today we have Super Hybrid rice. Introduce ultra-high-yield rice together with Permaculture principles to the poorest subsistence farmers in the Philippines and turn around millions of lives.

Here is what we're doing:

We are introducing a permaculture system using nitrogen fixing shrubs to create highly fertile terraced land on which to grow Super Hybrid rice as a cash crop. 
               


              Lucaena trees fix nitrogen for crops in terraces

The project aims to provide farmers with a profitable source of income ( super hybrid rice) to replace their bare subsistence on normal rice farming then manage the profits to repair their "slash and burn" hill plots and turn them into more productive, permaculture farms. Rice is their traditional mainstay and cash crop so we reasoned that trebling rice yield would provide the necessary foundation for all else to follow.

By enlisting the cooperation of key government stakeholders we now have a formidable team to make it happen.

Ploughing field in preparation for planting

Sprouted hybrid rice ready for planting

Direct seeding of sprouted rice in prepared bed

Hybrid Rice Production, Aklan/Antique Provinces Business Proposal

Title of the Project: Hybrid Rice Production Project

Proponent: One Good Idea, Australia, a philanthropic group directed by Manfred Kemter & George Parry

Beneficiaries Barangay, Municipality Province: Aklan, Region VI Antique,

Contact Person: Manfred Kemter: email: mkemter@ozemail.com.au

Funding: One Good Idea: George Parry: georgeparry@iprimus.com.au

Project description

The ultimate goal of the One Good Idea group is to help reduce poverty and unemployment by developing agri – enterprises, making food plentiful and enhancing the enabling mechanisms for economic activities.

Rationale for proceeding

The cultivation of hybrid rice varieties can result in significantly increased yield, and income, for the same area of land under production. This hybrid rice project aims to help increase the average household income of farmer beneficiaries by approximately 30% and generate employment during project construction, farm production and off – farm activities.

This proposed project on hybrid rice production aims to maximize the potential of agricultural land in Aklan and Antique. The project intends to provide demonstration farms to Agricultural Reform Beneficiaries  (ARBs) and assist them with appropriate technology and extend financial assistance by providing inputs through a soft loan scheme.

Philippines Management team

Directors and consultants

  •   Manuel A. Boboy Velaco, Provincial Head of Department of agrarian Reform (DAR) – Antique. Office located in San Jose, Antique.

  •   Dr . Paterno I. Rebuelta, Rice Specalist/Faculty, College of Agriculture, Forestry and Environmental Sciences, Aklan State University (ASU), Banga, Aklan

  •   Engr. Ernesto ‘Estong’ Anino DAR Aklan

  •   PARPO I Valentin ‘Bong’ Magante DAR Aklan

  •   Jennifer Broadbent, DAR Aklan

  •   Manfred Kemter Consultant Coordinator 

    Australian co-ordinator: George Parry

Stakeholders

  • ·Farmers and Cooperatives in Aklan and Pandan Antique
  • ·The participants were selected by officers of DAR Aklan and Antique, Aklan State University and Abante - a NGO with 4,000 members.
  • ·The participants from DAR and Abante training engaged in consultation activities with the community to demonstrate their engagement with the project. They were assessed in particular for their preparedness to change practices.

·Hybrid rice production will assist the community Initially by more than doubling the normal yield.

The project will initially involve five (5) (Agricultural Reform Beneficiaries) ARB farmer-cooperators from the (Agricultural Reform Cooperative) ARC. Each of the hybrid rice farmer cooperators will utilize at least a hectare of irrigated rice land.

Cooperators for the Organic Fertilizer Production will be identified by the subject organization (Abante) as this will be co-managed by the cooperative.

The initial cooperators will be selected by DAR and Abante representatives based on heir preparedness to adopt new farming techniques.

Project overview

Objectives

This project aims to improve farm productivity and sustain agricultural production for increased household income of the members of the cooperative to improve the quality of their lives as well as to develop their knowledge and skills in Rice Production.

Specifically, this projects aims:

  1. a)  To identify, train and supervise 5 ARB farmer-cooperators on Hybrid Rice Production;
  2. b)  To plant, maintain and harvest demonstration farms using Chinese Super Hybrid and Borrocai 300 rice seed.
  3. c)  To increase Rice Production from 2.8 MT/Ha/Cropping to at least 5 Metric Tonnes/Ha/Cropping;
  4. d)  To increase farm household income by 30% through sales of rice of at least P40,000 per cropping;
  1. e)  To encourage other ( Agrarian Reform Beneficiaries) ARBs to adopt the project; and
  2. f)  To adopt roll-over and replication scheme for the project

Proposed timetable of deliverables

  • ·We have commenced a total of 5 Ha test planting for this current June/July season with a forecast October harvest.
  • ·The next rice cropping season is October to December 2014 (3 months).
  • ·Assumption that funds will be available by August 2014 to begin project.

Aklan State University and DAR

Roll-Over Scheme

Aside from the training and techno-transfer, each of the cooperators will be provided with inputs based on the computed requirements of their respective demo farm. These inputs will be given as a soft loan granted to the cooperators through the proponent organization with no interest payable after 1 cropping cycle. These schemes are included in the PSP approved by the BOD and presented to the General Assembly.

Proceeds generated from the Rice Production Project will be used by the proponent organization as a capital to other target project beneficiaries. After one (1) cropping cycle, new set of cooperators is expected to implement and replicate the project. Five new cooperators are expected to replicate the project on its second year and another 5 for the cropping third year.

Employment Generation

This project will generate at least 50 full-time-equivalent jobs from the 5 identified cooperators. Each cooperator would at least need a hand / or an assistant especially in the land preparation. The technology to be adopted from this project entails intensive but efficient labor system. Land Preparation, Tilling, Basal fertilizer application, seed soaking, sowing, transplanting, fertilizing, pesticide application, harvesting, etc. would at least require 10 employees per hectare of demo farms totaling to 50 jobs for the entire one (1) project cycle. For the 2nd project cycle, a new set of cooperators or replicators will be identified employing a possible additional job generation of at least 50 more.

Environmental sustainability

This project will encourage adoption of environment-friendly activities. Use of organic fertilizers and organic based insecticides and pesticides will be promoted. Part of the training module would include a discussion on the practice of natural farming methods and application of organic methods using protocols established under the SALT (Sloping Agricultural Land technique) strategy.

As can be seen, the use of new Chinese Super Hybrid rice with a permaculture polyculture, incorporating piggeries, chickens and nitrogen fixing food crops will eventually eliminate costly and destructive chemical fertilisers. With input from the DAR and the agriculture Dept of Aklan U we plan to turn around the destructive farming practices used by hill farmers and help them to a prosperous and ecologically sound farming life.

Manfred's Story

                                              Manfred Kemter
The driving force behind this project is Manfred Kemter. Manfred has spent his life developing permaculture principles to build resilience and self-sufficiency. Here's his story:

I was born at the outbreak of WWII in Biburg, Bavaria and spent my first 13 years on my grandmother's 35 Ha farm which had provided total self-sufficiency for my extended family for over 1000 years. Ours was a rural community based on total self-sufficiency. Our extended family lived on the family farm and gained all of our sustenance from 35Ha of agricultural land which had been farmed for 1000 years using permaculture principles, surviving the 100 years war, the 30 years war, Depression, hyperinflation, famine, WWI and WWII and feeding a large community of starving people after the destruction of Augsburg in WWII. Aside from rain and sunshine, there was no off-farm input. And nothing was wasted. 

     Our 35Ha smallholding was completely self-sufficient

In our community we all worked cooperatively to ensure community survival. There were no men because of the war so I went out, from early childhood with a cart and we harvested hay or potatoes, wheat or rye. Because of the weather the animals were always stabled so we took the feed to the animals rather than letting them wander the fields. This meant we maximised crop production as the animals did not trample any crops. This had the added benefit that all the biomass from the fields was now concentrated in the stables. Manure and deep litter  were a wonderful resource that we applied directly to our crops. The effluent from the stables and from our toilet went directly to a holding tank and was applied to the fields. Stable straw was changed daily and used as mulch. Every waste product was recycled. We had no artificial fertiliser. It was all organic and balanced. As a child it was my job to go out with buckets and barrows and spread this compost. The fields grew lush and green and the soil was dark and rich, full of humus and worms. The fields were ploughed in the Autumn and the compost was spread in the furrows. The snow would then cover the fields and in the Spring the fields were harrowed again and planted. 

       

The farm had an annual cycle and it involved everything, pigs, chickens, eggs, ducks, cows, crops, fruit, pasture. The family's meat needs were met by our livestock. We had an oversupply of everything -fruit, berries, grains, vegetables, meat, eggs etc, and whatever was harvested in abundance was preserved. Apples were crushed into cider, fruit was dried or stored in barrels in the cellar along with the potatoes. Vegetables were pickled. We cut ice from a pool of water that the community used that was kept over winter in an underground cavern to keep the cellar cool. A team of people would go down into the cave and cut blocks of ice with saws and carry them up to the cart, distributing them to all the farmers. 

                                 Food stored in root cellar

We stored grain and fruit, meat and vegetables in the cellar. We made and stored sausages and smoked ham, bacon, dried meat, poultry etc which we hung in the cellar. We pickled, dried, stored everything - to get the last ounce of productivity from our farm. We had no electricity and no refrigeration so we stored everything in this way. We baked our own bread from our own grain once a week - 2kg loaves of black rye bread - you can still buy these in specialist bakers in Sydney if you know where to look. Any crops not eaten by people such as what we called 'pig potatoes' were boiled in a vat and compressed into a cake then used as high-energy stock feed. 

I attended the St Georg school in Augsburg until I came to Australia at age 13. The history of the city and it's numerous great citizens (Luther, Diesel etc) had a lasting impact on my life and the philosophy I developed. The industry and the charity of a wealthy 17th century philanthropic Augsburg family, the Fuggers were upheld as ideals in my schooling.

                                     Augsburg today

The Fuggerei is the worlds first community housing project founded 500 years ago. It is still functioning today. The annual rent was and remains a Rheinish florin, which was then approximately a week's wages for a craftsman. It was left this way over the centuries implementing the core philosophy of "assistance so others can help themselves". The modern Fuggerei thus helps to relieve the city of its welfare obligations. My experience of this influenced my personal philosophy. I went on in Australia to develop disabled group housing which relieved the state of much of its financial burden by introducing Bill Glaser's Choice Theory approach to personal responsibility and self reliance, enabling previously highly dependent people to achieve personal independence and pride.

                  Fuggerei community housing - Augsburg

On the farm there was not much time for play, there was something for me to do wherever I went. What I liked most and what I remember from my earliest time was doing the chores in the farmhouse. Feeding the chickens, collecting eggs, feeding the pigs, cows and oxen. I loved keeping up the firewood to the kitchen and the huge oven in the living room. There was an abundance of berries to pick and fallen fruit to gather in the orchard; some for jam others for cider and my favourite, green-apple jelly.

As I got older, I was involved in all facets of the mixed farm operation. Harvest and planting were the busiest times, however preparing the soil in autumn and spring involved the spreading of stable manure to compost into the ploughed soil under the snow and then boost the new crop and pastures with liquid stable waste into the summer. Timing was the key at all stages to ensure a maximum quality harvest. 

The days were long and only Sundays and festival days were times of respite and fun. The morning would start at 4.30am with prayer, breakfast and then the trip to the fields for a sunrise start. Morning tea then a two hour lunch break at home to avoid the beat of the day. Usually the day would end at 6.30 to 7pm. Schooldays were a break in the routine once the wartime evacuations were over but holidays were long and hot on in the summer. 

It was towards the end of the evacuation period that I witnessed the bombing of Augsburg which annihilated half the city and most of its industry. 16 Jul 1944 A total of 1,087 B-17 Flying Fortress bombers USAAF Eighth Air Force attacked Germany in three waves (407, 238, and 407 bombers, respectively), escorted by 240, 214, and 169 fighters, respectively, with most of the bombers targeting Munich, Stuggart, Augsburg, and Saarbrucken; a total of 11 bombers and 3 fighters were lost. For 3 days after the bombing of Augsburg I witnessed a constant steam of people passing and visiting our farm in search of food.

                                       

                                   Destruction of Augsburg

Whatever else the defeat may have meant to the Germans, it meant that they were going to go hungry, probably for a long time; and they were hungry already. The SHAEF maximum daily ration for normal consumers was 1,550 calories, but the amounts actually being issued ranged from 804 calories in Hesse and Hesse-Nassau to 1,150 calories in parts of the Rhineland. The normal consumers were the new proletariat of the occupation. The gentry were the "heavy" and "very heavy" workers, railroad workers and miners for instance, who could get up to 2,800 calories. The out-and-out aristocrats were the self-suppliers, that is, the farmers, who did not have to trouble themselves with ration cards. The normal consumer was not starving, but if he subsisted entirely on his ration, which no one really expected him to do, he was very close to it. A typical week's ration issued during May of 1945 consisted of the following: bread, 3 pounds; meat, 4 ounces; butter and fat, 2 ounces; sugar, 7 ounces; macaroni and spaghetti, 5 ounces; potatoes, 6 pounds; some cereal (added to the children's ration), 6 ounces; milk (only for children up to six), 1 quart. The total was less than 1,000 calories per day, and the difference was made up by adding a few ounces of green vegetables "provided trucks can be found to haul them and provided the people can eat rhubarb without sugar." 

                                           

Permaculture using Keyline and Sloping Agricultural Land Technology

In Germany by the end of the war there were no men left! Then Polish and Russian prisoners who helped out during the war had returned home and my uncle, my father's brother, came back from Siberia in 1951. He was part of a three hundred thousand (300,000) man army captured by the Russians of which only 7,000 returned. He lived to age 86. When my cousin married, the agricultural land was added to her husband's estate as was the custom in rural inheritance practice.

When we arrived in Sydney Dec 25, 1952, it was a shock to observe the monotony of the country on the train journey from Sydney to Geelong in Victoria; a journey lasting beyond 24 hours. The countryside was either bush or brown gravel; the land had been overstocked and eaten down to the roots. The few remaining sheep mere skeletons; either living or dead. A scene I was never to forget. 

Ten years later, when I had my own farm, I rotated the cattle when they had eaten down to four or five centimetres with a layer of organic matter underneath that of at least 2cm to reduce evaporation and encourage the development of natural nutrients. The other thing that left me with a lasting impression was that every arable piece of ground and most of the slopes had been cleared of trees or ringbarked; the whole trip was dotted with thousands of bleached, decaying trunks that had been killed a hundred years before to promote growth of grass or wheat. Later, on our own property I promoted the growth of the most valuable trees and paid for the full purchase price with the trees I culled. Coincidentally, all old gnarled and twisted trees were left for homes and shelter for a diverse assortment of wildlife. I later had the property declared as a sanctuary. The trees have added 50 years of growth and remain there to this day. There were two major commercial benefits from this approach; The growth in timber added more value than the land was worth and later when I subdivided the property the blocks sold quicker and brought a better price than any surrounding, cleared subdivision.


I went to school in Australia for four years, worked on a farm after school every day and then for four years after I left school. After eight years I managed that farm and as my parting act-exported bulbs to Holland. We became so competitive that we bought out the other bulb growers in Geelong and supplied flower bulbs Australia wide. This was done by mechanising, improvising and economising. We saved labour costs by mechanising the sowing, weeding and harvesting process; then added value by refocusing the workers into adding value by grading and packaging for our customers. We conceived and manufactured specialised machines from old car and machinery parts and streamlined the packaging process. The greatest return came from developing the acquired land into smaller holdings or rural subdivisions as well as stocking the more viable 1,000 to 10,000 acre with mainly sheep from drought affected NSW.

In 1959 I left to complete my schooling and learn English by focusing on language and science in a four year BA Ed course. During this period I studied Australian farming methods and practices and concluded that most farmers in Australia don't enjoy the the lifestyle and quality of life of the average German farmer. The most successful operators  here are either large, mechanised and well schooled family organisations or companies employing agriculture and business graduates. After that are the traders who buy run down, debt or drought affected farms; engage in minimal farming, window dress and wait for a good season to sell.  In Germany, farms are long term enterprises.


             

                                      Rice planting - Philippines

Farming formed a large part of my life in Australia. All my experience, my study and my work centred around primary production, I exported meat and live sheep, studied tropical pasture development and the various uses of nitrogen fixing, leguminous shrubs and trees. I attended field days in Northern Queensland and the Northern Territory and the highlight in my memory was planning and conducting a 10 day tour of tropical farming enterprises. This involved Kings Ranch Fullers seeds and a day in Humpty Doo with James Gayoso catching wild buffalo for export. The tour was arranged for Seichi Kawai, the world's biggest emerald dealer at the time. His farm near Bogota spanned the size of a small country and he planned to develop this into a modern, productive agricultural enterprise. He imported farm machinery and seeds as well as cattle, suitable for tropical primary production.

Over the last 10 years here in The Philippines due to rapid population growth and the desperate need to feed this population, the forests have been degraded through the practice of slash and burn. The topsoil has been progressively lost and less than 20% of natural forest remains.  Rice is the mainstay and if the season is good the farmers eat until the next harvest. Competition from cheap imports of rice, the cost of production, especially the cost of fertiliser, has pushed them further into poverty. The typhoon wiped out more than 60% of the country's crop. With the help of a group of philanthropists, loosely formed into "the One Good Idea Group" I have moved to the Aklan  Region in the Philippines to introduce a comprehensive program designed to bring prosperity to these victims of centuries of archaic practices and finally a devastating storm. The key to this program is the introduction of high yielding Super Hybrid rice and from there the introduction of proven methods of Key-line farming, focusing on the use of organic fertiliser production and crop diversification.

                             Vegetable farming in Cebu

Now at the age of 75 I am engaged in the most ambitious and the most worthwhile endeavour of my life. I have seen the plight of the poor hill farmers in the provinces in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda) and believe with the help of the team we have assembled that we can turn their lives around.

We can't do it alone, but together - with your help - we will change the world for the better.

Brian Martin, ESP Gallery Marrickville says:

       Wishing you well in all your goals & endeavours Manfred !

It was inspiring to meet you and I will always wish you safe passage as you go about your good works around the world.

My personal view is that if someone is making the world a better place, then I don’t care what beliefs or motivation drive them towards it. Results matter more than belief systems.

To anyone who does not know Manfred Kemter, he is a retired businessman from Australia, he originally came from Germany as a child, he has seen the worst that civilisation can do as a small child on the outskirts of Augsburg, and he has aspired to be the best that we can do as an adult. He has single-handedly brought prosperity to poor villagers in the Philippines after the devastation of cyclones in recent years.

I met Manfred because he lived across the back lane from ESP Gallery in Marrickville Sydney. We had many long discussions about humanitarian aid, and direct action.

I will miss Manfred’s discussions, but wish him the best of success with his direct action approach to fundraising and personally helping hill villages & Cooperatives with the introduction of high yielding Chinese Super Hybrid Rice and Key-line permaculture; ensuring their ongoing supply of food & income through improved cultivation practices and in partnership with progressive minds from the Department of Agrarian Reform and the University of Aklan to teach a shift in the perception of prosperity from having many children to education and entrepreneurship.

Auf wiedersehen Manfred
story_txt:
Want to Do Some Good?
A third of the people on the planet are in hand-to-mouth poverty. Hopeless, isn't it? But what if you could change that - How would you do it?In the 70's we had the Green Revolution. Today we have Super Hybrid rice. Introduce ultra-high-yield rice together with Permaculture principles to the poorest subsistence farmers in the Philippines and turn around millions of lives.Here is what we're doing:We are introducing a permaculture system using nitrogen fixing shrubs to create highly fertile terraced land on which to grow Super Hybrid rice as a cash crop. 

               
              Lucaena trees fix nitrogen for crops in terraces
The project aims to provide farmers with a profitable source of income ( super hybrid rice) to replace their bare subsistence on normal rice farming then manage the profits to repair their "slash and burn" hill plots and turn them into more productive, permaculture farms. Rice is their traditional mainstay and cash crop so we reasoned that trebling rice yield would provide the necessary foundation for all else to follow.
By enlisting the cooperation of key government stakeholders we now have a formidable team to make it happen.

Ploughing field in preparation for planting
Sprouted hybrid rice ready for planting

Direct seeding of sprouted rice in prepared bed

Hybrid Rice Production, Aklan/Antique Provinces Business Proposal
Title of the Project: Hybrid Rice Production Project
Proponent: One Good Idea, Australia, a philanthropic group directed by Manfred Kemter & George Parry
Beneficiaries Barangay, Municipality Province: Aklan, Region VI Antique,
Contact Person: Manfred Kemter: email: mkemter@ozemail.com.au
Funding: One Good Idea: George Parry: georgeparry@iprimus.com.au
Project description
The ultimate goal of the One Good Idea group is to help reduce poverty and unemployment by developing agri – enterprises, making food plentiful and enhancing the enabling mechanisms for economic activities.
Rationale for proceeding
The cultivation of hybrid rice varieties can result in significantly increased yield, and income, for the same area of land under production. This hybrid rice project aims to help increase the average household income of farmer beneficiaries by approximately 30% and generate employment during project construction, farm production and off – farm activities.
This proposed project on hybrid rice production aims to maximize the potential of agricultural land in Aklan and Antique. The project intends to provide demonstration farms to Agricultural Reform Beneficiaries  (ARBs) and assist them with appropriate technology and extend financial assistance by providing inputs through a soft loan scheme.



Philippines Management team
Directors and consultants

  Manuel A. Boboy Velaco, Provincial Head of Department of agrarian Reform (DAR) – Antique. Office located in San Jose, Antique.
  Dr . Paterno I. Rebuelta, Rice Specalist/Faculty, College of Agriculture, Forestry and Environmental Sciences, Aklan State University (ASU), Banga, Aklan
  Engr. Ernesto ‘Estong’ Anino DAR Aklan
  PARPO I Valentin ‘Bong’ Magante DAR Aklan
  Jennifer Broadbent, DAR Aklan

  Manfred Kemter Consultant Coordinator 
Australian co-ordinator: George Parry



Stakeholders

·Farmers and Cooperatives in Aklan and Pandan Antique
·The participants were selected by officers of DAR Aklan and Antique, Aklan State University and Abante - a NGO with 4,000 members.

·The participants from DAR and Abante training engaged in consultation activities with the community to demonstrate their engagement with the project. They were assessed in particular for their preparedness to change practices.
·Hybrid rice production will assist the community Initially by more than doubling the normal yield.
The project will initially involve five (5) (Agricultural Reform Beneficiaries) ARB farmer-cooperators from the (Agricultural Reform Cooperative) ARC. Each of the hybrid rice farmer cooperators will utilize at least a hectare of irrigated rice land.
Cooperators for the Organic Fertilizer Production will be identified by the subject organization (Abante) as this will be co-managed by the cooperative.
The initial cooperators will be selected by DAR and Abante representatives based on heir preparedness to adopt new farming techniques.

Environmental sustainability
This project will encourage adoption of environment-friendly activities. Use of organic fertilizers and organic based insecticides and pesticides will be promoted. Part of the training module would include a discussion on the practice of natural farming methods and application of organic methods using protocols established under the SALT (Sloping Agricultural Land technique) strategy.
