As can be seen, the use of new Chinese Super Hybrid rice with a permaculture polyculture, incorporating piggeries, chickens and nitrogen fixing food crops will eventually eliminate costly and destructive chemical fertilisers. With input from the DAR and the agriculture Dept of Aklan U we plan to turn around the destructive farming practices used by hill farmers and help them to a prosperous and ecologically sound farming life.

Manfred's Story


                                              Manfred Kemter

The driving force behind this project is Manfred Kemter. Manfred has spent his life developing permaculture principles to build resilience and self-sufficiency. Here's his story:

I was born at the outbreak of WWII in Biburg, Bavaria and spent my first 13 years on my grandmother's 35 Ha farm which had provided total self-sufficiency for my extended family for over 1000 years. Ours was a rural community based on total self-sufficiency. Our extended family lived on the family farm and gained all of our sustenance from 35Ha of agricultural land which had been farmed for 1000 years using permaculture principles, surviving the 100 years war, the 30 years war, Depression, hyperinflation, famine, WWI and WWII and feeding a large community of starving people after the destruction of Augsburg in WWII. Aside from rain and sunshine, there was no off-farm input. And nothing was wasted. 


     Our 35Ha smallholding was completely self-sufficient
In our community we all worked cooperatively to ensure community survival. There were no men because of the war so I went out, from early childhood with a cart and we harvested hay or potatoes, wheat or rye. Because of the weather the animals were always stabled so we took the feed to the animals rather than letting them wander the fields. This meant we maximised crop production as the animals did not trample any crops. This had the added benefit that all the biomass from the fields was now concentrated in the stables. Manure and deep litter  were a wonderful resource that we applied directly to our crops. The effluent from the stables and from our toilet went directly to a holding tank and was applied to the fields. Stable straw was changed daily and used as mulch. Every waste product was recycled. We had no artificial fertiliser. It was all organic and balanced. As a child it was my job to go out with buckets and barrows and spread this compost. The fields grew lush and green and the soil was dark and rich, full of humus and worms. The fields were ploughed in the Autumn and the compost was spread in the furrows. The snow would then cover the fields and in the Spring the fields were harrowed again and planted. 

        The farm had an annual cycle and it involved everything, pigs, chickens, eggs, ducks, cows, crops, fruit, pasture. The family's meat needs were met by our livestock. We had an oversupply of everything -fruit, berries, grains, vegetables, meat, eggs etc, and whatever was harvested in abundance was preserved. Apples were crushed into cider, fruit was dried or stored in barrels in the cellar along with the potatoes. Vegetables were pickled. We cut ice from a pool of water that the community used that was kept over winter in an underground cavern to keep the cellar cool. A team of people would go down into the cave and cut blocks of ice with saws and carry them up to the cart, distributing them to all the farmers. 

                                 Food stored in root cellar

We stored grain and fruit, meat and vegetables in the cellar. We made and stored sausages and smoked ham, bacon, dried meat, poultry etc which we hung in the cellar. We pickled, dried, stored everything - to get the last ounce of productivity from our farm. We had no electricity and no refrigeration so we stored everything in this way. We baked our own bread from our own grain once a week - 2kg loaves of black rye bread - you can still buy these in specialist bakers in Sydney if you know where to look. Any crops not eaten by people such as what we called 'pig potatoes' were boiled in a vat and compressed into a cake then used as high-energy stock feed. 

I attended the St Georg school in Augsburg until I came to Australia at age 13. The history of the city and it's numerous great citizens (Luther, Diesel etc) had a lasting impact on my life and the philosophy I developed. The industry and the charity of a wealthy 17th century philanthropic Augsburg family, the Fuggers were upheld as ideals in my schooling.


                                     Augsburg today
The Fuggerei is the worlds first community housing project founded 500 years ago. It is still functioning today. The annual rent was and remains a Rheinish florin, which was then approximately a week's wages for a craftsman. It was left this way over the centuries implementing the core philosophy of "assistance so others can help themselves". The modern Fuggerei thus helps to relieve the city of its welfare obligations. My experience of this influenced my personal philosophy. I went on in Australia to develop disabled group housing which relieved the state of much of its financial burden by introducing Bill Glaser's Choice Theory approach to personal responsibility and self reliance, enabling previously highly dependent people to achieve personal independence and pride.


                  Fuggerei community housing - Augsburg
On the farm there was not much time for play, there was something for me to do wherever I went. What I liked most and what I remember from my earliest time was doing the chores in the farmhouse. Feeding the chickens, collecting eggs, feeding the pigs, cows and oxen. I loved keeping up the firewood to the kitchen and the huge oven in the living room. There was an abundance of berries to pick and fallen fruit to gather in the orchard; some for jam others for cider and my favourite, green-apple jelly.
As I got older, I was involved in all facets of the mixed farm operation. Harvest and planting were the busiest times, however preparing the soil in autumn and spring involved the spreading of stable manure to compost into the ploughed soil under the snow and then boost the new crop and pastures with liquid stable waste into the summer. Timing was the key at all stages to ensure a maximum quality harvest. 
The days were long and only Sundays and festival days were times of respite and fun. The morning would start at 4.30am with prayer, breakfast and then the trip to the fields for a sunrise start. Morning tea then a two hour lunch break at home to avoid the beat of the day. Usually the day would end at 6.30 to 7pm. Schooldays were a break in the routine once the wartime evacuations were over but holidays were long and hot on in the summer. 
It was towards the end of the evacuation period that I witnessed the bombing of Augsburg which annihilated half the city and most of its industry. 16 Jul 1944 A total of 1,087 B-17 Flying Fortress bombers USAAF Eighth Air Force attacked Germany in three waves (407, 238, and 407 bombers, respectively), escorted by 240, 214, and 169 fighters, respectively, with most of the bombers targeting Munich, Stuggart, Augsburg, and Saarbrucken; a total of 11 bombers and 3 fighters were lost. For 3 days after the bombing of Augsburg I witnessed a constant steam of people passing and visiting our farm in search of food.
                                       
                                   Destruction of Augsburg
Whatever else the defeat may have meant to the Germans, it meant that they were going to go hungry, probably for a long time; and they were hungry already. The SHAEF maximum daily ration for normal consumers was 1,550 calories, but the amounts actually being issued ranged from 804 calories in Hesse and Hesse-Nassau to 1,150 calories in parts of the Rhineland. The normal consumers were the new proletariat of the occupation. The gentry were the "heavy" and "very heavy" workers, railroad workers and miners for instance, who could get up to 2,800 calories. The out-and-out aristocrats were the self-suppliers, that is, the farmers, who did not have to trouble themselves with ration cards. The normal consumer was not starving, but if he subsisted entirely on his ration, which no one really expected him to do, he was very close to it. A typical week's ration issued during May of 1945 consisted of the following: bread, 3 pounds; meat, 4 ounces; butter and fat, 2 ounces; sugar, 7 ounces; macaroni and spaghetti, 5 ounces; potatoes, 6 pounds; some cereal (added to the children's ration), 6 ounces; milk (only for children up to six), 1 quart. The total was less than 1,000 calories per day, and the difference was made up by adding a few ounces of green vegetables "provided trucks can be found to haul them and provided the people can eat rhubarb without sugar." 

                                           
Permaculture using Keyline and Sloping Agricultural Land Technology
In Germany by the end of the war there were no men left! Then Polish and Russian prisoners who helped out during the war had returned home and my uncle, my father's brother, came back from Siberia in 1951. He was part of a three hundred thousand (300,000) man army captured by the Russians of which only 7,000 returned. He lived to age 86. When my cousin married, the agricultural land was added to her husband's estate as was the custom in rural inheritance practice.
When we arrived in Sydney Dec 25, 1952, it was a shock to observe the monotony of the country on the train journey from Sydney to Geelong in Victoria; a journey lasting beyond 24 hours. The countryside was either bush or brown gravel; the land had been overstocked and eaten down to the roots. The few remaining sheep mere skeletons; either living or dead. A scene I was never to forget. 
Ten years later, when I had my own farm, I rotated the cattle when they had eaten down to four or five centimetres with a layer of organic matter underneath that of at least 2cm to reduce evaporation and encourage the development of natural nutrients. The other thing that left me with a lasting impression was that every arable piece of ground and most of the slopes had been cleared of trees or ringbarked; the whole trip was dotted with thousands of bleached, decaying trunks that had been killed a hundred years before to promote growth of grass or wheat. Later, on our own property I promoted the growth of the most valuable trees and paid for the full purchase price with the trees I culled. Coincidentally, all old gnarled and twisted trees were left for homes and shelter for a diverse assortment of wildlife. I later had the property declared as a sanctuary. The trees have added 50 years of growth and remain there to this day. There were two major commercial benefits from this approach; The growth in timber added more value than the land was worth and later when I subdivided the property the blocks sold quicker and brought a better price than any surrounding, cleared subdivision.


I went to school in Australia for four years, worked on a farm after school every day and then for four years after I left school. After eight years I managed that farm and as my parting act-exported bulbs to Holland. We became so competitive that we bought out the other bulb growers in Geelong and supplied flower bulbs Australia wide. This was done by mechanising, improvising and economising. We saved labour costs by mechanising the sowing, weeding and harvesting process; then added value by refocusing the workers into adding value by grading and packaging for our customers. We conceived and manufactured specialised machines from old car and machinery parts and streamlined the packaging process. The greatest return came from developing the acquired land into smaller holdings or rural subdivisions as well as stocking the more viable 1,000 to 10,000 acre with mainly sheep from drought affected NSW.
In 1959 I left to complete my schooling and learn English by focusing on language and science in a four year BA Ed course. During this period I studied Australian farming methods and practices and concluded that most farmers in Australia don't enjoy the the lifestyle and quality of life of the average German farmer. The most successful operators  here are either large, mechanised and well schooled family organisations or companies employing agriculture and business graduates. After that are the traders who buy run down, debt or drought affected farms; engage in minimal farming, window dress and wait for a good season to sell.  In Germany, farms are long term enterprises.


             
                                      Rice planting - Philippines
Farming formed a large part of my life in Australia. All my experience, my study and my work centred around primary production, I exported meat and live sheep, studied tropical pasture development and the various uses of nitrogen fixing, leguminous shrubs and trees. I attended field days in Northern Queensland and the Northern Territory and the highlight in my memory was planning and conducting a 10 day tour of tropical farming enterprises. This involved Kings Ranch Fullers seeds and a day in Humpty Doo with James Gayoso catching wild buffalo for export. The tour was arranged for Seichi Kawai, the world's biggest emerald dealer at the time. His farm near Bogota spanned the size of a small country and he planned to develop this into a modern, productive agricultural enterprise. He imported farm machinery and seeds as well as cattle, suitable for tropical primary production.
Over the last 10 years here in The Philippines due to rapid population growth and the desperate need to feed this population, the forests have been degraded through the practice of slash and burn. The topsoil has been progressively lost and less than 20% of natural forest remains.  Rice is the mainstay and if the season is good the farmers eat until the next harvest. Competition from cheap imports of rice, the cost of production, especially the cost of fertiliser, has pushed them further into poverty. The typhoon wiped out more than 60% of the country's crop. With the help of a group of philanthropists, loosely formed into "the One Good Idea Group" I have moved to the Aklan  Region in the Philippines to introduce a comprehensive program designed to bring prosperity to these victims of centuries of archaic practices and finally a devastating storm. The key to this program is the introduction of high yielding Super Hybrid rice and from there the introduction of proven methods of Key-line farming, focusing on the use of organic fertiliser production and crop diversification.


                             Vegetable farming in Cebu
Now at the age of 75 I am engaged in the most ambitious and the most worthwhile endeavour of my life. I have seen the plight of the poor hill farmers in the provinces in the Philippines after Typhoon Haiyan (Yolanda) and believe with the help of the team we have assembled that we can turn their lives around.
We can't do it alone, but together - with your help - we will change the world for the better.

Brian Martin, ESP Gallery Marrickville says:

       Wishing you well in all your goals & endeavours Manfred !
It was inspiring to meet you and I will always wish you safe passage as you go about your good works around the world.
My personal view is that if someone is making the world a better place, then I don’t care what beliefs or motivation drive them towards it. Results matter more than belief systems.
To anyone who does not know Manfred Kemter, he is a retired businessman from Australia, he originally came from Germany as a child, he has seen the worst that civilisation can do as a small child on the outskirts of Augsburg, and he has aspired to be the best that we can do as an adult. He has single-handedly brought prosperity to poor villagers in the Philippines after the devastation of cyclones in recent years.
I met Manfred because he lived across the back lane from ESP Gallery in Marrickville Sydney. We had many long discussions about humanitarian aid, and direct action.
I will miss Manfred’s discussions, but wish him the best of success with his direct action approach to fundraising and personally helping hill villages & Cooperatives with the introduction of high yielding Chinese Super Hybrid Rice and Key-line permaculture; ensuring their ongoing supply of food & income through improved cultivation practices and in partnership with progressive minds from the Department of Agrarian Reform and the University of Aklan to teach a shift in the perception of prosperity from having many children to education and entrepreneurship.
Auf wiedersehen Manfred

story:
My Name is Ryan Bellerose

I am a Metis man from Northern Alberta who has moved south and now Lives in Calgary, I have been involved in the struggle for indigenous rights for most of my life.
Last year I got involved with a movement named Idle No More, I got involved for two reasons, the omnibus bills being introduced were damaging not only to the environment, but specifically to indigenous people and our rights. I met a lot of really great people, people who were committed to the struggle that I feel is the most important struggle in my life. 3 people who I am lucky enough to call my friends decided to go in a different direction, one that required more focus, and more direction to make more tangible changes in the lives of Native people. Nina Wilson and Jess Gordon, both of whom were founding members of Idle No More and who are women who I respect greatly and see as role models not just for Native women, but for any indigenous people, and Richard Dubois, a Native artist who often works with native youth. Our focus now is much more on advocating for our cultures, protecting sacred sites and actual boots on the ground activism. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are starting our group with a launch event called " Igniting the fire", we do not want to fund our group on the backs of our people, many of whom struggle already, but we know we need money to to make money, and we need money in order to more effectively advocate for our people and the environment. Our launch event is a silent auction with a twist, we will have several native artists who will be selling their art but instead of 100% going to our group, we will be splitting the sales 60-40 with the artists. some of these artists are travelling from as far away as Manitoba and British columbia to participate. we will also be running the auction online. we have raised about three thousand dollars so far, enough to get the deposit paid on the venue and part of the catering cost. we are confident that the auction will raise much needed money but we need money to promote and to pay deposits. we will share our budget as well as the financials of the group as we feel its important to be open and transparent.


The Impact

Your contribution will help us get set up to be self sufficient, we are using the launch event to raise money to help run the group, to promote native art and culture and to help our group be more effective as advocates and train more people in our communities to be more effective advocates. Our future goals include advocacy training for communities, as well as an indigenous arts and music festival that we hope will be an example for sustainable events across Canada.

story:
Hi! I'm Eve, founder of Buzz Tour

For the last two years I have been learning about action that people are taking on climate change. After giving up my job I traveled and learned to do things differently. It was the first time in my life I had the time to really step back and think for myself. What became very clear to me was that the causes of climate change are cultural and systemic. Now is the time. There is no more time to wait. Our species has achieved wonders over thousands of years, but if we wish to preserve our continued existence on Earth we must change our behaviour within the next 15 years.

The Buzz Tour is all about making connections and pollinating change. Every person has their own path and contribution to a positive future and we celebrate that. We will walk to inspiring people and projects all over the country and take the inspiration, wisdom and skills with us. We'll also share it on buzztour.org. With support we'll be able to feed ourselves, pay for emergencies, use video equipment to record the fabulous people and get kitted out for the walk. We'll visit a huge range of groups including schools, permaculture farms, Transition projects, community elders, and people taking direct action. Help us! Join us!

What We Need & What You Get

Money would help but any donations in kind would be great! We would much rather borrow the things we need than buy them. The more help we get the more people on low/no income can join us.
  • Camping equipment
  • Venue hire
  • Audio visual equipment - a gopro and data cards
  • Walking and safety gear
  • Transport to the walk start and from the finish
  • Food along the way

THANK YOU, helping take action should be rewarded. Our perks for you:

  • A personalised thank you letter
  • A packet of wildflower seeds for you to plant - beautiful and helps bees!
  • A Bee yourself fridge magnet

  • Our handmade buzz tour felt bee broach
  • Our awesome buzz tour cotton shopper bag

  • A bee decorated cushion cover - the walking bees will handmake this just for you, in the colours that you want
Other ways to be involved:
  • Get us to come to your school and show you the fabulous things we find!
  • Join us along the walk as we put the world to rights, learn about native insects and plants, and change our lives.
  • Be inspired and get connected! By joining us as a supporter you will be part of a network of people who want to make this world better and be more than they are. We will have a supporters meetup to help people forge those links in person.

The Impact

The impact on anyone who joins us is likely to be life changing, it is no small thing to leave day to day life behind and walk your country to learn the wisdom of your people. For those who can't walk with us, we want to share what we discover and learn with you, which is why we'll be capturing as much great stuff as we can by video, audio and photo. We want to come to you! We want to walk to people all over the country and bring them news of the inspiring things their people are doing. Showing that other ways are possible can change the course of your life. It certainly did for me. We are a great country, but leaving a habitable planet for our descendants will be the greatest thing we can do.

Other Ways You Can Get Involved

Are you doing amazing things? Would you like us to visit? Would your school like us to do an inspiration session? Can you put someone up for a night on the way or give us a hot meal? Share this crowdfunding appeal and our website (buzztour.org) with your friends, contacts and family. The more people get in touch and ask us to visit, or walk with us the better! 

Join us on the walk!

story:
“To know, to love, to protect” - Jacques-Yves Cousteau

Seventy percent of our planet is one connected ocean. It produces half the oxygen we breathe and feeds over one billion people.

Today the ocean is at risk, losing biodiversity at an alarming rate due to pollution, overfishing, and climate change. The ocean’s temperatures greatly influence our planet’s climate, weather, fish stocks, bird populations. Ocean temperatures are steadily increasing yet our understanding of how they vary at the scale of the ecosystems is largely unknown to science.

Only the power of citizen science and crowdsourcing can “plug this hole” in our understanding of how temperature varies in the ocean. Without this knowledge, the management and conservation of marine ecosystems is a “shot in the dark”.  It is a vital source of information that governments, scientists, fisheries, and conservation organizations need if they are going to understand this major threat to ocean life.

Project Hermes is the first global effort to measure ocean temperatures worldwide at the scale of the ecosystem.  Since August 2015, Cousteau Divers and the University of Queensland spearhead this unique project. Using satellite sea surface temperature, diver’s computers and a collaborative, non-profit, open source software and database, Project Hermes will provide near real-time temperatures of the ocean, at depth, world-wide. We are producing a new source of scientific data. Please donate to equip 50 dive centres with reference temperature instruments and mine existing backlogs. 

Join us in exploring how the ocean behaves, on a human quest to bond a worldwide community of divers in saving what we love. Cousteau Divers is a citizen science  platform of divers (freedivers and scuba) united to study and protect the ocean. Together with NOAA’s Coral Reef Watch and the Global Change Institute at the University of Queensland, participate in solving some the greatest scientific mysteries and challenges of the ocean.


Cousteau Divers

The Cousteau Divers community started six years ago, to act as an immune system for the ocean seeking to better understanding it and better protect it. Check out what we’ve been doing up to now on www.cousteaudivers.org/science and www.cousteaudivers.org/multimedia/all. Our Web site is being improved and the new version will go live in October 2015.

Our rapidly-growing community will soon consist of 50 Cousteau Dive centres in over 15 countries in Europe, the Middle East, Asia and the Americas. We have gathered thousands of images of marine life world-wide and an online community hundreds of thousands strong. Join our online community of over 130 thousand likes on www.facebook.com/cousteaudivers.

Project Hermes

Hermes is a messenger god of transitions and boundaries, according to Wikipedia, a crowdsourced online encyclopedia.  We are also creating a crowdsourced database, of diver temperatures and images. A guide to the underworld, Hermes is an appropriate reference for this project focused on detecting thermoclines.

In July of this year, during the World Ocean Summit in Lisbon, Cousteau Divers met with Professor Ove Hoegh-Guldberg, Director of the Global Change Institute at the University of Queensland (GCIQ), a world-class research organisation dedicated to solving the mysteries of the ocean, especially in the light of the rapid changes that are now occurring due to climate change. Speaking about the power of citizen science, we quickly realised what we had in our hands. Combining the Cousteau Divers community and reach to the University of Queensland’s scientific network and connections with NOAA's Coral Reef Watch, we can take the temperature of the ocean. Literally. We need this data in order to better manage marine resources at large.

Ocean and Climate

The ocean plays a crucial role in climate change and weather patterns. Current satellite technology can only read the “skin” of the sea. Divers have the ability to help monitor it in depth on a regular basis, thereby providing a new source of scientific data, with myriads of applications.

On this daily map of sea surface temperatures (SST) we can see El Niño forming in the Pacific Ocean (the large red blob). As El Niño spreads across the world in the coming year, we will be able to monitor its effect on water temperatures at depth, which has tremendous scientific value. www.coralreefwatch.noaa.gov/vs/map.php

One example of the tremendous importance of ocean temperatures is mass coral bleaching and mortality. As sea temperatures rise, corals lose their photosynthetic symbiotic zooxanthellae, which results in the coral suddenly whitening. Given that the zooxanthellae are a critical source of food and nutrition for the coral, corals often starve and die following mass coral bleaching. The images above were taken in American Samoa between December 2014 and April 2015 by Richard Vevers of Underwater Earth. Due to climate change, ocean temperatures are exceptionally warm across the planet. 2015-2016 promises to be an El Niño year, meaning that warmer than normal temperatures are likely to spread throughout the world, potentially devastating corals and impacting the many life forms that live on them.

The Team

In addition to our core partner at the University of Queensland, we are working with the following partners. NOAA’s Coral Reef Watch uses some of the most advanced technology in the world to monitor the sea surface temperatures from satellites. DAN Europe’s Diving Safety Laboratory is the leading diver safety research organisation in Europe and has been collecting diving temperatures for a decade, with over 60,000 diver data profiles in stock. This data will be anonymously fed into the Hermes software to obtain a 10-year backlog of sea temperatures. We will organise a hackathon to explore programming solutions and practical applications of this new data.

All of these partners, and more, are helping us make Project Hermes a reality with in-kind contributions. All data collected and processed is made open source and shared among all project partners and the public. We hope to present preliminary findings in time for the United Nations Climate Summit (COP21) in Paris, this December, where the leaders of the world will gather. We will shed new light on how the ocean influences climate, a missing piece of the puzzle.

From aerospace engineers and graphic designers to oceanographers and developers, we're now a team of a dozen excited people allocating brain bandwidth to this revolutionary project.

Last but certainly not least, we can't do any of this without the active contributions of the future 50 Cousteau Dive centres. Above is a selection of 15 applicant dive centres who will join the program from all over the world in 2016!  All dive centres can join, and we hope to have as many as possible contributing data to Project Hermes soon. Membership is free. Know any dive centres who want to help monitor the ocean? 

Join us and change the world! 

Each Cousteau Dive centre will receive a set of three instruments: a Site Station, to monitor temperature at a constant depth for months at a time; a Temperature Logger, to be worn by the centre's dive master/instructor who is in the water most frequently; a universal dive computer connector, to upload diver's profiles.

In January 2016, the Cousteau Dive centres will receive a branding package and they will be promoted on the new website.

Scientific goals and methods

The near real-time monitoring of the temperatures of the ocean at depth worldwide, calibrated by satellite and precision instruments. A Site Station is immersed in at least one of the Cousteau Dive centre's dive sites and records temperature at a constant depth for months at a time with great precision. Additionally, divemasters go on every dive with one of our devices, to measure the variations of temperature, such as thermoclines, and to calibrate the dive computers of their customers. 

Temperature is collected by the divers, then matched with satellite surface temperature and benchmarked against the Site Stations and dive temperature loggers. This new "product" is then fed back to the contributor with compelling visuals, in order to drive the retention of contributors. 

We are producing a new source of scientific data: real-time temperatures of the ocean at depth. We combine diver (freedivers and scuba) computer data with satellite sea surface temperature for a better understanding of how the ocean behaves and interacts with the climate and biodiversity on the ecosystem scale.

Open source

All data collected and processed is made open source and shared among all project partners and the public. Contributor feedback loops help retain data providers.

We are non-profit, non-governmental, and open-source. We believe mankind needs this information in order to better manage its resources, and we have found a way of making it technically and financially possible, today.

Cousteau Divers and Dive centres are observers and observatories of marine life world-wide. We are raising funds to deploy calibration temperature loggers in all Cousteau Dive centres.

Funding and targets

Project Hermes is currently bootstrapped by Cousteau Divers and the Global Change Institute at the University of Queensland. We are looking for grants, donations and in-kind contributions. Funding will help keep the platform free and maintained, and develop this new field of study, by improving satellite and diver data synchronising and calibrating devices, as well as developing new technologies, hiring dedicated staff, and organising an international hackathon.


Our global target for this campaign is to raise $ 42,500

 (between both international and Dutch campaigns) 

The Indiegogo campaign aims to support the deployment of temperature equipment in 35 Cousteau Dive centres. The Dutch campaign supports the remaining 15 Cousteau Dive centres.


Temperature loggers and site stations will help us model the behaviour of ocean temperatures around the dive centre as well as to model error margins of dive computers. The universal dive computer adapters will help collect more data from divers visiting the Cousteau Dive centre. The server is needed to host all this new data, and manpower is necessary to handle shipping and coordination of dive centres.

Over the top!

If we manage to raise more than the target $ 42,500, the combined "extra" proceeds from both campaigns will go to the following, in order:

- Develop the Hermes software to process all this new data (est. $ 25,000). This software will collect data, match it with satellite and calibration data, and dispatch the product globally. Cousteau Divers and the University of Queensland are currently bootstrapping this development, but it can't go fast without further funding!

- Organise the Hack the Ocean hackathon (est. $ 15,000), to perform exploratory programming using anonymous diver temperature profiles and satellite data.

- Produce a Climate and Ocean report before the end of the year (est. $ 15,000). We're really hoping we can produce revolutionary knowledge in time for the Climate Summit in Paris, this December. This is a massive undertaking and will require a lot of resources in order to meet that target in time.

- Start desining new hardware that is specific to this project (est. $ 25,000). We'll start making our own temperature instruments, specifically tailored to our need, to improve the ease-of-use and accuracy of our temperature measurements.


What we're doing right now 

Cousteau Divers is launching a new Web site in October designed to showcase the Cousteau Dive centres and receive their data, and CGIQ-CRW are defining the requirements for the software to match satellite with diver data. DAN Europe is carrying out the necessary calibration modelling of commercial dive computers. NOAA CRW is designing the software solution concepts and volunteers are helping with coding and visualisation. 


Let's go hack the ocean! How do thermoclines behave? How does the ocean store and release energy? How do thermoclines influence crops, coastal and marine life, and weather? What new discoveries will come from this research? Join us! Donate now.

www.cousteaudivers.org
www.gci.uq.edu.au
www.project-hermes.com

Sea you there!
Pierre-Yves Cousteau, initiator of Project Hermes, is going to be at the following events to promote Project Hermes and speak about oceans and innovation at large. Check out the following calendar and come hear the story first-hand!

September 8, 2015: #ISWA2015, Antwerp, Belgium.

September 15, 2015: Maritime Cyprus, Cyprus.

September 18, 2015: Forum Economie Positive, Le Havre, France.

September 29, 2015: #EMSEA2015, Crete, Greece.

October 8, 2015: #EoEAlliance, Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

“To know, to love, to protect” - Jacques-Yves Cousteau
Seventy
percent of our planet is one connected ocean. It produces half the oxygen we breathe and feeds over
one billion people.
Today the ocean is at risk,
losing biodiversity at an alarming rate due to pollution, overfishing, and
climate change. The ocean’s temperatures greatly influence our planet’s
climate, weather, fish stocks, bird populations. Ocean temperatures are steadily increasing yet our understanding of how
they vary at the scale of the ecosystems is largely unknown to science.Only the power of citizen
science and crowdsourcing can “plug this hole” in our understanding of how
temperature varies in the ocean. Without this knowledge, the management and
conservation of marine ecosystems is a “shot in the dark”.  It is a vital source of information that
governments, scientists, fisheries, and conservation organizations need if they
are going to understand this major threat to ocean life. Project Hermes is the first global effort to measure ocean temperatures worldwide at the scale of the ecosystem.  Since August 2015, Cousteau Divers and the University of Queensland spearhead this unique project. story:
Project Summary

We are excited to be working toward the goal of installing a 40kW solar array on the roof of our church.  This crowdfunding campaign gives an opportunity for others both near and far to partner with us as we continue to Care for Creation, Care for our Community and Invest Responsibly.

  • We are the congregation of Saint Anthony Park Lutheran Church in St. Paul, Minnesota.   Located on the corner of Como Avenue and Luther Place, we have a visible and social presence in the heart of this neighborhood community.
  • Our recent investment in a new roof along with the church's optimum solar orientation makes this a perfect time to implement a rooftop solar project.
  • We have been awarded the Made In Minnesota solar incentive.  This incentive is estimated to pay more than half of the cost of the project over 10 years, but first we have to raise funds for the entire project.
  • With your help this broader outreach campaign will raise $10,000 (~8% of the total project cost).
  • Donations are tax-deductible. A receipt will be emailed to you immediately upon confirmation of your donation.

Project Support

Please consider supporting our project in the following ways:

  • An easy and effective form of support is by simply sharing our campaign with your social media network.  By reposting and/or sharing our campaign on  Facebook and/or Twitter you can help broaden the awareness of our project.
  • In return for your monetary support there are several ways we would like to say thank you.  We are excited to offer these perks that are meant not only to encourage your donation but also to illustrate the importance and effectiveness of renewable energy. 

  • The perks for donating will primarily be knowledge-based activities that will not tap into project funds. Every dollar you donate will be used to build our solar array.

Project Impact

There are several ways to equate the impact of our solar project, here are just a few:

  • We like to think of this fund-raising project as a bit different than other capital and mission based projects.  Your donation helps create a project that reduces real carbon emissions in Minnesota, while also being a tax-deductible gift.

  • Over 30 years it is estimated to save the church over $257,000 in energy costs.
Annually this 40kW solar array will;
  •  produce about 50% of the church's electric use.
  • will offset ~73,800 pounds of carbon dioxide (equivalent to 3,950 trees)

Beyond the physical and fiscal impacts we hope this project will inspire.  Together we will learn what is possible and meaningful when we care for the environment by using solar energy.

story:
What is Crimson Fuel?

Crimson Fuel is the brainchild of Scott Morris, a small business entrepreneur with a vision for economic freedom for America.

Oil, namely the imported stuff, has a noose around the American economy and culture. We consume so much of it that by eliminating about 20%, we could turn our trade deficit into a trade surplus. This would have a cascading effect on the economy, and impact every single American.

There is a fuel that COSTS as much as 40% LESS per mile driven, and can easily replace gasoline, without requiring you to buy a new car or pay to have yours converted, and can be sold at the gas stations we already have in America. There is no need to build out an enormous infrastructure and change the lives and habits of American consumers.

Methanol is that solution. Methanol can be made from almost anything, with cost and waste products as the limiting factors. Currently, natural gas is the most viable feedstock and will be for many years to come. But coal is a close second, and we have a LOT of that too.

Between natural gas and coal, we have enough resources in the USA alone to fuel every vehicle in the USA, accounting for growth, for the next 400 YEARS!

Our Plan

We will open/acquire gas stations in carefully selected locations, that will install this kit and convert cars for free, with a patented and EPA approved conversion kit that also comes with a full warranty against any damage to your engine. Those consumers will then simply fill up at our station for as much as 40% less than they pay for gas every month. If they are not in range of one of our stations, they can simply put gas in the car as they always have. Pretty simple really. We don’t need to build special stations or undergo any massive change to make this happen. We simply need to enable your car to run on this superior fuel, and then sell it to you. When you fill up, you are contributing to the economic prosperity of America, and our national security by not sending dollars overseas.

What We Need

We need your help to build a consumer outcry and demand that rallies the people to adopt a new fuel that will rid us of the stranglehold of the oil cartel.

We already have the support of a major methanol manufacturer to the tune of $200,000, provided we can raise the remaining $300,000, and we need to raise it from the American people to make a statement that this is what America wants…freedom from oil and sending dollars overseas that ultimately fund terrorism against our homeland.

Show corporate America and the investment and venture capital community that their investment is worth it.

Your dollars show a type of bona fide support that the investment community will not be able to ignore. This will enable us to campaign for the larger investment dollars we need to open thousands of stations across the USA. If your dollar is behind it, the investment dollars are easy to justify.

America is supposed to be a free market. A truly free market allows various products to compete. With methanol, we will never be hog-tied to a single source for our fuel. If natural gas gets too expensive, we can simply make it from something else. The producer that makes the methanol that meets the consumer demand will win the market share, and deservingly so. If they fail to keep up, then another one will move in and take that market share away. This is how the American free market is supposed to work.

We need you to support this with a few bucks to make sure this gets off the ground. The government is too heavily influenced by big oil lobby money. We need you, the people to put your dollars behind this and show them they cannot control us anymore. It is a true revolution, fought with your dollars.

Become a Crimson Fuel Revolutionary with your support.

Every supporter will have the opportunity to submit their photo and a short statement on why they chose to support Crimson Fuel. These will be featured on mini video screen on our pumps at our stations, and in our commercials and marketing campaigns, encouraging other Americans to join in creating freedom in the American vehicle fuel marketplace that has never before existed.

Other Ways You Can Help

Times are tough. Maybe you just can’t contribute directly, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Spread the word out and make some noise about the American Economic Revolution and Crimson Fuel.
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out to everyone you know. This is a way to make a real difference in America!

change to make this happen. We simply need to enable your car to run on this
superior fuel, and then sell it to you. When you fill up, you are contributing
to the economic prosperity of America,
and our national security by not sending dollars overseas.
What We Need
We need your help to build a consumer outcry and demand that rallies the
people to adopt a new fuel that will rid us of the stranglehold of the oil
cartel.
We already have the support of a major methanol manufacturer to the tune of
$200,000, provided we can raise the remaining $300,000, and we need to raise it
from the American people to make a statement that this is what America
wants…freedom from oil and sending dollars overseas that ultimately fund
terrorism against our homeland.
Show corporate America
and the investment and venture capital community that their investment is worth
it.
Your dollars show a type of bona fide support that the investment community
will not be able to ignore. This will enable us to campaign for the larger
investment dollars we need to open thousands of stations across the USA. If your
dollar is behind it, the investment dollars are easy to justify.
America
is supposed to be a free market. A truly free market allows various products to
compete. With methanol, we will never be hog-tied to a single source for our
fuel. If natural gas gets too expensive, we can simply make it from something
else. The producer that makes the methanol that meets the consumer demand will
win the market share, and deservingly so. If they fail to keep up, then another
one will move in and take that market share away. This is how the American free
market is supposed to work.
We need you to support this with a few bucks to make sure this gets off the
ground. The government is too heavily influenced by big oil lobby money. We
need you, the people to put your dollars behind this and show them they cannot
control us anymore. It is a true revolution, fought with your dollars.
Become a Crimson Fuel Revolutionary with your support.
Every supporter will have the opportunity to submit their photo and a short
statement on why they chose to support Crimson Fuel. These will be featured on
mini video screen on our pumps at our stations, and in our commercials and
marketing campaigns, encouraging other Americans to join in creating freedom in
the American vehicle fuel marketplace that has never before existed.
Other Ways You Can Help
Times are tough. Maybe you just can’t contribute directly, but that doesn’t
mean you can’t help:

Spread the word out and make
     some noise about the American Economic Revolution and Crimson Fuel.
Be sure to use the Indiegogo
     share tools to get the word out to everyone you know. This is a way to
     make a real difference in America!

story:
83 Year Old Tree

This 83 year old tree is in jeopardy of being cut down.  The current owners do not have the $2000 needed to trim this old tree in a manner that will allow it to continue to thrive and have petitioned the city to allow this grand old tree to be cut down.

This tree was listed in the Arizona Great Tree registry in 2004 and was at that time estimated to be 75 years old. (See the write up http://aztrees.org/c_greattrees.php?Y=2004

In years past, the circus would arrive in Glendale and set up camp close to Catlin court.

One year, two of the elephants escaped, they were found rubbing their backs against the trunk and enjoying the shade. Thus, the tree came to be nicknamed the "Elephant Tree".

Height: 100+ feet, Canopy: 63 feet, Circumference: 13 feet.

Current home to three Arizona Harris Hawks, watch the above video to see one of the hawks come back to roost in its branches.

We are trying to raise $5000, this will allow for current trimming and then annual maintenance for the next five years.  

 

Since the tree was planted;

  • End of WW1
  • Women are granted the right to vote in a number of countries, including the US
  • The Great Depression in the US (started in 1929)
  • The first public television broadcast
  • Empire State Building Completed
  • Cheeseburger Created
  • Broadcast of "The War of the Worlds" Causes Panic
  • Pearl Harbor Attacked
  • Microwave Oven Invented
  • Car Seat Belts Introduced
  • Disneyland Opens
  • Martin Luther King Jr. Makes His "I Have a Dream" Speech
  • Star Trek T.V. Series Airs
  • Microsoft Founded
  • Personal Computers (PC) Introduced by IBM
  • Official End of the Cold War

So much history in this tree's past. To think it can be gone with a simple chain saw.

We are not asking for a hand out, rather a hand up in trying to save this old tree. Trying to ensure this old tree will be around for generations to come

Won't you please help...?

story:
La Conserva della neve

La Conserva della neve è una mostra-mercato floro vivaistica che ospita esclusivamente vivai da collezione scelti tra i migliori del panorama italiano ed europeo e personaggi internazionali tra artisti, studiosi e architetti del paesaggio. La manifestazione, giunta alla XII edizione, ha luogo ogni anno nel mese di settembre. Tre giorni no-stop con orario di apertura al pubblico dalle 09:00 alle 19:30. Dal 2002 al 2009 la mostra si è tenuta a Viterbo all’interno del parco storico di Villa Lante di Bagnaia, uno dei più famosi giardini all'italiana del XVI secolo. Dal 2010 si è spostata a Roma nella splendida cornice di Villa Borghese all’interno del Parco dei Daini. Quest'anno l'evento si terrà il 19, 20 e 21 settembre 2014.

La Conserva della neve is a floriculture trade fair that exclusively hosts nurseries chosen from collections among the best of the Italian and European panoramas, as well as international artists, scholars and landscape architects. The event takes place once a year in the month of September for three days non-stop, and is joined with this year’s 12th edition. The exhibition was held in Viterbo inside of the historic park of Villa Lante di Bagnaia, one of the most famous Italian gardens of the 16th century, from 2002 to 2009. In 2010 it relocated to Rome in the splendid setting of Villa Borghese inside of Parco dei Daini.This year the event will take place on the 19th, 20th and 21st of September 2014, from 9:00 a.m. to 7:30 p.m.

Una kermesse completamente rivolta al mondo del verde, con oltre 120 espositori da tutto il mondo, dove è possibile acquistare piante, trovare tutte le novità del settore e scambiare informazioni difficilmente reperibili nei circuiti tradizionali. É questo che rende La Conserva della neve un evento unico in Italia e in Europa.

This is a kermesse aimed exclusively at the green world, with more than 120 international exhibitors. Here it is possible to purchase plants, to discover all of the novelties of the sector and to exchange information not easily found in traditional circuits. This is what makes La Conserva della neve a unique event in Italy and Europe.

L'importanza culturale e divulgativa della manifestazione è ampiamente dimostrata dalla sempre maggiore affluenza di pubblico soprattutto giovane in particolare studenti in Scienze Agrarie, Scienze Forestali, Architettura del Paesaggio, scolaresche, ma anche dalle famiglie e dai numerosi appassionati del verde, sia amatori che professionisti. Dalle 3.000 presenze della I edizione nel 2002 si è giunti a 15.000 visitatori nel 2013.

The cultural and educational importance of the event is amply demonstrated by the growing affluence of the mostly young public, particularly students of the Agrarian Sciences, Forest Sciences and Landscape Architecture. Other guests include families and numerous individuals, hobbyists and professionals alike, passionate about the ‘green.’ Attendance has gone from 3,000 present in the 1st edition in 2002 to 15,000 visitors in 2013.

La manifestazione ha contribuito in questi anni all’attuazione in Italia di nuovi vivai specializzati, è riuscita a sostenere la creazione di fondazioni scientifiche per la salvaguardia della biodiversità vegetale di specie appartenenti al nostro territorio nazionale e a coadiuvare le associazioni internazionali che operano soprattutto nei paesi in via di sviluppo per promuovere un’agricoltura sostenibile, migliorare la qualità della vita quotidiana, valorizzare i saperi tradizionali, fare economia.

In the past few years, this event has contributed to the fulfillment of new specialized horticulturists and has succeed in sustaining the creation of scientific foundations for the safeguarding of plant biodiversity of species belonging to our national territory. We have co-operated with international associations that operate in developing countries to promote sustainable agriculture, to improve the quality of daily life, to economize and to value traditional know-how.

Chi siamo / Who we are

La Conserva della neve è un'Associazione non profit che promuove e organizza l'omonima manifestazione culturale, allo scopo di far conoscere al pubblico italiano e straniero le nuove forme di arte e architettura del paesaggio e diffondere il concetto di “biodiversità” vegetale.

La Conserva della neve is a non-profit association that promotes and organizes the cultural event of the same name, with the goal of rendering new forms of art and landscape architecture known to the Italian public, as well as to diffuse the concept of plant ‘biodiversity.’

Oltre a questa finalità, l'Associazione ha posto uguale interesse verso tutte le attività e creazioni rivolte al mondo del verde e del paesaggio sottolineando l'importanza di figure professionali quali ricercatori, studiosi, architetti del paesaggio, agronomi, associazioni, artisti, scrittori, a cui ha sempre dedicato un posto di primo piano.

But that’s not all. The Association has geared an equal amount of interest towards all of the activities and creations dedicated to landscapes and to the green world, emphasizing the importance of professional figures such as researchers, scholars, landscape architects, agronomists, associations, artists and writers, to which it has always dedicated a spot in the foreground.

Nel 2011 è stata invitata ad un gemellaggio con il salone del Florovivaismo Florexpo alla Nuova Fiera di Roma; inoltre è stata chiamata a collaborare alla realizzazione delle edizioni 2011 e 2012 della manifestazione "Era di Maggio…", svoltesi alla Galleria Nazionale di Arte Antica di Palazzo Corsini alla Lungara a Roma.

In 2011, the association was invited to a twinning event at the Florexpo at the Nuova Fiera of Rome. It was also called to collaborate in the realization of the 2011 and 2012 editions of the “Era di Maggio...” event, at the National Gallery of Antique Art in the Corsini Palace in Rome.

Le ultime quattro edizioni svoltesi nel Parco dei Daini di Villa Borghese, divenuto la sede definitiva della mostra, hanno creato un ottimo e costruttivo rapporto tra la manifestazione ed il Comune di Roma rappresentato dalla Soprintendenza Beni Culturali (Direzione Ville e Parchi Storici) e il Servizio Giardini.
Questa collaborazione si concretizza ogni anno nella fornitura annuale delle specie storiche di bulbose, erbacee ed arboree per i Giardini Segreti da parte della manifestazione e nelle visite guidate dal personale comunale ai Giardini Segreti per i visitatori della mostra.

The past four editions have taken place in Parco dei Daini in Villa Borghese, which has become the definitive location of the exhibition. They have created an optimal and constructive relationship between the individuals involved in the event and the Commune of Rome, represented by the government department responsible for cultural goods (direction of villas and historic parks) and the Servizio Giardini.
This collaboration manifests itself every year in the annual supplying of historic species such as bulbs, herbaceous and tree crops for the Giardini Segreti on behalf of the event, as well as in the guided visits of the Giardini Segreti provided by the personnel of the commune.

Ciò grazie alla passione e alla coraggiosa caparbietà delle sue socie fondatrici Lusi Nesbitt, Presidente dell'Associazione, imprenditore nonché Grande Ufficiale al Merito della Repubblica Italiana e Maria Cristina Leonardi, Agronomo Paesaggista, le quali spendono ogni anno gran parte delle loro energie e del loro tempo per mantenere sempre alto il livello qualitativo della mostra.

This is all thanks to the passion and to the courageous stubbornness of the founding associates, Lusi Nesbitt, President of the Association, entrepreneur and “Grande Ufficiale al Merito della Repubblica Italiana“ and Maria Cristina Leonardi, Agronomist-Landscape Architect, which spends a large part of its time and energy each year constantly maintaining the high qualitative level of the show.

Perchè donare? / Why donate?

Il tuo contributo è fondamentale perché ci aiuterà a migliorare e a rendere sempre più ricca e interessante la manifestazione. Da parte nostra ci sono sempre stati impegno e passione nel diffondere la cultura della biodiversità, ospitando artisti e professionisti che sapessero coinvolgere e trasmettere al pubblico la bellezza e l'amore per l'ambiente.

Your contribution is fundamental because it will help us to improve the event and to render it ever more rich and interesting. On our part, there has always been a high level of commitment and passion in diffusing the culture of biodiversity and hosting artists and professionals that know how to transmit their beauty and love for the environment to the public.

Ma la dedizione non basta. È per questo che ti chiediamo di sostenerci. Il tuo contributo servirà a:

  • rinnovare l'immagine e migliorare il sito internet, rendendolo più coinvolgente e più aggiornato;

  • sostenere la partecipazione alla mostra di artisti e architetti di fama mondiale. Perché sono i cardini della manifestazione;

  • organizzare un maggior numero di attività scientifiche e di intrattenimento, per i grandi e per i bambini.

But dedication is not enough. It is for this reason that we ask you to support us. Your contribution will be used to:

  • renew our image and improve the website, updating it and making it more captivating.

  • to sustain the participation of world famous artists and architects in the exhibition, because they are the cornerstone of the event;

  • to organize a larger number of scientific activities and entertainment, for adults and for children.

Grazie per il supporto che vorrai darci!

Ti aspettiamo alla Mostra il 19, 20 e 21 settembre 2014.

Thank you for any support you are willing to give!

We will see you at the exhibition the 19th, 20th and 21st of September 2014.

www.laconservadellaneve.it

Seguici su / Follow us on

Facebook

Twitter

story:
The Spirit of Mawson

THE AUSTRALASIAN ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION 2013-2014

2013-2014 marks the centenary of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition led by the great scientist and explorer Sir Douglas Mawson. In a celebration of this remarkable endeavour, the new Australasian Antarctic Expedition (or AAE for short) will follow the route of its namesake, melding science and adventure, to discover and communicate the changes that have taken place in this remote environment over the last hundred years.

Led by Professor Chris Turney and Dr Chris Fogwill, from the University of New South Wales, Sydney, the 2013-2014 expedition will attempt to revisit the site of the original AAE huts at Cape Denison, Antarctica, the enigmatically named ‘Home of the Blizzard’. However, recent attempts to access the area have been thwarted by the presence of a large iceberg, which in 2010 lodged itself across the bay. Over the last three years an extensive area of sea ice has built up within the bay, effectively barring ships from entering the harbour at Cape Denison but potentially making it possible to access the site over its surface with all-terrain vehicles (popularly known as ATVs). We have chosen to attempt the crossing using ARGOs, unique eight-wheeled amphibious vehicles. We aim to access this scientifically and historically significant site, but to make this possible we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

To support our attempt to cross the sea ice and access Cape Denison we have secured two ARGOs in collaboration with ARGO ATV (Aus). However, to maximize the chances of our success in this remote region we need to secure at least one more ARGO.  We have selected the ARGO 8x8 Frontier, an amphibious all terrain utility vehicle designed for reliability in the toughest conditions.  The main chassis has been engineered using field-proven technology, allowing for increased payloads and greater durability under the harshest of conditions. This will allow us to tow large loads across the ice to support biological and environmental science projects below, on and above the ice.

Including snow tracks, winch system and operator covers, one of these ATVs costs a total of $37,919, critical to the success of this part of the expedition. If we exceed this target we may be able to get two Argos, improving our chances of getting in and allowing us to do more science on the sea ice! If we fall under our target, we will look to purchase a smaller model.

The concept of crowd funding with Indiegogo harks back to Mawson‘s original Antarctic expedition one hundred years ago, where many expedition items — including huskies, tents and sleeping bags — were funded by schools and public donations from across the world! To attract potential supporters we are able to offer a number of unique gifts and perks, ranging from limited edition t-shirts, exclusive photographic prints and the opportunity to join us virtually on the ice; you can even have an Argo named after you, your club, society or business!

The Impact

The Australasian Antarctic Expedition 2013-2014 is all about adventure, exploration, scientific discovery, and importantly communication. The AAE aims to engage with a broad audience live from Antarctica and the Southern Ocean throughout the expedition. Through a variety of media, including Google+ Hangouts on Air, Twitter and YouTube, we will broadcast live from Antarctica using the latest satellite technology to support live streaming from the ice.  

The Antarctic remains one of the last great unexplored regions on our planet. In spite of over a century of discovery – including aerial and satellite surveys – remarkably little of this great continent has been explored on the ground. Crucially this pristine southern polar region is uniquely placed to monitor the health of our planet. The Australasian Antarctic Expedition (AAE) will focus its efforts on the Antarctic Commonwealth Bay and subantarctic islands to provide the first complete snapshot of this region for a century.

The AAE has identified a team of scientists who are world experts in the natural and physical sciences while also being passionate about science communication. The research programmes to be undertaken include:

1. Oceanography: The Southern Ocean plays a crucial role in global climate and the carbon cycle. 90% of the world’s excess heat trapped by the atmosphere is going into the ocean and changing circulation patterns, threatening to turn the region into a source of carbon, exaggerating future warming. The AAE will make detailed measurements on the passage south (e.g. temperature, salinity, carbon) to determine just how sensitive the Southern Ocean is to change.

2. Climate: The ‘screaming sixties’, the ‘furious fifties’ and the ‘roaring forties’ filled sailors of old with dread. And yet these fearsome westerly winds are migrating inexorably southwards taking warmer water with them, threatening the stability of Antarctic ice. The AAE will collect peat, ice and rock samples to place satellite data in the context of the past millennia.

3. Biology: Recent expeditions to the Southern Ocean and Antarctica continue to report the discovery of thousands of new species, while living and ‘fossil’ animal and plant remains provide a sensitive measure of the changing environment. The AAE will observe, document and monitor the wildlife above and below the Antarctic ice, giving new insights into this unexplored region. 

By supporting our campaign and making it possible for our team to reach Cape Denison, you will be helping us to achieve our scientific goals and extend our work onto continental Antarctica. The Argos will make it possible for us to support science on the ice in this remote and hostile environment, thus providing a unique perspective for understanding and communicating the changes going on in this remote part of our planet over the past century. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Whilst not everyone can contribute directly to this campaign, we would love you to join us on the AAE. For more information of how to join the expedition either virtually or in person please go to www.spiritofmawson.com. Please spread the word with your friends, either through our web page, or with the Indiegogo share tools!!!
story_txt:
The Spirit of Mawson
THE AUSTRALASIAN ANTARCTIC EXPEDITION 2013-2014
2013-2014 marks the centenary of the Australasian Antarctic Expedition led by the great scientist and explorer Sir Douglas Mawson. In a celebration of this remarkable endeavour, the new Australasian Antarctic Expedition (or AAE for short) will follow the route of its namesake, melding science and adventure, to discover and communicate the changes that have taken place in this remote environment over the last hundred years.
Led by Professor Chris Turney and Dr Chris Fogwill, from the University of New South Wales, Sydney, the 2013-2014 expedition will attempt to revisit the site of the original AAE huts at Cape Denison, Antarctica, the enigmatically named ‘Home of the Blizzard’. However, recent attempts to access the area have been thwarted by the presence of a large iceberg, which in 2010 lodged itself across the bay. Over the last three years an extensive area of sea ice has built up within the bay, effectively barring ships from entering the harbour at Cape Denison but potentially making it possible to access the site over its surface with all-terrain vehicles (popularly known as ATVs). We have chosen to attempt the crossing using ARGOs, unique eight-wheeled amphibious vehicles. We aim to access this scientifically and historically significant site, but to make this possible we need your help!
What We Need & What You Get
To support our attempt to cross the sea ice and access Cape Denison we have secured two ARGOs in collaboration with ARGO ATV (Aus). However, to maximize the chances of our success in this remote region we need to secure at least one more ARGO.  We have selected the ARGO 8x8 Frontier, an amphibious all terrain utility vehicle designed for reliability in the toughest conditions.  The main chassis has been engineered using field-proven technology, allowing for increased payloads and greater durability under the harshest of conditions. This will allow us to tow large loads across the ice to support biological and environmental science projects below, on and above the ice.
Including snow tracks, winch system and operator covers, one of these ATVs costs a total of $37,919, critical to the success of this part of the expedition. If we exceed this target we may be able to get two Argos, improving our chances of getting in and allowing us to do more science on the sea ice! If we fall under our target, we will look to purchase a smaller model.
The concept of crowd funding with Indiegogo harks back to Mawson‘s original Antarctic expedition one hundred years ago, where many expedition items — including huskies, tents and sleeping bags — were funded by schools and public donations from across the world! To attract potential supporters we are able to offer a number of unique gifts and perks, ranging from limited edition t-shirts, exclusive photographic prints and the opportunity to join us virtually on the ice; you can even have an Argo named after you, your club, society or business!

Oceanography: The Southern Ocean plays a crucial role in global climate and the carbon cycle. 90% of the world’s excess heat trapped by the atmosphere is going into the ocean and changing circulation patterns, threatening to turn the region into a source of carbon, exaggerating future warming. The AAE will make detailed measurements on the passage south (e.g. temperature, salinity, carbon) to determine just how sensitive the Southern Ocean is to change.
2. Climate: The ‘screaming sixties’, the ‘furious fifties’ and the ‘roaring forties’ filled sailors of old with dread. And yet these fearsome westerly winds are migrating inexorably southwards taking warmer water with them, threatening the stability of Antarctic ice. The AAE will collect peat, ice and rock samples to place satellite data in the context of the past millennia.

story:
Help Save Monarchs and Bees at Scale... through habitat on solar sites

Join us  in launching a grassroots campaign celebrating and calling on solar developers to build solar farms that include habitat for monarch butterflies, honey bees, bumblebees, and other important pollinators. 

Monarch and bee populations are in crisis and the best way to help is to create more habitat. 

Developers can easily and cost-effectively incorporate region-specific deep-rooted grasses and wildflowers in the land management practices for solar farms. What's needed is a small change in the planning/building process to evaluate the costs of hauling in and maintaining gravel versus other ground cover crops.


     

What We Need 

The monarch butterfly population is at the lowest-recorded level in our lifetimes, and our honey bee and bumblebee pollinators that we rely on for our fruits and vegetables also are in serious decline

At a neighborhood level, everyone is encouraged to plant pollinator gardens. Solar sites are an opportunity to create millions of "pollinator gardens" throughout the United States.

Base Goal $5,500
An ad in a national solar industry trade magazine

Stretch Goal $24,000
A full-page ad in a prominent regional newspaper and an ad in a national solar industry trade magazine


The Impact

Minnesota alone will build 2,500 acres of solar farms over the next two construction seasons — equivalent to more than 750,000 12'x12' backyard bee & monarch gardens.
With your support, the five largest companies building these solar farms will include honeybee and monarch habitat on all of these sites, establishing a best-practice standard to be implemented nationwide.


Use of Funds / Campaign Thanks

  • As a 501(c)3, with a 25-year track record of work in the public interest, Fresh Energy will receive a nonprofit rate for buying the ad and all funds raised will be used for the ad campaign and the organization's work related to it.
  • If the base goal is not met, we will find a lower-cost ad placement. Funds that exceed one goal, but don't achieve another will be used for a lower-cost ad campaign.
  • Patagonia St. Paul has generously donated a special gift that will be given to someone drawn at random that has supported this campaign or entered to win. All campaign donors will be eligible. To enter at no cost, send a postcard with your name and address to Fresh Energy at 408 St. Peter St., St. Paul, MN 55102.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can chip in toward the financial goal, and we would also love your help in getting the word out. Here are some sample tweets/Facebook posts you can copy/paste:

  • Monarchs, honeybees, and birds need habitat. We all need clean energy.  Join us in calling for pollinator habitat on solar farms. http://pollinatorpledge.com
  • Start spring right, by calling for solar farms to be built with honeybee, monarch, and bird habitat. http://pollinatorpledge.com

The campaign team

  • Dr. Raj Rajan: global sustainability and innovation leader, board member of Fresh Energy
  • Michael Noble: Executive Director of Fresh Energy, an 501(c)3 non-profit organization that researches and advocates for policies that accelerate the transition to a clean energy economy
  • Dr. Karen Oberhauser: Professor in the Department of Fisheries, Wildlife and Conservation Biology at the University of Minnesota
  • Dr. Marla Spivak: MacArthur Fellow, Distinguished McKnight Professor, Department of Entomology at the University of Minnesota
  • Russ Henry: Land management and biodiversity consultant and president of Giving Tree Gardens

story:
My Clean City 

My Clean City is a national environmental program that strives to provide youth with progressive volunteer opportunities, positive leadership experiences, and impacting community involvements in the environmental sector. We are a leadership program run by youth for youth, with measurable results.

We acknowledge the potential of young people to make our world a better place. There are so many incredible resources and community programs dedicated to improving our environment, but lack active youth engagement. Rather than add to the overflowing sector, My Clean City strives to strengthen the existing efforts of committed organizations. We are a collaborative project that works with existing environmental organizations, and grassroot programs to engage, enable and evaluate youth volunteer actions with the goal of building a more environmentally sustainable future.

As the catalyst between non-profit organizations and today’s youth, My Clean City will provide a unified portal for like-minded individuals to access all of these opportunities and realize as a team the big difference many small actions can make!

My Clean City Approach

The common youth perspective of volunteering = work is no more. 

My Clean City instead makes volunteering = play, a game, an experience full of rewards!

Through an interactive online interface, youth will earn CleanCreds for the environmentally friendly activities performed. 

Differing from other environmental initiatives, My Clean City is a merit and results-based endeavor; beyond simply raising awareness of core environmental issues and problems, My Clean City strives to quantify youth impact through the recording of results and the crediting of volunteers and organizations that assist in environmental goals. Together—through this collaborative effort—we can reduce Canada’s carbon footprint and inspire others towards a cleaner country!


We Need You!

An integral pillar of our program is to acknowledge the work of young Canadian leaders. Through our CleanCred system, we strive to reward our passionate young environmental ambassadors for their hard work. 

CleanCreds are based on both effort (volunteer time donated) and impact (positive effect in our community); those with the highest cumulative total at the end of our program will be awarded scholarships and mentorship opportunities to grow their impact to the next level.

ALL the funds raised will go directly into these scholarships. Your contributions will be a donation that keeps on giving as you enable My Clean City to support our future community leaders. 

$5000 is the bare minimum we need for our scholarships. This will only cover a $500/province scholarship. 

Ideally we would like to offer at least $1000/province which would require us to raise $10,000.

Even better, with your generous support if you help us surpass this goal, we will be able to open up our scholarships to recognize more young leaders in your region.

Our wishlist is $30,000 to allow us to support 3 bright young leaders in each province.  

If you:

  • believe in the potential of youth
  • desire a more sustainable future
  • value bridging the gap between youth and community
  • wish to strengthen existing environmental efforts
  • foster leadership in young Canadians
  • empower leaders of today to find their ability to help community
  • move beyond awareness for environmental change and promote action....

if you answer yes to any of these, we urge you to consider supporting My Clean City in our efforts to build sustainable communities through the power of YOUth!


Who Are We

My Clean City embraces the power of youth in every form. We are youth run for youth. 

Volunteer driven our team is comprised of over 50 young leaders spanning from coast to coast of Canada. We are Canada's Top 20 Under 20, Shad Valley scholars, young UN Peacekeepers, Sustainability Student Union Presidents, Junior Achievement Leaders, key club & roteract leaders, environmental science majors, high school students, environmental club founders, passionate change leaders and more!

Meet Our Founder

Kelly Lovell is a youth ambassador dedicated to enabling young people to reach their potential. As a respected TEDx speaker, QEII Diamond Jubilee Recipient and Provincial Change the World Youth Ambassador, Lovell works tirelessly to provide opportunities for her peers to develop their leadership and ignite change.

“I have a simple goal to inspire an individual. Even one inspired heart can change this world, as they have the potential to spread their passion….I invite you to be a part of my quest for global change and inspiration." - Kelly Lovell

Watch her recent TEDx Talk and learn of the passion behind My Clean City first hand


Other Ways You Can Help

We are always open to your support. 

The best way you can offer additional support includes the following: 

1) Know environmental organizations that could benefit from connecting with more young volunteers or increasing local awareness of their programs? 

Connect them to us! We partner with environmental groups across Canada free of charge with the simple intention to strengthen their community impact. 

2) Have some spare time or looking for meaningful ways to get involved in your community?  OR know of a young person looking to get involved?

Volunteer with us and help My Clean City empower the young leaders of today to build a more sustainable tomorrow!

3) Have any connections with your local city hall?

My Clean City is reaching out to municipalities to help us recognize our young leaders. Your help in connecting us with your local council could enable regional youth to have their contributions recognized by your community

4) SPREAD THE WORD

Help My Clean City make a lasting impact in Canada and share our project with your networks, colleagues, friends and family


Thank you for your support. Together, we are confident we can create a better tomorrow, today!
